title: Moto Z Force still going strong

thread.text:
Been using for over a year now. 
Has stayed reasonably up to date with Security Updates.
Camera has been competent.
Battery life is still over a day in normal use. 
Bluetooth audio works as expected. No drops. I don't miss the 3.5mm headphone jack.
Couldn't agree more. 👍 Mine is still running strong as well.
I've had just enough days that I manage to drain the battery before days' end that I threw on a Tumi battery mod that was on sale, but overally I'm still quite happy with it too.
A year for me as well. "Knock on wood" I have been mostly issue free, and have not dumped it in the water.
Mine has been going great for over a year as well.. Still happy

A little over 10 months for me and still doing good as well. Two minor gripes are no 3.5mm headphone jack, not a big deal as I knew this going in and I don't really use headphones much. The other is the "shatter proof" screen. The screen is not flat, there are obvious waves in it. It also scratches way too easily. I put a glass screen protector on and there are a couple spots where it doesn't sit flat. I think I'd rather have a real glass screen. I'm very careful with my phone, and stuff happens, but give me gorilla glass.
All that being said, it's probably the best phone I've ever had. 
Not sure what next year will bring or what my next phone will be. I've gotten Motorola phones for my wife and I for many years now because of them having the most stock Android OS, and also because of the good sized battery. I don't like that Moto shrunk the battery in the second generation Force and Play, probably to nudge people into buying the battery mod, but I've got maybe 14 months more with this phone and who knows what will be out by then, lol.

I've always felt the Force was under appreciated. If it's not a samsung or crapple it just didn't get pushed as much by the sales force. 
I still absolutely love mine.

Still live mine as well. Have had it for 13 months. Have had the Tumi battery mod since day 1 along with the Verizon screen protector. The only issues I had were constant freezing / rebooting, which has mostly gone away after a Factory Data Reset.
just looked at the z3 force specs. staying with the original till it dies.

title: How-to: Fix "Your device has failed verification and may not work properly" message on boot error

thread.text:
I rarely reboot my device so I don't know when this error started happening. Some say it started with the first OS update (September security patch?) for Moto Z Droid/Moto Z Force Droid. For all I know, it could have been there from day one. I didn't think anything of it because I know I didn't modify anything - my bootloader remained locked (oem_locked appears on the fastboot screen). 
I noticed that this was causing an issue when Android Pay stopped working after it was updated to no longer work on devices where the bootloader was unlocked. Getting updated to Nougat did not resolve the issue. We got a discussion going on in the Lenovo support forums and after some time, it was suggested that we repair the OS install and for the Droid models, a customer-facing tool is available!https://forums.lenovo.com/t5/Moto-Z-.../3495375#M2268
Use the Verizon Software Update Assistant to repair the OS
Prerequisites: Windows or OSX, USB Type A to USB Type C cable (you could probably do C to C if you had a newer Macbook)Download and install the Software Update Assistant
Windows: http://www.motorola.com/verizonsoftwareupdatewin
Mac: http://www.motorola.com/verizonsoftwareupdatemacOpen Software Update AssistantConnect your Moto Z Droid or Moto Z Force Droid to the computer.Swipe down the Notification Shade and select the "Software Installation" option.Wait for the Software Update Assistant to detect your phone.When your phone is detected, click Restore.You'll be prompted to choose Erase or Keep Data.The Software Update Assistant will download the OS image, then install it to the phone. The phone will reboot to the Fastboot menu. Do not disconnect the phone.When complete, the phone will reboot and you can disconnect it from the computer. 
If this is happening on a GSM unlocked model, I'm not sure if there's a application available.

title: Why does the notification feature not work on the Motorola phones when you switch texting programs?

thread.text: I spoke in length with a rep about this that was higher up and he just said that when you switch messenger apps on Motorola phones, it damages the software that not even a hard reset (manual reset) can fix. Unfortunately, you're stuck with the default messenger application on the device in order for notifications of any messaging or texting app to work properly. Hence why Samsung and Apple control the marketplace (in his words). So, you got about a 90 day manufacturer warranty where you can switch phones twice. Outside of that, it's $8.99 p mo for AT&T's insurance plan that'll cover you for 2 switches in a year which for my Motorola z2 Force isn't worth it since Motorola just came out with a plethora of new phones and now this one is a lot cheaper (the mods too) from trusted sellers on eBay.

replies.text: On both my current first gen Moto Z Force and my previous third gen Moto X switching between Android Messages and Verizon Messages+ causes no issues with notifications. Could you elaborate more on the problems you are having?
It’s too bad you didn’t talk to a rep who knew what he or she was talking about. I haven’t read such nonsense in a long time. ESPECIALLY the part about the hard reset.

thread.text:
I'm not sure what you mean. I've been using Textra on different Moto devices with no problems at all. 
There are some problems when you change the message app on Moto devices, but, as far as I know, only if you disable or uninstall (after root) the stock app. If you only switch the default app you shouldn't experience any problem.

replies.text: Makes sense. I disabled the stock app when I switched and when that app didn't work for notifications and affected my whole phone, I went back to the stock app and re-enabled it. So, that would be the only problem is disabling the stock app? Is there a way to fix this beyond cashing in on my warranty? I thought in order to switch messenger apps you had to first disable any other apps that exist in the same context.

thread.text: Sounds like it. You don't really need to disable the stock app, just change default in settings - apps - gear icon top right - SMS app.

If you are still having issues after enabling the app back try a couple of things. First make sure everything is updated on the Play Store, disabling an app usually uninstalls recent updates. After this, wipe the cache partition from the recovery menu and see if it helps.

title: How to disable AppFlash in newest Z Force update

thread.text:
Just got a new update (Dec 1, 2017), which included installing AppFlash. Here is Verizon's description of AppFlash:http://forums.androidcentral.com/e?l...token=L9coqyCq
I'm not personally interested in having Verizon suggest things to me, so I looked into disabling it. It's a little hidden, so I thought I'd share how to do it.
+ Go to Settings (swipe down from the top of the screen, click the gear icon)
+ Tap on Apps
+ Tap the 3dot menu button in the upper right, tap "show system"
+ Scroll down & find the AppFlash app, tap on it
+ Tap Disable
Pretty easy.

replies.text: Thanks for the information. You might also want to check your Systems app for Mobile Services Manager, which is the former DT Ignite. This should also be disabled, as it allows Verizon to install apps on your phone.

Anticipating the new version of Android (Oreo) coming soon (and hoping to fix the freeze and camera issues I've been having) I'd like to know if it's best to Factory Data Reset before or after the upgrade?

I have not had to Factory Reset my Z Force yet, through numerous OS Updates and system version updates. But when I have had issues in the past, with other phones, I have:
Turn Off the automatic "Back up my... " option in Settings.
Back up all personal data and Factory Reset.
Download & install the new update.
Factory Reset again if you feel it's necessary. Doesn't hurt at this point.
Start setting the phone up again as new. This is where Turing off the Automatic Backup My Data ones in useful....it let's you setup your phone fresh & clean, no auto download of the same apps & Settings you had before. Slowly start downloading apps and updating Settings, etc.

For those that are not aware of this issue, be very, very careful about the USB C cables that you buy online; many of them can be dangerous to your phone (think Note 7.) It may be that Amazon is only selling safe cables now, but there was a time when they were selling many that were dangerous. An engineer at Google named Benson Leung spent a lot of time in the last year evaluating many cables and power adapters for safety. This web site does a good job of showing those that are safe: https://usbccompliant.com

thread.text: OK, here is the skinny. I've been through a ton of chargers and I've verified these results. With standard USB-A to USB-C chargers, you can get a maximum of 2.4A, which will not trigger the "turbo charging" notification. Moto mod battery packs will charge, but the charging notification for the battery mod may not show it is charging. (It does.) If you have a USB-C to USB-C charger that can deliver 3A or more (I have a Cheotech wall charger that meets this spec) you can get the moto mod battery to show a charge notification properly, and can get a more rapid charge. With the Moto wall wart charger, you can get up to 5.4A charge, which is extremely quick. BTW the car charger is 3A as well, and will trigger the "turbo charging" notification. So if you want a portable rapid charger, look for a 3A USB-C to UB-C charger. The USB-A to C chargers are generally limited to 2.4 A. These will work but are slower and may give misleading charging notifications for battery mods (but they will work).

2.4a is pretty quick, but 5.4a... Wow.
Thanks for the info!

I don't plug my stuff into a computer, no need for that these days. I have multiport chargers that have all or some of their ports that are QC 2.0. Even battery packs with QC ports.

I guess I can get the amps for you if you are curious to how QC 2.0 works. Otherwise when I put it in the non QC port, it charges any device as fast as it can (other than QC or or turbo speeds), but when plugged into a QC port, it's super fast.

The stock Aukey USB-C to USB-C doesn't work at all though... Not even to slow charge.
Mod note, I have cleaned up the links.

Just to clear things up, The Moto Z line doesn't use any variation of Qualcomm's QuickCharge, it uses the USB Power Delivery 2.0 spec, which was introduced with USB 3.1 and USB-C concurrently. The two steppings of power that the Moto Z line uses are 15W on the 5V line and 27W on the 9V line.

replies.text: See this thread: https://forums.androidcentral.com/sh...d.php?t=706935

Turbo charging ONLY works with type-C. That could be the hardwired charger that comes with it, or many of the aftermarket type C chargers, with a type-c to type-c cable (as described in the thread that Ry linked to). None of the USB-A to USB-C cables, or microUSB to type-c adapters are going to turbocharge.

title: Fix for tiny chip in metal frame

thread.text:
My phone fell from like 6 inches today. Not sure if it hit a little debris on the ground or what, but I was very surprised to see a tiny dent/chip in the frame on the top right corner. 
Does anyone know if the metal frame is painted or if that's the color of the metal, and the material on its own?
The color I have is the black lunar grey model. 
Anyone have an option for a good paint? Honestly, it's so tiny and looks like a slight discoloration more than anything else, but I'm kind of ocd, so I would love to try and fix it if possible.
I hear the OCD. I'd like to know if there's a paint color too

I imagine it has to be paint, not the material, since there are 3 different color frames and I doubt they'd use 3 different materials. No idea where to get properly matching paint, though. Could get a vinyl wrap to cover it and protect from future little nicks.

replies.text: Yeah I agree with that logic for sure. It must be paint. Thank you

thread.text: You can get a plastic liquid filler for the dent to fill it in and smooth it out one dried. Any AutoZone will have touch up paint to match well enough to blend it in. This is what I would do. Sorry to hear about your phone man.

replies.text: Thank you, I'll check on that. Sounds like a good idea. Any recommendations for a specific product?

thread.text: I've seen some at Walmart, AutoZone and advance auto parts. Also check any hardware stores. Home depot or Lowe's. Just a small tube of some sort of filler that hardens or cures after it sets up a few minutes to an hour. Don't get the concrete or metal. I would try and find a liquid plastic or hardened rubber filler. There is also a paste where you can apply the divit yourself and then just run your finger over it to flush it out. Then all you have left to do is just touch it up and truthfully, I'd just find a sharpie color that closely matches and dab it until it blends. You might find touch up enamel paint but it may be costly. I'd lean towards the paste filler so it can be formed to the divit so much easier. Let it dry and then hunt for the color after. You may even find a paste filler that's dark and won't have to paint. One thing about the paint is it will seal the filler in which probably isn't a bad idea as the filler could chip out later if not solidified by something. You have a pic of the damage? Also get some of the finest grain sand paper you can get to smooth it out before touch up. Hope this helps and let us know how you come out.

replies.text:
Much appreciated! Honestly it's really tiny. I'm almost embarrassed to take a photo of it. I wouldn't even call it a divot. I'm actually trying to figure out if it needs any filler at all or if it just needs to be painted. 
I'll do some shopping and send a before an after. 
Thank you!
So did you fix it?

thread.text: I know how you feel. It would bother me too. I collect high end watches and although I wear them, they are as new as the day I got them. I'm a fanatic about keeping things like new and also keeping all boxes and paperwork with my phones too. Adds value if you ever resale any of it. I know lots of people who just toss their boxes away. I in no way could do that. I just store them all away. Hope you get it fixed or well enough that you don't notice it anymore.

The phone is just a tiny bit too wide with the squared off back. We came from the Droid Turbo which is only 2-3 mm narrower, but its curved back made it much more comfortable for one handed use. It's such a problem that my wife and I are debating returning both of ours to Best Buy and getting the Galaxy S7 tomorrow.
Aside from that, we've both been disappointed with the strength of signal and drop calls where we never dropped them before.
The Bluetooth doesn't ever automatically connect to my car like the Turbo does, and when I do connect it, the default Bluetooth volume is always ZERO. When I turn up the volume, it's as if the phone is resistant and will only increase a little at a time.
Any suggestions?

I don't like the fact that I haven't been able to stop playing with the damn thing since I bought it. 
Only thing I don't "like" so far is that the leather Moto Style Back is unavailable. Did it surprise Lenovorola that the phone was being released? Because, you know, it shouldn't have, since it's their phone. I'd really like to get the leather back to replace the "wood" one that came with the phone. I'm also not thrilled by the bumper case made available to go with the Z Force Droid. Not only are they sort of ugly, but the charging port hole doesn't line up correctly. And if I had one design change to make, it would be to put the power button on the top or opposite side from the volume buttons. These are all very minor nitpicks as I'm enjoying the Z Force Droid immensely. They really made quite a winner here. A shame not enough people are going to give it a try because of the Verizon exclusivity and the fact it will get lost in the wash of the Note 7 and iPhone 7 releases. Bad timing.
I'm not happy with how thin it feels. It helps with the battery pack on. But then I won't be able to use an Otterbox case. So that is one thing that I don t like.
Qi charging would have been nice.
I'm not happy that it hasn't arrived yet. Played with one at Best Buy though and so far everything else I have to say is going in the other thread.
I too don't like that my Moto Z Force DROID isn't here yet.

The lack of bumper case alternatives to the Verizon one, which needs modification to be useful. Plenty of "bumper" cases on Amazon for it, but those are all just full-coverage TPU cases, not bumpers. I'm thinking about getting one of those and cutting out the back panel to approximate a bumper. I want to protect the edges, but I also want to be able to use mods freely, so I need a bumper that doesn't suck...
(Before anyone asks, I have a razor for cutting TPU, but not a Dremel for finely trimming plastic; I don't mind the actual modification, but I need to be able to do it without investment).

thread.text:
*Too slippery (hopefully a diff styleshell fixes this)
*Speaker pop

A few more:
- the bottom antenna band sits around the USB-C port. It's plastic so it will get scratched for sure. 
- ships with the may 01 security update. So it ships three months behind on updates.
- lack of notification LED ( always on display almost mitigates this but not quite )

Grid was a problem. I quickly went with Nova Launcher and 5x6 grid.
The shell it comes with is slippery. No good. Ordered a bumper case. I also read where the shatterproof screen can scratch easier, so I'm adding a tempered glass to it.
I agree that I'm hoping future cases will allow for use with mods, especially the battery mod.
The device speakers are a trade up to my former z3v speakers. And the free speaker mod is great! No issues there.
Calls are a little tinny to my ear. No matter. Volume is fine. Wife says she cannot tell when I have her on speaker phone. A plus for sure.
I personally love the size and the edges. The volume buttons should be under the power button. But I'm getting used to it.
Never used the headphone jack. Not a missing to me. 
Battery is an improvement over my old phone. And quick charge is great. Just wish it was wireless charging.
And I wish it was IP68.

Waterproof is not a issue for me although I see why many people like it. Headphone jack is also not a issue since I always use Bluetooth headphones. I am waiting for a wireless charging mod without the battery though. I'm sure it will come. Just a matter of when. 
Maybe when the device becomes available for more markets they will announce more mods as incentive to get more people to purchase the device.

This one is nit picky, but still annoying to me. The hotspot quick settings tile takes seconds to acknowledge a press. 
The reviews I saw mentioned gorilla glass on the back. Besides the two steps at the upper and lower edge the back appears to be plastic.

replies.text:
Most of the back is metal - the mods have magnets, the back of the phone is metal.
Also, I assume you're referring to the pulldown menu hotspot button? The issue with it is that stock Android doesn't have an icon for "in process". So it either shows as off or on, and when you first tap it and it starts thinking, the icon doesn't change until it's actually ready to be used. I agree that should change, perhaps to an icon without the slash through it, but still grayed out.
Wow. While u realized the mods used magnets I never thought about how exactly it worked. I assumed the phone and the mods had magnets!

I personally feel the whole scratch prone thing was seriously overblown. I use my phone in pretty harsh surroundings everyday. 
My screen protectors have always gotten scratched, so honestly I'm thrilled with the natural scratch resistance of the T2, and expect the same with the Z-force, if not better due to it being the next generation.

thread.text: When I listen to podcasts without the JBL speakers, the regular speakers will sometimes "pop" like an old-time radio. Rare, but it happens.

I bought the Verizon Shell/Holster combo with Kickstand. The shell doesn't add a lot of bulk to the phone, and it has a nice grippy feel. The only time I use the holster is when I throw it in my purse. It works really well.
Lately I just use the "wood" style back and a leather Jison slip-in pouch.

The vibration is a little weak on calls. I always leave my phone on vibrate at night, and with my T2, never missed a call. Missed 2 this morning and noticed after a couple more calls today that the vibration isn't as strong as I would like.

replies.text: Interesting. I love the vibration motor on this phone. It feels so... Premium.

I agree, it feels premium, especially the haptic button press feedback, and for texts and emails as well. For some reason the ringer vibration is comparatively lighter based on first impression. 
I also don't love the lack of breathing on the moto display, even if the need is somewhat nullified by the hand waving sensor. 
And the security kind of makes the moto Voice less useful as well. I love the fingerprint sensor for turning the phone on and off, but don't like having to turn the phone on to take advantage of the features of moto voice. I used to have no security on my phone to avoid this issue, but I like the fingerprint sensor. I'm not worried about security. thread.text:
Having had a Droid Razr for a couple of years, followed by the vastly improved RazrMaxxHD for another couple of years, I'm used to the top button turning the screen on, the button underneath for volume. What possessed Motorola to have two volume buttons at the top, and the turn on button underneath is a mystery to me. Taking awhile but I'm getting used to it, even an old dog can sometimes learn new tricks.
How slippery the 'wood' back plate is. When I first bought the phone (at the store) they were out of the leather back plate, so I opted for an Evo Check case protector. Fits well, very grippy, and the plug for the charger fit after the rubber stretched a bit. To begin with I had to undo the bottom of the case to plug in the charger, but that resolved itself within a few days. The edges of the glass are protected as the Evo Check wraps over them a bit. Even though the glass is guaranteed against breakage for 4 years, an ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure. 
The volume could be better on calls. I find I have to use the speaker phone, as I did on the two razrs that preceded this device. Overall I'm very happy with it. Wider and taller than the razr maxx, but the larger view, larger keyboard, make up for that , and I've already gotten used to the size.

thread.text: ^That is bad. If you post some battery stats, especially using an app like gsam battery monitor we might be able to help. In general, you might have really bad signal that drains battery, an app or apps running in the background that shouldn't or a bad unit that needs to be replaced.
Thank you! Installing gsam now, this is my second Z force and battery is the same. I will run it another day after full charge and post the results.

replies.text: If this is your second one to do this I'm suspecting really poor signal and/or some apps running rogue in the background. Give it a day or so and grab some screen shots. It's especially important to see what apps are using the most battery and your signal strength.

Thanks again for the help, here are a few from today, off battery for about 3 hours and at 76 percent. I did stream about 45 minutes of audio and made about hour of calls. I'll post more at end of day.
One bar of reception...Is that normal?

My first thought, too - weak signal, and 3G to boot. Weak signal will kill the battery.
Also, one hour of display on in 3 hours. That's a lot of screen on time in such a short period. (Interesting that "phone" is crossed off, but it shows up in app suckers.)
I don't use Instagram, but if there is a way to turn off background updates, I'd consider that as well. You can catch up when you actually open the app.
The fact that GSAM is high on the list suggests to me that the issue is more with poor signal than app use, though.

Couldn't agree more. 
Also agree about Instagram. Unless you absolutely need to see your notifications on the app icon, I would turn off background updates.
Unless things have changed with this phone. When WIFI is on the phone isn't really using the cell radio (what your seeing as 3G signal)

For data, correct. However, the phone is always using cellular connectivity - check for calls, text messages, etc. When the signal is low, the phone must provide more power to the antenna to hold a signal, using battery faster than if you have a good signal.

Another app I would install is called Signal Check Lite. It will show you what your actual signal strength is. Post some screen shots. The higher the number the worse it is. Here's my story....... I'll try to keep it short. 
I had a bad 4g signal for years. Mine was an average of -120 to -125. I couldn't hold a 4g signal and was forced onto WiFi or 3g. 
Before I bought the Z Force I made several calls to Verizon. I refused to give up. I now have a 4g network extender. But I had to call several times and threaten to leave with several accounts. 
But be careful they don't try to force you into a 3g network extender. You pay for 4g so why shouldn't you get what you pay for. 
If your phone is searching for a signal that will drain your battery fast. Be sure if you go into location settings and touch the menu 3 buttons top right of the screen, scanning should pop up. Touch that and shut off wifi and Bluetooth scanning unless you need them. That will also drain your battery. 
At night I shut off 4g and touch the 3 menu button and restrict background data. Calls and texts still come through. But it's my data and I don't allow apps to use it in the background unless I'm using that app. 
I hope these help. From your screen shots I suspect a bad signal strength. But I could be wrong. Give it a try and see.

Well, a 4G LTE extender requires that you have internet connectivity with 5 Mbps upload and 10 Mbps download minimum though Verizon recommend 10 Mbps down and 20 Mbps up. If you don't have that from your internet provider, make sure that you upgrade, or go for the 3G extender. Also be aware that it has about a 50' radius maximum.

Both very good points. Thank you for pointing that out.
I have found the 50' radius to be way low. I actually have to remember that I am connected to it when I leave the house. For me I can get almost a block away before it disconnects, and disconnects any call I might be on. Verizon had an option to add certain telephone numbers to restrict who connects to it which is nice.

Resurrecting thread.
I'm coming from a note 5 and was hoping to upgrade to note 7, but that will not be happening. My biggest gripe and not waiting on the note 5 is no SD card slot. I'm not interested in down grading to sg7.
Long story short, my other half picked up the black moto z force because his HTC m8 was going down hill. I got the white/gold one. Verizon Corp stores have a special, buy one moto z force get the other one 50% off. Plus $300 trade in credit on his HTC m8 towards a new phone. Basically, we are getting two moto z force's for a hair more than what would cost monthly for one. It was a no brainer. I would get my SD card slot back and I could pay off what I owe on the phone anytime when the note 8 arrives next year if I don't like/enjoy the device.
I'm not too bad of a Samsung butt lover so don't give me too much crap. I really love the camera and spen. I hate touchwiz with a passion.
Anyhow, about my dislikes on the moto z force: it's a slippery phone. I had the moto turbo 2 and loved how it felt in the hand. So, I am looking for at least the JBL speaker moto mod or a different back plate with the bumper.
Second, the camera really sucks in low lighting or when not using the flash with bad lightning. I was really hoping moto was gonna update this from the turbo 2. I feel they would really corner the market and be up there to be an apple/Sammy killer. Why didn't they fix this. I try my best with other 3rd party camera/photo apps out on the market.
Third, why not Miracast? You can only mirror your phone with Chromecast right now. I'm hoping this will be fixed in a future update as I did research this in other forums. I mirror a lot on my Roku. For now, it looks like I'll be buying a Chromecast stick until the fix comes. Sighs.
There's other little things but nothing I can't get use to like the mia notification light. Too bad they don't even give you the option of firing off the flash for notifications in the accessibility menu.
What I love about the phone is the vanilla Android os. If moto does one thing right, it's this. They give you the ability to customize your phone with no rooting. I'm a big fan of Nova Prime and it continues to run smooth on the motos.
Second, the ability to have the SD card slot back. Yes, Sammy brought this back in the sg7 lines but I want a note series phone with the spen.
The battery is fabulous! I don't need to say more about that. You all know.
And lastly I'm looking forward to using a bumper with the moto mods and different back plates. Again, anything to play around with customizing is a plus for me.
Thanks for reading! 😀

thread.text: I dont like that the power option doesnt have a restart, all it has is power off, this is the first phone i have ever had without a restart option.

replies.text: Motorola phones are close to stock Android, and at least from ICS through Nougat 7.0, stock Android has not had a restart in the power off menu. I read somewhere that Nougat 7.1 has it on the Pixel and Android One, though, so I bet it'll come eventually to this phone?
My Nexus 6p has it, my Z Force doesn't. You know though, if you just hold down the power button for a few seconds, it'll restart.
As far as I know, holding down the power button to restart isn't a "clean" shut off.

From Motorola:
Reset the Moto Z Force
In the unlikely event that your device becomes unresponsive, frozen, blank or black screen, or will not respond to the power button, you can perform a force restart on the device by following the steps below.
Press and hold the Power button for 10 - 20 seconds, the device will restart and go through the boot-up sequence.
Note: The forced restart or reboot will not delete any data on your phone.
When I say "clean", I'm under the impression that this method simulates a battery pull and power up.

The bios is what handles the button presses. Normally it passes the presses to the OS, but in cases like holding the power button down for 10 seconds it will power down everything into a shut down state regardless of what the OS is doing. The OS will have no warning and any non saved info or half saved files could become corrupt. Normal file housekeeping will fix the files but by fixed I mean they will delete them, so its never something you should use normally. Desktops and Notebooks have been doing this for decades and it is the same thing. 
It is intended for use when ever the OS/phone freezes and becomes unresponsive. I haven't come across a case where the bios couldn't shut down properly, but I wouldn't be surprised if bricked firmwares failed to shutdown.

title: Outgoing and incoming calls on speaker phone

thread.text:

Does the phone have a Car Mode that might be getting activated by accident?
That's happened to me occasionally. It is annoying.

I've had this happen but only once. It happened after receiving a call just as I killed the ignition to exit my vehicle (and, connected Bluetooth). As I put a foot on the ground I heard my phone announce the call & afterwards, speakerphone became default. I remedied by clearing the recovery cache.

Moto voice is on which will announce calls and texts while driving. Just now as I made an outgoing call, it got placed on the speaker phone. 
In talking with Verizon support, they first said to turn off Moto voice. It isn't practical to turn this on and off each time I get in the car or out of the car. 
They then made a suggestion to clear the system cache partition. What will that do as far as data and apps that are installed?

replies.text: Nothing. It is completely benign. It basically just clears old log files, temporary files, etc., that will no longer be necessary.

I'm following steps provided by Verizon to wipe the cache partition, but it's not working. 
I'm able to get as far as selecting recovery mode. The instructions at this point indicate that I should see the Android robot with the exclamation point, which I do. The instructions state I should hold the power button and press volume up. The only problem is that upon getting into recovery mode, all I see is 'no command.' No combination of button presses does anything.
What am I doing wrong?

thread.text:
Hmm, not sure. The instructions that I see say that when you see the red exclamation droid, hold the power button, press volume up once and then release the power button.
If that still doesn't work, try press power and volume up at exactly the same time.
If you have a bumper or other case on it, take it off so the buttons are more responsive.

Despite not successfully wiping the cache partition, turning off the phone and going into recovery mode seems to have fixed the issue with the calls over speaker phone. 
While the official Motorola instructions indicated to press power and volume up to get the option to wipe the cache, another set of instructions indicated that it was necessary to boot into FastBoot mode and then the recovery mode, after which I would get the wipe cache option.

This seems to occur after letting Moto Voice answer a call for you ("Say answer or ignore" and you say "answer"). Once this happens, speakerphone defaults to on for any calls I receive (possibly calls I make but I can't remember). So far it seems that if I reboot, the problem goes away.
This sucks, as it tends to cause great pain in my ear when I answer if I don't remember to reboot. Definitely a bug since you can't undo it without rebooting.

I've talked to Verizon about this issue since it's still continuing to happen. I don't think they are aware of this issue as a bug and they just tell me since the phone is out of warranty that all I can do is do a factory reset. How is that going to fix the bug?
I have also contacted Motorola support and they have only suggested to clear the cache partition.
I don't think I should have to keep restarting the phone each time after I've used Moto voice. 
What's the way that this could be proven as a known issue to Motorola so that it will get fixed?
What's interesting is that I haven't noticed this since my previous post in this thread... Are you on the latest update?

I'm on 7.1.1 with the September security update.

I have a few manually created contacts that have somehow been duplicated. These contacts were created manually either by entering the number and creating a phone contact or saving the number after a call and creating a phone contact.
My contacts had been backing up to the Verizon cloud. That cloud reverted to contacts only when Verizon took away my data storage. I got them to put data storage back, and it was after this that I noticed a few duplicate contacts.
I'm unable to simply delete the duplicate without both the original and duplicate being deleted. There's no duplicate contacts that exist in the cloud and so far the only solution offered by Verizon is to reset the phone. replies.text: I've found the easiest way to deal with contacts is to use Gmail. All your contacts are backed up on Google. Not a fan of Verizon Cloud. thread.text: I agree 100% with Google Contacts. I setup my contacts that way with my first smart phone in 2010 and all my Contacts have instantly synced with every new phone since then. And Google has a find and merge duplicates feature when logged in from a computer. You can export contacts out of your phone, then import into Google Contacts from a computer, find & merge duplicates, then re-sync back to your phone as Google Contacts.

title: Can I rollback Nougat if I need to?

thread.text: Suppose I do the Nougat update on my Moto Z Force and don't like it. Can I rollback that update?
The only way to rollback is re-imaging the phone with the marshmallow image and you will need a computer to download and install it.

replies.text: Unless there is something different about the Z Force, Moto Droid phones never allow a version downgrade. The bootloader will not allow you to flash a lower version of itself.
Maybe the bootloader is locked and does not allow to install an image from the computer.

thread.text: thanks. Not interested in doing that.
Why wouldn't you like it is the question? It's exactly like marshmallow with a couple of new tweaks

replies.text: Well, some of the apps that are critical to my business have not been verified to run properly under Nougat. I didn't want to find out the hard way that they won't handle Nougat.
I updated mine (like an I d i o t) and now want to go back to MM. My reason is MM made a feature(I can't speak about due to site rules) quit working.
Wut
Yea Heath I follow you. I held onto unlimited plan because of that. Hoping there's a work around soon.
Same here...
On the Moto Z Force Nougat has disabled Screencasting for some unknown reason. Likely because they have their counterpart Chromecast so they can tell you bend over and buy our hardware.

thread.text: If in doubt.... It's not compulsory to update...
The simple answer is no.
You can't downgrade. I tried flashing Marshmallow and it fails to flash the files.
My bootloader is unlocked. Just went to see if I can and it allows you to unlock it

replies.text: Honestly that means nothing with a Verizon Droid phone.

With Moto phones, that still doesn't matter. (I am shocked that the bootloader is unlock able BTW. Are you sure that this is a Moto Z Force Droid Edition from Verizon? Or do you possibly have an unlocked Moto Z or Z Play (not Force, not Droid)?) Once the bootloader gets updated to a new version, it will not allow a downgrade, unlocked or not, and I am 99.99% sure that the signed partitions that are flashed will only boot with specific bootloader versions. 
Of course that's not true if somebody has developed an M custom ROM that you can flash, but, again, that's only possible with an unlocked bootloader.

thread.text: I assume that, if I don't install the Nougat update, I'll still be able to install future security updates and Moto fixes. Correct?

replies.text: As far as I know, future security patches will be on the current track as in there won't be security updates for phones still on Marshmallow.

thread.text: Sure.

Why wouldn't you like it is the question? It's exactly like marshmallow with a couple of new tweaks
They removed the option to turn off notifications when on a call. Now there is this sweet feature of when actually using the phone as a phone and an email, text, VM or ANY OTHER thing that happens that causes a notification, the sound will now play in the middle of your conversation. 
What a great feature to have.

title: Considered playing the field but am sticking with the Z Force

thread.text:
I'm a Z force owner. Like a lot of you I'm sure, I've been watching the fall phone releases pretty closely. 
It's tempting to change, especially since I moved a couple of years ago to buying phones outright and reselling them to make it easier to change when I wanted to. 
I want a large screen, battery life, top performing camera, and fast/not laggy software - and don't want to pay top dollar. I also use Verizon.. potentially willing to swtich but still prefer phones that work on all four US carriers for resale value.
This year is unlike other years - no phone is the clear cut best for me. 
All the new phones have things that are awesome, but all have at least one major flaw as well. With prices rising as they have, none of them seem worth it.
1. Pixel 2 XL - mediocre screen, high price, already more reports of bluetooth reliability being poor (but awesome everything else)
2. LG VX30 - screen, laggy software (quad DAC, great camera)
3. Note 8 - $#%^ expensive, laggy software (but awesome camera)
4. Razer phone - unproven camera, no CDMA (but big battery.. and camera could be ok)
5. Mate 10 Pro - crappy software (but the HW looks awesome)
6. HTC U11+ - looks near perfect, but not sold in US (why didn't Google go with this phone for the 2 XL?)
7. OnePlus 5T - could be great, but the camera needs to be better, still no CDMA
8. Essential PH-1 - terrible camera (but awesome HW, fast stock SW, and a currently good value price)
9. iPhone 8 Plus - expensive, like being able to customize the experience on Android, camera not the best anymore
So, with all that said, I decided to just stick with the Z Force. the moto power pack for just $38 to make sure the phone lasts a day (I'm a heavy user so battery life had already degraded). Reformatted to improve performance and stability.. and with just those changes I'm reminded of how much I like this phone. Moto does a great job with software and radios, which are often undervalued. The ability to add battery capacity and other features via mods is very well done.
This really is a great phone.. low-light photography and lack of headphone jack are my only real complaints. Here's to another year.. or at least another few months

replies.text:
Exactly my criteria as well. It's gotta be the Pixel 2 XL. Just wait until it's on sale. 
The "mediocre screen" is an inflated detraction, on the Pixel 2 XL, IMO. Google has already addressed the so-called flat colors and also the potential burn-in problem with software updates. Plus, they added a year onto the warranty so it has a two year warranty. I've seen several in the stores and, yes, there is a detectable blue tint when angling the phone but it's not terrible. Also, I would not characterize the Moto screen as being anything special.
Great battery, top performing camera, snappy performance--that's Pixel 2 XL
Another candidate would be the Galaxy S8 Active, but it's not yet on Verizon (but probably will be.) Got to watch for the dreaded Samsung lag though.

thread.text: Well, there is also the iPhone 7 Plus; it's true that it's not new, but it's not as expensive as the 8 Plus and still has a great wide angle camera and true "telephoto" camera (and a better camera than the Z Plus), and will definitely keep its resale value better than the Z Force will. In fact, if resale value is part of the measure, this is the best time going forward to sell the Z Force. The 7 Plus would be a great bridge phone for a year based on your criteria. (Get the Verizon model or the SIM free model for the ability to sell on any US carrier for resale.)

The Z Force in general is not a great choice for resale value.. had to give that up when I bought it, so I'm ok not worrying about that for now.. just like to pick something that works with that going forward. You are of course right that now is better than later though. I'm just not sure I can switch to iOS.. like the way I can tweak Android to work the way I want too much.

I agree the Pixel 2 XL's screen is fine, and that the Z Force's is nothing special. 
I'm more worried about radio quality with the Pixel 2 XL. I had to get rid of a Nexus 6P which was otherwise a great phone because wifi and Bluetooth would not stay connected consistently. This was supposedly a pretty common problem with the OG Pixels, and, while early, it appears the Pixel is having some of the same issues. Too early to decide, so I'll keep an eye on how much chatter there is about that type of issue. The Z Force has never given me any issues with the radios.

replies.text:
Yes, radios are one of Motorola's strong suits. 
Reading the Pixel 2 forums there are some bluetooth problem threads but most are of the nature of "my Pixel 2 XL works great with "X" device doesn't pair with my "Y" device. Or people are having problems with pairing to a particular vehicle. Also, people that have owned both OG Pixel and Pixel 2's say the Pixel 2's bluetooth works better.

thread.text:
That's quite helpful, thanks! I do have my eye on a Pixel 2 XL as the likely best fit for me.. will see if the price drops down the road and the radios perform well. The HTC U11+ would be great as well if it makes it to the US.
Also, I forgot to put the Essential Phone in my first list. Great HW, stock SW, good value at current pricing, but apparently a terrible camera.
This is just such an odd year for Android flagships - so many options that look great but have a fatal flaw. It's frustrating to see such great phones in some dimensions that fail in others...

The last week or so I've noticed a drastic increase in location searching on my Z Force. Almost every time I wake the phone or launch an app I see the GPS icon flash on. 
It isn't causing any significant battery drain. And I don't see anything out of the ordinary using the location services. But it just seems strange to me. I haven't changed any settings or added anything.
Anybody else seeing this or have any ideas on what it could be?

replies.text: Maybe a recent app update has enabled location that didn't before. I started to look in Settings/Apps/Permissions. It's amazing how many apps want our location. Also, you could check your Settings/Location/3 dots upper left corner/Scanning to see if WiFi or Bluetooth scanning is enabled. This might activate location.

thread.text: I've seen that off and on in the past, but not recently. Sorry I can't tell you why either.

While I try to resist temptation from a possible Black Friday deal for the Z2 Force I thought I'd post a wishlist for the 2018 version.

5. Continued improvements to screen Shattershield. Needs to be readily available, easier to replace, and cheaper to replace.

title: Unable to send text via Moto voice

thread.text:
I'm trying to send a text message via the Moto voice app. Instead of the app doing what I ask it to, a message comes up that says unable to connect to Google.
What does Google have to do with sending a text message? The app worked just fine when I asked for a score of a football game

replies.text: I said OK Moto Z, send a text to ***** and it correctly brought up Google to send the message.

You might have received the newest update to the Google app. It wasn't working for me for a few weeks and then I signed up to be a Google App Beta tester and last week they pushed a new update and it resolved the issues.

thread.text:
It's an issue within the Google app, ever since they integrated Assistant into the Google Now functionality. Moto Voice just listens for your custom launch phrase and then passes off most commands to the Google App. 
There is a Beta version of the Google app that resolves the issue, so hopefully everyone gets it soon via the Play Store.
You can check out the official Google Support discussion here:https://support.google.com/websearch...nkK2Sgs/?hl=en

title: Moto Z Force uses HSPDA even when LTE is available

thread.text:
My z force will always default to h+ instead of lte, if I force it with an app like radio switcher it will get lte. I carry an att phone for work and always have lte on it. Rarely on my z. I cannot view or add APNs. My wife's phone does not do this and it is a Moto z but not force ( both model xt1650). I called cricket support and she said my phone is not compatible with cricket. Lol since it calls, texts, and surfs internet fine. Just can't get it to primarily choose lte. 
Radio switcher will let me force lte but that has it's issues as well. This behaviour is when I set it to global(prl).

replies.text:
Welcome. 
I’ve moved your thread to the Z Force forum for comments from other users.

thread.text:
The Moto Z Force was designed specifically and has settings that are tuned to work on Verizon Wireless only - it is/was a Verizon Wireless proprietary phone. Using it on any other carrier is just luck. You may just have to live with it that way.
You can try changing the setting from Global but nobody can guarantee that this will work.

It's very strange, I'd like to know the criteria it uses to select lte. Sometimes it's fine others it's irritating. If I put it on lte/umts/gsm from global it behaves the same way. If I use the radio switcher app and force it lte only it does stay on lte but then I can't make calls. I figured I'd just have to deal with it but I was hoping there's a butter solution. Since verizons required to have their lte phones unlocked I didn't think these things should be an issue.

Unlocked just means that the SIM card slot isn't locked to a Verizon SIM. It doesn't mean that the phone will have the proper software to make phone calls over LTE, have the same bands that another carrier uses for LTE, etc.

Having never tried the Galaxy VR goggles at the Verizon Store I decided to order a Daydream View and see what it was all about. I was surprised at how well it works and how real the simulation was.
The Z Force presents a reasonably sharp image and for sure you can get a bit of motion sickness when you first try it out if you run a race car or roller coaster app.
There isn't much content but there are a few good ones to play with though apps like Netflix VR do not give you a good viewing experience as compared to watching the movies in normal mode.
For me, it was worth the price of the goggles (on Amazon about $71) just to get the experience.

To me, the best thing about DayDream is making photospheres of places I love and being able to "visit" them in VR later on. Some of the games & apps are clever, but some are gimmicky and not really worthwhile. Still, neat tech, and as content develops it should get even better.

A couple weeks ago it was time to blow out our home sprinkler system before winter. Had to open a few valves manually in an in-ground box, which I opened to find that I have a leak, because the box was full of water.
I tend to carry my Z Force in my shirt pocket. I leaned over to mess with the valves, and it slipped right out and dunked straight into the water. I immediately pulled it out, of course, but it went under, and then floated (Not sure if that was the phone, or the Tumi battery pack, or both providing buoyancy). I grabbed it, and it was only in the water 3 seconds, tops, but it was full immersion. I pulled the mod & bumper case off and put them inside, but didn't wipe them down until after we finished the blow-out.
I've had zero issues with it. Great phone.

I had that happen with a Z Play and the "pool my wife had to have". I just had a cheap gel case on and it sank 2 foot. Took it out, dryed it off and sat it on top of dehumidifier for about 12 hours. 
I made sure to not power it up. After the 12 hours it works just fine.

title: Moto z force suddenly has charging problems. turbo charger failed 1st week

thread.text:
Moto z force suddenly has charging problems. 
-turbo charger failed 1st week - threw it away
-put adapters on my USB mini cables and charged fine
-bought USB-C cables and they (all 4) worked great until today
-now none of the new USB-C cables charge the phone
-Switched 3 different brands of charger - no change
-Followed stupid Moto/Lenovo suggestion to reboot the phone - no change
-phone DOES charge with old mini-USB plus a cheap mini/C converter
WHY?? Any Moto engineers out there with real suggestions (as opposed to Lenovo support)? Anyone else seeing this? I'm furious for an almost $700 phone to have these problems so soon after purchase.
Any reason you don't want to return the phone?

title: I'm not geting a message notification above my messaging icon when a new text comes in.

thread.text: I have a Motorola Android 7.1.1 and I used to get a number above my text icon every time a new message came in. I no longer get that and I have tried going into settings, notifications, and app manager and haven't found anything that turns it on or off. Any advice?
Welcome to the forums. Which Moto model do you have and which launcher are you using? Those notification badges are only available on some Verizon/Droid models unless you use a custom launcher.
I have Motorola Moto Z Force Droid and am using Message+. I read some comments about Message+ not working well. Maybe I should use Message instead.
Thanks for registering. I moved your thread to the Z Force forum for better visibility.
Same here, Message+ stopped showing notifications but not because of 7.1.1 because it used to work with 7.1.1 when I first got the update...stopped sometime after that....perhaps a Message+ update?
All latest updates installed including system update yesterday. Not sure when it first stopped showing notifications. I didn't notice until a few days ago.
So I'm using Action Launcher and somehow the message updates got turned off. Went into Action Launcher settings, turned it on, and all is well again. Check your launcher's settings.

Starting with the 7.1.1 update, the Bluetooth will no longer consistently connect. I'll turn on the Bluetooth device and then turn on Bluetooth on the phone. The connection between the phone and the device won't work. I'm having to restart the phone to get the connection issue resolved. I've contacted Verizon about this, but I'm sure they'll say they haven't heard of this before and will suggest I do a factory reset.

I have seen quite a few similar complaints on the Moto Forum, with no real explanation or resolution. I have not had any Bluetooth issues my mynZ Force; even through all of the System and OS updates we have received.
Personally, I would back up my data, do a Factory Reset and then not install any apps. None. And not let anything update from the Play Store. Then try to connect one Bluetooth device and see if it works. If not, then ask for a warranty replacement knowing that it doesn't work on a clean phone with no Play Store apps. Just my suggestion.

Unfortunately as far as a warranty replacement, I don't have that option since I purchased the phone last July. I did get in contact with Verizon and I guess I had assumed what their response would be when I posted this. They suggested trying to connect the Bluetooth on another device and see if the same issue occurs. I guess by doing that, it will determine if there's an issue with the phone or if it's the Bluetooth device.

title: Does my Moto Z Force suport MAP?

thread.text: I'm, getting a new Jeep with a Uconnect 8.4 NAV. The Uconnect offers Android users the ability to send and receive SMS messages, if their phones support the MAP protocol. I searched, but can't find whether my Motorola Moto Z Force, Android 7.1.1, is compatible. Can anyone provide some guidance? I don't have the vehicle yet, so I can't just test it myself. Thanks.
I can't say for certain about the X Force, but my wife's Z Play sends messages via her Jeep Cherokee UConnect 8.4; so I don't see why the Z Force wouldn't be supported.

Thanks very much, Scott. I ordered an '18 Grand Cherokee, which will have the 8.4, so I'll find out soon enough. From what I understand, the ability to initiate normal SMS messages requires an add-on feature called Uconnect Access. I think that I get a one-year trial, and then it costs something to subscribe. If you don't have Access, all you can do is answer incoming SMS with one of about 20 canned replies.
My Z Force works great in my Ram with Uconnect.

replies.text: Thanks. Is yours the 8.4? I have a 730n in my JK, but SMS only works sporadically and only lets me reply when it works at all. I'm hopeful that I can use SMS normally when I get my Grand Cherokee.
It's 8.4 but I also subscribe to Uconnect which I guess works different than no subscribing and using Moto or Google assistant.

thread.text: The only problem we have found is that the newest U Connect and the Moto App - Driving Mode both prompt for a new text and then both ask if we would like to reply. She stopped using the Moto App driving mode while in her Cherokee and uses the U Connect prompt to send replies

replies.text: Yeah, it's the Moto app that I use now with the 730n in the JK. Driving mode is on and announces a new SMS, but not always through the bluetooth system. It sometimes just uses the phone, which is in my pocket. I may be able to reply. I cannot initiate an SMS, and Uconnect said that SMS is not supported in the 730n. I'll have to see whether it's worth $150/year to use SMS in my new Jeep after the 1-year trial ends.

I have no issues with Driving Mode on my Z Force, using a Bluetooth kit that plug into the Aux port in my Wrangler. It always works. The new text message via hands free is a recent issue with an update to the Google App.
I was not aware of a fee to continue using certain U Connect features, may have to look into that and re-read all of the U Connect documents and e-mail. I certainly don't plan on paying an annual fee just for SMS support.

Uconnect 8.4, itself, does not require a fee for full SMS, but allows only a handful of canned replies. The add-on feature, named Uconect Access, allows full SMS and costs $150 a year, though you may be able to pay monthly. Access also offers other premium features that are included in the $150.
Thanks for the update.

title: How do I use "quick decline messages" when my phone is awake?

thread.text:
I have the Moto Z Force. I just setup/customized the quick decline messages (i.e. Cant talk right now, etc). And they work fine IF my phone is asleep. In other words, when the incoming call screen is in full screen mode. I swipe up on the caller icon, boom. Great.
BUT, if my phone is awake (like if Im doing something on my phone, anything) the incoming call display is smaller (at the top of the screen) and only gives me 2 options (ignore or accept). No matter how i swipe, I dont get the option to use the quick responses. Anyone know how to do it? I mean, when I'm ON my phone....that's when I need the quick decline options the MOST.

I have power beats Bluetooth headphones and have them paired to the phone. I'm listening to iHeartRadio when all the sudden, the audio just stops.
I'm using mobile data and the signal seems fine. The phone is right next to me so it's not an issue of being too far away. I'd contact Verizon about this, but I don't think they'll be of much help.
does the speaker do this with all phones?

The audio just stopped again with iHeartRadio. I've only got the one phone so I don't have a way to test this.
I don't know if this is an issue with iHeartRadio, the headphones, or the phone. The headphones were just charged last night so that's not the issue.

Has this happened to anyone else? I've tried 3 different USB OTG cables or adapters with different memory media, and the phone connects to the media just fine, I can even browse the connected media for a few seconds, but within 10 seconds to a minute the phone just stops sending power to the OTG connected media and no longer interacts with the media. I've tried rebooting my phone and disabling Tasker. Nothing seems to get it sustain a connection for more than about 45-50 seconds.
I'm on 7.1.1, not sure if that has anything to do with it or not.

thread.text: It's my understanding that the shatter shield comes off but then your glass will shatter easier. So it also scratches easier. If I take it off, will it be less likely to scratch? I haven't had a scratch on my screen in years and got one today on this phone. Never used screen protectors. I'm not a phone dropper. Just liked the specks on this phone, but not digging how easy it scratches.

replies.text:
The screens on these phones will not shatter, because there's no glass. It's not just that the top layer is a hard plastic screen protector, but the layers under that don't use glass either. The screen can be damaged, but not by shattering.
Don't use it without the top shattershield lens on it. If you do, you risk scratching a layer that's not made to be replaced, and the layer under the shattershield might be just as, or even more prone to scratches as the top layer.
My suggestion would be to just keep using it and put up with the scratch until they have the replacement shattershields available. Then, replace the shattershield and put a protector on top of the new one. A number of people have put tempered glass protectors on, including some ~$10 ones from Amazon. So you can find one of those with good reviews, and then if it gets a scratch, it's a $10 replacement instead of a ~$30 shattershield replacement.
Ironically enough, using a tempered glass protector actually adds the chance of shattering, but of course only the protector that's cheap & easy to replace.

I'm wondering what everyone's battery life is like how that they've had the phone for awhile and it's had two major updates. Mine is horrific. It's definitely not a rogue app or something syncing in the background because it happens when I'm using the phone doing non-intensive tasks. For example, just browsing forums, Reddit, and social media at 50% auto brightness, I'll drop 15-20% per hour. If I take the phone directly off the charger and use it non-stop, I should be able to get more than 5-6 hours of non-intensive use, right? This might be acceptable for the Z2 Force and it's 2700 mAh battery, but not for the original Z Force and a 3500 mAh battery.

My Z Force is still getting really good battery life. Not as good as when it was new....but after numerous System Version updates and 2 Android OS updates I still have not performed a Factory Reset (FDR). I'm sure that if I did a FDR without auto-backup enabled I would get even better battery life.
Sometimes after numerous version updates and Android OS updates it's just time to backup all personal files, pics and music and do a FDR and start the phone fresh and clean. Like a good "Spring Cleaning" for a phone.
I am not a super heavy user, I would say average. I charge my phone all night while I sleep. I start each day with a full charge and then use my phone for a lot of email, texting, a few calls per day, maybe a few You Tube videos, lots of Forum usage, some web browsing, and some shopping (Amazon, E Bay, etc). I end up with about 3 - 4 hours of SOT and around 20 - 30% battery remaining after 16 or so hours off the charger. Some days are heavier usage and I may need to plug in for a quick turbo charge, or use a Battery Mod but not too often.
My Moto z force (Droid) is a day one release pre ordered it through Verizon. Battery life is about the same as it was new. I can go 24 hours on a charge and I'm kind of a heavy user.

title: small folder thumbnails and no blue light in 7.1.1

thread.text:
I got moto force Verizon updated to 7.1.1.
But i can't find any blue light options under display settings? Anyone knows why?
Also now all folders have really very tiny icons, and they are really hard to see, any way to make them bigger like they were in 7.0?
Which Moto phone? It'll probably be more helpful to move this thread to that phone's subforum, rather than stay in the general Nougat forum (since your question is device-specific).
as i did moto z force. but it's os related

It's actually not OS related -- the OS is Android, and Android doesn't have a native blue light filter feature. That's added by the manufacturer, so it's more of a device-specific (or manufacturer-specific) issue. That's why I think this would get better traffic in the Z Force forum.
If the phone used to have a blue light filter, and now it's gone, then it's possible Lenovo (or Verizon) removed the feature for some reason -- you'd have to ask them why. You could always look for a 3rd party blue light filter in the Play Store.
Regarding the folders with tiny icons -- do you mean that for folders on the homescreen, you'd like more options for how the app icons are displayed on that folder icon (like grid, fan, stack, etc.)? This would be dependent on the launcher you're using -- if Lenovo doesn't give you an option to customize that appearance, then consider installing a 3rd party launcher like Nova.

The only mod I have (aside from a couple style backs) is the first gen speaker, and I rarely use it. The Z Force is a very good phone without any mods, so there's no reason to buy them unless you want to, and no reason you'd get "locked in" to one phone line.
Tempered glass screen protectors are abundant and cheap, so the screen scratching isn't really an issue either, unless you just absolutely hate having a protector.
I too was burned by the lack of follow-through on promised updates (Droid MAXX), but so far Lenovo is doing pretty well with updates to the Z's. It's June, and we're on the May security patch. The June patch only just rolled out to Nexus/Pixel last week, so we're only just barely behind the bleeding edge on security updates. We're on Android 7.0, so not the absolute latest, but pretty good. So far I'm pleased with the updates, though we'll see how Lenovo does in the 12-24 month age span where support tends to drop off from most manufacturers.

title: Moto X Pure vs.Moto Z Force Native App and Camera NX

thread.text:
I wanted to show a comparison between the MotoX Pure using HDR, the Moto Z Force using the native app with HDR auto and HDR on, compared to Force using the NX camera app HDR auto and HDR+.
It's meant to be a torture test of sorts. The focus point is always the dog's head but then with three light sources, two windows and a lamp. Naturally the Moto X Pure struggles although HDR helps. The Force struggles with both apps on HDR auto. But what really makes the biggest difference is the HDR+ mode. It is able to avoid blowing out the bright light sources while still allowing the dog's head to be seen.
Here is the link. https://photos.google.com/share/AF1Q...RmR00yU3lLOUdn

1. I don't think that this is a good test. I'd delete a photo like this if I took it. It seems uninteresting to me.
2. I like the first one most. Of the last two, I like the middle one more than the last one. My eye is not drawn to the back of the dog's head, but to the items along the back wall and the furniture. And the first photo I think captures that best. The lamp is overexposed and harsh in the last two photos, especially the last, as is the light in the window.
I have no idea which photo is which (X Pure, Z Force stock, and HDR+).
Top photo above is the camera NX HDR+ . The middle is the Z Force app HDR on and bottom is HDR auto. I've also labeled all the photos in the album I posted.

Middle photo is the best one, IMO. 
The best photo in the photo album is row 7, last photo in the row. I believe this photo is the same one as the middle photo above.
The top photo suffers from damping down the light too much--it's just not that dark in the room. It is a sunny day outside and there is sunlight coming in from the window next to the dog's head. Surely the lamp throws off more light. But you wouldn't know that by the top photo. Also, take a look at the area under the window in the top photo--plenty of noise in those dark areas. The front of the chair's seat cushion is a matrix of pixels. Look at the rug in the area in front of the chair and under the window--a smudgy, smear of pixels. Yuck. (Best seen on the photo in row 5, shot #1 on photo grid page.)

Thanks for the feedback. Of course I do have the advantage of being in the room taking the photos. The NX app was decompiled from the Google pixel app. I think you'll see a significant difference how the windows are handled. The pixel camera app does run a little darker at times. As for the lamp, I would say the light would be between the top and middle. I found it interesting. For outdoor photos most of the time the Force native app on HDR auto gives the most consistently good photos.

title: Phone pauses song with headphones? What to do?

thread.text:
I currently use the Z Force and the 3.5mm to USB-C adapter it came with.
When I play a song on Spotify or any other app, it randomly pauses and I have to hit play again. Sometimes the audio crackles, and it seems to get confused. 
It only happens when I use headphones, not Bluetooth.
Any suggestions? I tried doing a factory reset too

Sounds like you have lint in your USB port. Use a toothpick and try to remove any lint or other debris that might be lodged in the USB port. If you have a can of compressed air you might try that as well.
Welcome to Android Central! If that doesn't work, it's also possible that the headphone plug isn't entirely compatible with the jack in the adapter. Have you tried other headphones?

I used a can of compressed air to clean it out and also tried different headsets.
It still seems to stutter.
Is it possible to solder in a new USB-C port? I got this phone less than a year back, I think I could probably exchange it for another refurbished one...
It's just annoying how it all depends on one port for both charging and headphones.

replies.text:
I had this problem with my Droid Turbo a couple of times and it was always lint in the headphone port. Try a wooden toothpick and gently probe around in there. BE CAREFUL you don't damage the connector(s). 
In order to get a fine point on the toothpick with which to dig out the lint, I've snapped several toothpicks in half until I got a shard with a very sharp point on it.
Another useful tool for this purpose are those dental floss picks with the curved plastic toothpick on the end.

thread.text:
I'd think it could be a problem with the headphone adapter rather than the USB port. It could be that the wire between each end is failing and the signal is intermittently failing, making the phone think that you have unplugged the headphones.
Maybe see if you can find another adapter? Amazon sells a few for less than $10, most of which have 4 star reviews.

You should be able to isolate the problem by having the headphones on and gently wiggling the suspected component connections. That is, while listening to music with the headphones grasp and hold the type C USB connector steady where it enters the phone housing with one hand then wiggle the type C to 3.5mm adapter connection. The idea is to try to recreate the stuttering problem. Then try holding the type C to 3.5mm connection steady and gently wiggle type C to phone connection.

title: How do I stop particular Google notifications?

thread.text: I'm not sure why, but I receive daily weather updates from Google on the bar that's at the top of my Moto Z Force (what do yo call that bar?). How do I stop these? I don't necessarily want to block other Google notifications. Thanks.

thread.text: Are you referring to the Notification panel, or the Google Now search bar that comes preloaded in the top of the Home screen? thread.text:
I’ve had the Moto Z Force for a little over ten months so I wanted to share my experience during that time. 
Previous Phone Moto X Pure: I enjoyed the MXPE a lot, but battery life significantly declined in a year. Right now it’s averaging 13.5 hours on, 3.5 hours screen on time and that is without a SIM card or cell service. It has a very nice, accurate screen. It’s a very comfortable phone with an excellent form factor as well as front firing speakers. I think the 808 chip does have issues. The phone heats up at times, particularly when turbocharged, which I no longer use. Performance is good, but I never pushed it very hard. Camera is good, although significantly weaker than the Z Force. After the initial Marshmallow update that was very quick, security updates have been few and far between and the phone still has not been updated to Nougat. 
Form Factor: It’s certainly not svelte or sleek like an LG G6 or the Samsung S8 or S8+. It would be nice if the bottom bezel were a little smaller. Yet, I only use a bumper case and tempered glass screen protector because this phone is more durable than most because of its metal construction and Shattershield. In fact, I don’t have insurance on the phone and that saves me several dollars a month.
Screen: It may not quite reach the depths of vibrancy found on Samsung phones, but overall the screen is quite enjoyable, particularly blacks. It can get bright enough as well in full sunlight. The Shattershield is much improved over the Droid Turbo 2 as far as screen quality and brightness. 
Performance: The phone continues to be very fast and very responsive. Occasionally I do a full cache wipe, but I have yet to do or felt the need to do a full factory reset, even after major system updates. The phone generally does not heat up. I do not play games. Taking photos does heat the phone up. The phone generally does well holding cell and wifi signals. Calls are clear. I don’t listen to music much using headphones so no thoughts there. I enjoy the fingerprint sensor a lot. It is quick and generally quite accurate. 
Battery: Battery life has declined somewhat over time. At one point according to GSAM battery monitor I was averaging 25 hours on, with 6 hours screen on time. I know many have done better than that. But I live in a small town and generally try to keep the phone on 3G. Over time, battery life has decreased to 24 hours on, and 5.5 hours screen on time. I charge the phone when it gets below 40% when possible and not above 80%. I think that has helped somewhat. I sometimes use Pixoff battery app that helps with screen on time. I also use Greenify. Taking photos kills the battery quickly as it does with most phones. 
Camera: I have only used the front camera a few times, so I don’t have an opinion there. The rear camera takes excellent photos overall. I sometimes have trouble with motion shots, but realize I could use the professional mode. Hopefully a two camera setup may improve that in the the 2017 version. Low light photos can be hit or miss. HDR can add a lot to the quality of photos. XDA developers have ported the Pixel camera app to use on the Force and it can improve indoor and low light shots. 
Moto Mods: I have several style shells. I enjoy the novelty of them, but they’re not life-changing. I have the first generation JBL speaker and use it occasionally. It’s a lot of fun. I have the Hasselblad camera mod. When using it for zoom, it definitely is a significant improvement. Otherwise, the Force camera takes better photos, which is a disappointment. What is really unfortunate is that I think the Hasselblad mod should take better photos than it does with better processing. I have the Mophie battery pack. It’s somewhat bulky and could be grippier, but otherwise works well. 
Updates: The phone was updated to Nougat very quickly. Security updates have been consistent and timely. It will be interesting to see when the phone is updated to O (Oreo) and if that will be the last major update, which I assume it will be. 
Comparisons with other phones: I haven’t had any of the other 2016 or 2017 phones to compare with the Z Force. Yet, I probably would be happier with this phone over the Pixel and Samsung S7 edge. 
Bottom Line: I’ve been very happy with the Z Force. Hopefully I will keep it for a second year before upgrading in 2018 with likely another Z Force if it meets my needs and preferences.

As a side note; I have been letting my 5 year old use the Moto Z Force as a mini tablet (unbreakable? screen FTW!). It doesn't have a SIM in it, but she's getting 9+ hours of SOT watching YouTube and Netflix.
I should have also mentioned that my wife has a Z Play. I haven't used it much, but the screen is fine. The camera isn't as good as the Force, but the battery life as we all know is outstanding.

title: What Car Charger and Cable Do I Need for Turbo Charging Z Force in my Car?

thread.text:
I can't seem to get a consensus from reading through the previous topics in this forum so I am gonna ask straight up.
What Car Charger and Cable Do I Need for Turbo Charging in my Car?
Now, maybe I have missed the answer so please forgive me if I have.
i got the usb c fast charger from verizon and it works. used it today in my Jeep and the "Turbo Charging" notification popped up
Ouch. $40 a piece. I got 4 cars.

For me I like getting a 150 watt inverter off Amazon and then just buy an aukey dual USB quick charger. The inverter will be about $20 and the charger about $15 and now your car has AC for laptops etc, and you always have an AC phone quick charger where ever you travel.
To me it's better value than the expensive DC quick chargers

This one does pop up the turbo charging toast notification, and will also charge the battery mod. Haven't checked the output on it, but seems slightly slower than the included AC Turbo Charger.
USB Type C Car charger, Nekteck 5.4A USB-C Car Charger Adapter with Integrated Built-in Type-C 3.1 Cord for Macbook 12 Inch, Google Pixel/ Pixel XL Nexus 5X 6P and More, Black - Straight Cable https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0172QQNBY...cUvbUpU5560664
^That's the one I have. Does the job.

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0...cUvbUpU5561494 Vehicle chargerhttps://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0...cUvbUpU5561494 Usb micro to Usb C connector
This is the charger I use mostly. I also have several vehicles that needed to be set up and this was fairly cheap. I know there are several chargers that will charge even faster, but I had bought this one to use with a Turbo. This allowed me to use any of the SEVERAL micro usb cables around. Yes I know the turbo charging message doesnt pop up, but it charges very fast and keeps it charged while using maps/gps and even streaming music at the same time. 
I do have a couple usb c chargers and the one verizon sells also. Just havent really needed them as this setup works well.

I bought this adapter for my Moto Droid Turbo 2, and it turbo charged that VERY WELL. I tried it with my new Z Force, both with a USB-C cable and with a USB-C adapter for the micro USB cable I used to turbo charge my Droid, and neither Turbo charged. Just a warning.https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0...cUvbUpU5750371

replies.text: The Z Force does not use the Qualcomm quick charging technology that the Turbo and Turbos 2 used. It uses a USB C charging technology instead.

TurboPower charging on Motorola micro USB phones is Qualcomm Quick Charge.
TurboPower charging on Motorola USB Type-C phones needs minimum 15W (3A/5V) charging.

If the SD Card is formatted as Internal Adoptive Storage the yes you can move apps to the SD Card if the app is developed to allow that. Internal Adoptive Storage does have draw backs though, you can't use that SD Card in any other phone, laptop, tablet, etc. Once it's formatted as Adoptive Internal Storage it can only ever be used in that phone.
