title: Kyocera DuraForce Pro on Verizon vs Moto Z Force?

thread.text:
I used to have a Kyocera ruggedized phone. Loved the crap outta it. Have been running a Moto Turbo for a while now. Getting close to time to replace it.
Anyone know anyone or have experience with the the Kyocera DFPro and can compare it to the Z Force? I like the idea of the Z Force Shatterscreen, but the Kyocera's sapphire screen is pretty compelling. I also get that it can be damaged from side impacts.
Anyone know how the battery life compares against the two? 
Lastly, I'm curious about software updates. Moto is notoriously slow, but Kyocera is almost as bad. Anyone know if the refresh cycles will improve? 
Thanks in advance.
FWIW, Moto has been pretty good about pushing out security updates. I would also assume that Moto will have a more active developer community/community support than the Kyocera.

replies.text: Agreed...not only did we get Android 7.0 pretty quickly, but also regular security updates...I've been impressed.

thread.text: My nephew just got the duraforce pro and I liked its physical buttons. Neat phone that he likes a lot. I like the options of the Moto better. But the duraforce is a neat phone.

I think the days of bad updates from Moto are over. I have been pleasantly surprised on all the updated for my Z Force. 
As for the DuraForce, it looks like a good phone, if I were in the market now it would be on my list. BUT I love Moto display and would find it hard to move to another device.

replies.text: Wait til the next gen Z line comes with out. These updates may slow down.

thread.text: The Verizon Z phones are on Android 7.0 and I believe the latest (maybe next from latest) security update. They're doing VERY well at keeping them updated so far. (Though I won't hold my breath that they'll keep that up after the next Z's come out, as Ry said.) I'm very happy with my Z Force.

I had the Moto Z and now the Kyocera Duraforce pro. Both are excellent devices but serve different needs. 
The Moto Z was fantastic for me. The camera was pretty good. It was super fast. Build was nice. I believe that Moto will provide updates pretty quick also. 
The Kyocera is my current favorite device though however. It is built like a tank and that is what I think I enjoy the most. I do use a case. The sapphire screen is nice to have. Wireless charging built in and SD card slot. I also really like the physical buttons. For me having physical buttons and a dedicated camera button is awesome. I also like being able to use gloves with my phone since I have to use gloves for work. 
However the Moto Z is faster than the Kyocera and the camera is also better. I have not had lag on my Kyocera but I did notice the Moto is faster. And being able to use the mods are nice also. 
In the end you just have to decide what you are looking for in a device. Both are good choices.

I've been researching for a new tough outdoor phone myself and coming across this thread I started comparing the Duraforce pro and the Z force and this is is what I've found so far. Overall the Z force is the better phone spec wise but I can not find that it is IP certified or MIL-STD-810 certified which is important to me because if I drop the phone in a mud puddle or stream, I want it to continue working. I've read some reviews that the Duraforce screen will work while wet which some screens won't and it is suppose to be able to be submerged for up to 30 minutes in 3' of water and it even has the ability to take pictures underwater. The Z force doesn't have a earphone jack so you have to get an adapter to use headphones of other accessories that plug into the jack. I really like the idea of the Moto mods, especially the projector, it would be nice to be able to hang up a sheet and watch a movie while camping but again I worry about how tough or durable this setup would be, what happens if I drop the phone on a rock. For the price of the mod, I could buy a separate mini projector that I'd keep protected until use. The drawback for me on both phones is a removable battery. I have a Casio commando (which is discontinued, too bad) that I really like but it's outdated, slow, and the screen is small but it could take a beating and with it I always carried a spare battery so if I were away for a few days or something like getting lost or an accident happened I had phone power( I know I could carry a power pack of some kind but a spare battery was more convenient for me). There are other tough phones out there with all the stuff I want but unfortunately I'm kind of stuck with Verizon because of a family plan and where I go the coverage sucks for other carriers. 
One other thing that has kept me from buying a new phone yet is the ability to root the phone. I haven't done enough research on rooting the Moto Z force yet but with the Duraforce pro since it is fairly new and not a real mainstream phone I can't find any thing on a reliable way to root the phone. Can't really comment much about updates but Moto being a more popular phone brand would probably get them faster.
So in short the Z is a better spec phone but the Duraforce pro is a tougher phone so it depends on which you want.

replies.text: To me this is a non-issue since you can use the battery mods exactly like a removable battery would work. Plus you can swap them without rebooting!

thread.text:
Moto Z Force Droid hasn't been advertised with any official water or dust resistance ratings. 
If you need actual rugged, go Kyocera.

My farmer husband recently replaced his Kyocera Brigadier with the Verizon Kyocera DuraForce Pro and is really happy with it. I set it up for him (I have a Samsung Galaxy S7edge) and I am really impressed with the DuraForce Pro (especially since it's almost half the price I paid for mine last year). 
For him the dust and water resistance is huge as is the ability to use gloves. The big battery and the economy battery setting ensures that when out in the mountains snowmobiling we don't run out of battery. The wide angle camera is a great feature too. The phone is really impressive. 
He had the Brigadier for over 2.5 years and without a case a screen protector the Sapphire Glass never got scratched or cracked and the phone survived being carried around and falling out of his shirt pocket more times than I can remember. Hopefully the DuraForce Pro is as durable!!

title: All I can Say is WOW!!

thread.text: I have been using my Moto Z Force for the last week. I fully charged it Thursday night and pulled it off the charger Friday morning. Using it as I normally did with my Moto X, on Sunday afternoon it still had 78% battery life left. I was blown away. I also adjusted the camera fro full 21MP photos. I took many photos at the Philly auto show and they came out incredible. I think the camera takes better pictures tan my Wife's I-phone 6S. My Moto X would have been dead by Friday afternoon. At first the speed was only a little better than my Moto X. I was cruising through the phone and saw DT Ignite. I remember reading an article about it and that is was just bloatware last year. Once I disabled DT Ignite, it was like night and day. The Moto Z came to life and ran faster than the Roadrunner wearing a jet pack. I am so happy with the Moto Z and looking forward to many good years with it.

replies.text: My last few phones were the Lumia ICON, Note 5, Note 7, Pixel and now the Moto Z Force Droid. It is the most balanced phone (sans a stylus) that I've owned. The camera, while slow at times, is fantastic and highly underrated.
I agree.

thread.text: Great
Welcome to the happy Z Force club! 😀

Friday to Sunday and you only lost 22%? I'm sorry but I call BS. I have the Force and I like it, but I get to 78% after 5 to 7 hours or so. This is with it very little usage and less than 1 hour screen time.
Perhaps you turn your phone off rather often or do not have multiple sync services?

replies.text: Maybe he's using a battery mod
Even with the battery mod, that is too good. Nevertheless, enjoy your phone. I am still happy with it, but realistically it lasts one day.

I use battery mod with my z force. Wake up at 6am and by midnight I'm in single digits on the phone and battery mod at 0%. I am on T-Mobile with it so a good chunk of the power goes to signal acquisition, on average I have about 6-7 hours of screen time. I don't have to recharge through out the day though as I did with previous phones so that's a significant improvement.
By the way, the camera on this phone sucks like on all other moto phones in past 7 years. Ever try to take a macro shot closer then a foot away? Don't compare it with iPhone as their cameras are sub par also, compare it to top of the line cameras from Sony, LG and Samsung.

While I agree that Moto cameras in the past were horrible because I had 5 of their early Droids, I had thought they got better. I can't say for sure because i left Moto after they abandoned some us that were promised updates.
I'm perhaps less than 3 inches away from this...can even make out the dust on my desk...LOL
Just have to say, despite the speed, the Camera on the Moto Z Force is among the best...

thread.text: Underrated. But it's niche since it's exclusive to Verizon.

title: Screen will not sleep in accordance with settings

thread.text:
A few weeks ago I changed the screen setting from sleeping after "1 min", to "never", because I was using an app to read and write and it kept shutting off if I didn't touch the screen after 1 min. I changed it back to 1 min a week ago or so, and it will no longer shut off after 1 minute has elapsed.
I have not downloaded any new apps and have cleared the cache multiple times.
I'll try to clear the catch partition tonight, but just curious if anyone has any insights?
Thank you!

replies.text: Yeah, I should've mentioned that I checked that already. That was actually the first place I looked, but I've had that off since day 1.

thread.text: You can try in the Moto app there is a setting that will keep it on if it sees you are still looking at the screen.

replies.text: Yeah, I should've mentioned that I checked that already. That was actually the first place I looked, but I've had that off since day 1.

thread.text: There are plenty of third party apps, stay alive is a good one, that will keep screen on for selected apps. https://play.google.com/store/apps/d...ics.stay.alive
Do you have developer options active. I believe there's a setting in there that prevents it from sleeping but only while charging.

replies.text: Checked this too, it's not turned on. I do have developer settings accessed, but haven't played around with this particular setting.

thread.text:
That's a strange glitch.
If restarting the phone or clearing the cache partition doesn't work, what happens if you change the setting to something else (say, 30 seconds) temporarily, and then change back to a minute?

replies.text: Toggling between 30 and 60 seconds makes no difference. The screen just stays on regardless. Sometimes it shuts off correctly, but most times, it will dim like it's about to go off (after about 60 sec.), and then instead of turning off, it pops back onto full brightness. At this point it will just stay on full brightness and won't even dim again after 60 seconds go by. Really strange! It's not the end of the world by any means, but the OCD in me hates not being able to control or understand what's going on.

thread.text: I have Moto Voice activated on my Moto Z Force. However, my uConnect system does not work with SMS (voice calls work fine with uConnect). So, while my phone may announce a new SMS and offer the options to listen and reply, I can't use that feature when the phone's in my pocket. So, I wonder whether a bluetooth headset will work? If it will, and if the announcement comes through on the headset speaker and I can reply on the headset mic, I'll be good to go. I don't envision wearing the headset, but think that I can hear it if I leave it on the dash. I activated the option to "Announce incoming calls and texts while a headset is connected." Is my thinking accurate? If so, what are some headset make/models that should work? Thanks.

I use bluetooth earbuds and the Moto voice worked fine with text messages, hearing me say "no" if I want to reply and "yes" to hear. I switched to a different app that reads texts automatically, without asking. But Moto voice does do what you are seeking. I use Trelab cheapies. I don't know why anything that has a mic wouldn't work.
Thanks. Do you know whether anyone makes a hands-free unit on which I can turn off voice phone calls and use it only with SMS? My phone works fine for in/out voice with my uConnect.

That's above my pay grade. I don't know what uConnect is or how to do what you are asking. I use eCid app in the Playstore and it allows you to select if you want SMS and/or phone calls read out loud. Problem is I can't get it to recognize my voice commands, but it is OK since all I want is texts read out loud when I am driving with my earbuds in.
Management application connection bluetooth headset on Google Play "Bluetooth Audio Widget free"

Will the Moto Z Force work if I switch to T-Mobile? 
in my area they have good coverage, and I could save about a $100 a month

replies.text: Is it the Verizon version of the phone?
I thought that the z force was a Verizon exclusive?

It will almost surely work. You may not get LTE everywhere. 
But, there is a good way to check - get a T-Mo prepaid SIM and see if it works where you live/work/travel. Just cancel the service when you're done testing and then get a regular postpaid account (or stay with Verizon.)

thread.text:
Z Force Bands
CDMA (850, 1900 MHz)
GSM / GPRS / EDGE (850, 900, 1800, 1900 MHz)
UMTS / HSPA+ (850, 900, 1900, 2100 MHz)
4G LTE (B2, 3, 4, 5, 7, 13)
T-Mobile's Bands
LTE - Frequencies: Band 2 (1900 MHz), Band 4 (1700/2100 MHz), Band 12 (700 MHz)
4G HSPA+ Frequencies: Band 2 (1900 MHz), Band 4 (1700/2100 MHz)
3G HSPA Frequencies: Band 4 (1700/2100 MHz)
2G Edge Frequencies: Band 2 (1900 MHz)
so it looks like it might work, but be kind of gimped
WillMyPhoneWork.net - Check if your phone works on a network

replies.text:
thanks, that confirms it will work on 2G and some of 3G and LTE
might give that prepaid sim idea a shot

thread.text: I took a Verizon Moto Z Force to AT&T and it works perfectly and even receives updates. Not that would help someone deciding to take it to T-Mobile but it has worked 100% on AT&T.

This phone does not look like it has band 12. You will not get your best experience if you don't have a phone that has Band 12 enabled. This happens quite often with people and they end up blaming the carrier.

I just switched to T-Mobile yesterday with my moto z force. It works in most areas but not in all. Main deficiency is lack of band 12 which is long range lte. Driving in valleys between hills we get dead zones where you can't even make a phone call. Also building penetration is very bad without said band 12. I work in the hospital and as long as I am next to exterior wall I get 4g lte but soon as I pass a few walls and I have no reception at all. With Verizon I could be anywhere at I would have 4g reception, worst case it would switch to 3g.
I've ordered GSM version of moto z play and will see if my results will improve.

replies.text: That version supports Band 12, so you should see a marked improvement, and maybe you can sell your other to offset the cost.

title: Suggestions for a New Force Owner

thread.text:
Hey everyone, I have always been a huge fan of Motorola, have the original Moto X, and my wife also getting the 2nd gen. I have had a 2 year affair with a OnePlus One, and then dabbled in the nostalgia of a Blackberry PRIV, but the new unlimited plan for Verizon has brought us back to Big Red, upgraded my wife to the Force, and brought me back to Motorola as well. 
My question is, what tips, mods, cases, etc. do those of you who have had this for months offer? I purchased the Mophie Mod (man is it a brick), got the wife one of those Verizon Kate Spade cases for half off, Spigen glass screen protectors are on the way as well as an Incipio bumper for me. 
Has anyone found any skins that could attach to the Mophie Mod to keep it from being so slippery? Have those of you with battery mods find yourself keeping them attached all the time or only on need? replies.text:
I will second this...while looking at my phone it looks fine, but yesterday, in directly sunlight, I could see a ton of small micro scratches...doesn't affect it at all and I don't see them in normal conditions. But I did order some screen protectors for it arriving tomorrow. 
I think this is the most "complete" Phone out there that is as close to stock Android and with 7.0 that you can get. I think it is very underrated and doesn't get enough praise or coverage. 
A few notes:
I use adoptive storage and I've had ZERO issues with it. You need to make sure you are on a highly rated U3 card. It may still say your card is slow but I've had no issues at all. The 32GB base storage was just too little for me. You do need to remember to move apps with useful widgets to internal storage as widgets will not work on microSD cards.
The Camera is outstanding but often slow. It was rated just under the Pixel and while the Pixel is screaming fast, I found that the Pixel had way too many "halo" shots or white washed photos even with great sunlight. 
I use the JBL Mod and the Incipio Offgrid Power Pack Mod (as needed) in Efficiency mode. I also have 3 different "mods" for my normal back of the phone (stock, maroon and leather.)
I do not use any case (no bumper).

title: Verizon bumper damages phone paint (old design)

thread.text:
I have an early bumper, which I had to modify to work properly with the style backs. The other day I removed the bumper for some reason, and noticed that it has rubbed the paint off some small places on the sides. Frustrating, since I bought the bumper to protect the paint on the sides.
Anyone else noticed this?
I don't have this case, but man that sucks. I wonder if Verizon would give you a new phone since it was their case that caused the damage.

I doubt they would, and I'm not going to pursue it. It's fairly subtle, and if they replaced it, it would probably be with a refurb. I know my phone works perfectly, so I'd rather stick with the very minor disappointment I have then have to re-setup another phone with possibly some other issue.
Interestingly enough, it hasn't rubbed paint off on the top corner where I push to put the bumper on, or pull to take it off. The area pictured is the worst damage.
I'm still debating whether to stop using the bumper or not. I'm generally super kind to my devices, but it just takes one nasty drop to have a not-so-subtle gash in the paint/metal.
I also wonder if the other bumper has the same issue, but I don't want to have to remove the bumper to swap mods.
Just curious. Could you please post a pic of the actual bumper?

If you had to trim the bumper to install and remove the backs, it sounds like you have the old style. Call Verizon and see if they will send you a new style. I don't have my Z yet (should be here tomorrow) but when I ordered the bumper, I made sure it was the latest version cause I have read about this same problem with the older bumpers.

I second that.... I have the clear version of the bumper... No problems with any of the mods (I have speaker, camera, projector, mophie, car dock, style back). Only thing i've noticed is the clear one picks up some reflected light from the projector and 'glows' like halo around the phone  it doesnt affect the projected picture tho.
I just took mine off and looked, no paint damage visible on mine... I'd definitely at least see if they gave you an older version of the case and have them get you the current/correct version

title: Magnetic Type C cable plug for Moto Droid X

thread.text: I've become addicted to using cables with magnetic plugs for my Android and iOS devices, and I'm trying to find one for my Moto Droid X. These plugs save wear and tear on the power port and separate easily from the power cord. I've bought two Type C cables/plugs thus far and neither work with the Moto. Anyone out there trying to do the same thing? Anyone found a Type C came that actually works?

replies.text:
I know the usb-c is 'reversible', but try turning one of those around.... 
I have found one cable, when connected to a different device than the z force, will only charge if plugged in one way... The other way it transfers data but won't charge the device... 
Just a thought
Which cables? Been thinking about doing the magnetic plugs and cables.

thread.text:
My Nexus 10 has a magnetic power plug, where my Kids Nexus 7s do not. Guess which device has a working USB port and which 2 do not. 
My Pixel is my first USB C device so I'm hoping the port will be sturdier

I was thinking the ones mentioned that weren't charging, try those plugged in the other way... Have found two cables so far, one being a cable that was bought for the note7 from Verizon, that only will charge the moto mod project plugged in one way, other way it won't start charging, and one cable that came from bestbuy I think it was that will sync data to my z10 tablet both ways but only starts charging it if plugged in one way... 
Both devices will charge with another cable plugged in either way, so it is something in the cable/connector causing it... The magnetic adapter might have the same issue, and charge when it's plugged in one direction and not the other.... 
Just a theory....
I believe the connector is designed to work identically either way. I suspect contaminants in the connector. Sugary drinks are known to cause this, as is lint.

replies.text:
True, they are SUPPOSED to work either way. But the one cable I have that doesn't was that way right out of the package on a brand new device that does work either way on two other cables... So do not think it is lint or any debris in the connector... But a wiring issue in the cable plug... 
That why I was saying it COULD be something similar with these plugs if they don't have qc checks for it....

thread.text: The other issue is manufacturers that didn't adhere completely to the USB-C spec. There are cables/accessories that work with the Nexus 5X/6P that don't work with other USB-C, because those phones used a USB2 version of USB-C, and I believe aren't pinned the same.

title: Clearing Google Search Bar history completely

thread.text: It seems that the search bar history, or at least some of it, is not removed after I thought that I cleared my activity in Google/Accounts and privacy... For example, at least some history appears when I tap the search bar. I there a way to delete search history completely, perhaps all at once in Google products? Thanks.

Settings - Google - Search - Accounts and Privacy - My Activity - Tap the 3 horizontal bars at top left after it signs you in - Activity Controls - Toggle Web and App History to off.
It used to not be such a buried setting in prior Android versions. Guess Google really wants to collect info.
Thanks! I'll see how it works.

thread.text:
It is truly an underrated phone. After the Note 7 debacle, I've gone between a Pixel and this Moto Z Force Droid (with also a brand new, 256GB iPhone 7+ sitting in a box on my desk.) I started with Pixel, went to Z Force Droid, back to Pixel for a week and then sold Pixel and back with Z Force Droid full time. 
I have the JBL Speaker Mod and I will be getting a battery pack mod today. I also have a 256GB card formatted as adoptive storage and really use the heck out of this phone. The battery life is great and with moderate use, I can usually go 24 hours without recharging...heavier use, I do charge twice a day. And this phone charges faster than any phone I've ever used. 
The only problems I've had has been with the camera. Sometimes, it will say I need to reset the camera app or reboot phone. I once took a video of something I couldn't "re-do", the camera app crashed and didn't save my video. But other than that, no problems.
Speaking of the camera...while significantly slower than the Pixel camera, it takes awesome pictures and more consistently than the Pixel. With the Pixel, if I wasn't getting the "halo" effect, I was getting white washed pictures even in full daylight or blurry pictures at night. I'd rather put up with the slower camera on the Moto Z Force that hit and miss quality of the Pixel .
Speaking of this iPhone 7+ on my desk at work. One thing that has kept me from using it...iTunes. I don't want to have to sync with iTunes to get photos off the phone. I want to plug it in, move my pictures from phone to PC for storage and backup and be done with it.

replies.text:
I know, off topic on an Android Central forum, but there are a couple of ways to do this without iTunes (which I do not use for photos.) The first is iCloud Photo Library, which puts all of your photos into iCloud, and will sync easily to a Mac's Photos app or Windows - see https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT205323 for Windows.
The only issue is that Apple only gives you 5 GB of storage on iCloud for free, so you have to pay a monthly fee if you have more than 5 GB of storage.
The other way is at the same link - using My Photo Stream on iCloud, which I believe holds your last 30 days of photos. You just have to download them onto your PC (though it's possible on Windows that they just download automatically - I have only Macs.) There is no charge for My Photo Stream that I know of.

Haven't used an iPhone since a 5s work phone a couple years ago... But at the time I had onedrive set to upload photos from the camera and had icloud shut off... I have a office365 acct so I have 1tb storage on there... But either way you can move them off the onedrive once they sync to the pc... Never had to deal with trying to physically sync the phone that way

thread.text:

You never have to sync with iTunes for photos/vids. My wife has been using iPhones since the 4 and that is how we always unload photos. 
That being said, I have tried almost all the iPhones from the 4 on pretty much every year. I still cant use them and get rid of them. I dont like how locked down iOS is for doing just basic things.

Any suggestions on screen protection? Looking to keep scratches of main screen. I've had a couple different tempered glass one but they keep cracking... Which is annoying. Any suggestions?

Hello! I've used both plastic and tempered glass protectors on my phones, and have generally liked both. Plastic, however, does change the feel of your screen; whereas tempered glass gives your phone further protection and a nicer, "more accurate" feel. I would look on Amazon for some higher quality ones - some of the cheaper ones do work well, but if you can get a two-pack with a good rating, go for it!

Incipio with another new MOD.
I'm not particularly interested in this myself but good to see more development coming out of the woodwork.https://www.google.com/amp/www.andro...oto-z.html/amp

Came into this a little late, but I have the Mophie mod...
1- yes it has a usb-C charge port, and it is very happy charging from a Moto Turbo Charge adapter (I have the one with the phone and bought an extra). No wireless charging, but you can charge off wall adapter, car adapter, anything with a USB-C, no wireless pad needed.
It WILL also charge connected to the phone. IF you use a 'standard' charger, the phone will charge first (while showing "Waiting to Charge Mod". After the phone hits 100% and a few minute delay, it will divert charging to the Mophie), IF you plug into a Turbo Charger it will charge them simultaneously. What I have found is that if you want to charge it connected to the phone, plug the PHONE into the charger, not the Mophie. The phone circuitry handles sending power to both units.
2- yes, the stats integrate into the os (it shows on the battery page as well as the 'Command Center' widget wing
3- I will say that the leds are NICE to have, as you can hit a button on it and get a general idea of charge without having to plug it into the phone (as when you are using another Mod on the phone, and want to check the status of the power in the Mophie)
It has a slightly larger battery than the others and I actually like the design on this one a little better than the more rounded design of the others.
If I missed anything, just ask.

thread.text: is It true you can not run apps from the SD card on this phone?

replies.text: Hate to reply to something posted so long ago, but since no one addressed it - yes, you can install apps to the SD card if you use the "adoptable storage" option when you set up the SD card. It will then treat the card as internal storage. SD cards are slower than internal memory, though, so those apps will run slower. If you buy a cheap SD card, they could be frustratingly slow. If you don't install a ton of apps, it may be better to just set up certain apps to store their files to the SD card, and keep the apps on internal storage. I have a 128gb card, and set up Play Music and Google Photos to store their music, picture, and video files on the card, and have had zero issues, and still have over 13gb internal and 76gb on the card to work with.
Thanks!! for the reply FYI, GREAT to know that. After two Note 7's and a failed Pixel order I ended up with my first iPhone w/256GB so now I have all the space I need for now.

title: can't delete photo on SD card with google photo app

thread.text:
I love that google photo app is the default app for photo management. But recently google photo app can't delete the photos stored on SD card. It gave error like this:
Photos doesn't have access to delete items on your SD card. Go to the Gallery app to continue deleting.
Any solution ? Thanks !

replies.text: Where did the pictures come from?

thread.text: Yup, 3rd party apps (Google Photos included) don't have full SD Card access now. They can just read off of it and can only write/modify files into a folder the app created, so if the picture was not created by Google Photos, only the original app or a 'stock' application like the Gallery App or a system File Manager can do that.
but for Moto Z, google photos is the "stock" app.
Can you move the folder that the photos are in on the SD card into a folder that was created by the camera app? That folder should inherit the permissions of the higher level folder.
The third party file manager I installed can delete files no problem. So I don't think this is the issue. It is simply a bug. This is the problem with free apps, Google has no motivation to fix it.

What's interesting, however, is that that the Trusted Voice option in Security is off, and cannot be turned on because of the microphone issue.

I don't think this is the result of a mic issue. Moto Voice doesn't appear to be compatible with this setting whereas"OK Google" is. I personally use Moto Voice instead of "OK Google". 
At this point it appears like all Moto Voice does is go to Google Now, so it probably makes no difference at all. In the past, some of the Moto phones were optimized to preserve battery while the always listening feature was turned on. I haven't seen any comparisons drawn between how Moto Voice, vs. "Ok Google" impacts battery, but if anyone has some insight, I'd be very interested to hear about it. 
I would be tempted to change over simply due to trusted voice capability, but I haven't wanted to mess around with my settings since my phone has been running so smoothly and battery life has been phenomenal.

thread.text:
You need to setup OK Google first, then setup Moto voice in that order if you want Moto voice to work properly. If you just want OK Google then don't activate Moto voice. Moto voice just uses OK Google but adds a few cool features like reading incoming texts out loud hands free, and letting you respond hands free... announcing incoming callers and letting you answer, ignore, or send a text back hands free, and gives you the option to send a text back hands free if you can't answer the phone at the moment and the call is missed. 
All of these options are available through the phone or Bluetooth. Moto voice isn't a separate assistant, it's just OK Google with a few extra features. Personally it's one of the main reasons I use Moto phones.... Very few other Android phones do hands free this well.
When you have Moto voice activated you'll see the OK Google appear in the search bar when you first turn your phone on...Then it will dissapear. If you want OK Google instead just go into the Moto app and under voice turn Moto voice off 😋

Google doesn't sell user data. Verizon does. They sell it at least to credit bureaus and collection agencies; I know this for a fact because I've been involved in several of those trades. Verizon was completely willing to sell data for the creation of a universal "skip trace" database that had enhanced data capabilities useful for creating analytical data modeling of the propensity to pay for specific users that could be run up against debt that Verizon, AT&T, DirecTV, Dish Network, AOL (prior to being owned by Verizon), Capital One, CitiBank, many national healthcare providers and others were selling. This information included everything that was on the Verizon billing account except for the first 4 digits of the social security number or taxpayer identification number - those first 4 digits were hashed. All of the other companies I just listed also sell that user data. Verizon, Citibank and TransUnion were the three biggest third party partners in the creation of that database, which is the primary database utilized in third party collections and debt purchase collections for "high volume" collections, which includes student loan debts and healthcare. 
Google does not do these things; so why are you saying I'm accusing Verizon of doing things that Google does?

below are Verizon's directions to create a new auto reply
From a home screen, tap Apps.
Select Message+.
Tap Menu (slide 3 horizontal bars on left side of screen to the right).
Select Settings.
Select Auto Reply
Select Add a New Message. [Not an option on my pixel xl]
Enter a message then tap Save.
Change the end date then tap Set.
Tap Start.

title: Moto Z voice and bluetooth sms

thread.text: I now have the Moto voice activated on my Moto Z Force. I have a uConnect 730N system in my Jeep. I typically keep my phone in my pocket, but I still receive SMS messages through my uConnect. Basically, the uConnect annouces that I have a "new message from joe" and asks me whether I want to reply. However, my answer will not be heard by the uConect if the phone's in my pocket. I can hear incoming announcements with the phone in my pocket, but the Moto voice app won't "hear" me. I can engage in phone conversations without any problems. Maybe I don't understand the basic concepts here, so perhaps someone has an explanation. Perhaps it's a uConnect and not a droid issue. Thanks!
Turn off driving option in the Moto app. The car should still tell you there's a message but the phone won't ask for a reply.

Thanks very much! Before I give it a try, do you know whether the car will ask me for a reply? Otherwise, I might as well just let the phone announce that there's a message. 
I recall that, before I started using Moto voice, I could receive and reply to SMS through OK Google. I understand that Moto is pretty much a front end OK Google, but I can't set OK Google as a "trusted voice" in Security settings because of the bug that states that I can't use the microphone (described in http://forums.androidcentral.com/mot...one-issue.html). While I can use OKG for things like searches when the screen's unlocked, I can't engage in OKG stuff when it's locked because I can't set up a trusted voice. In my case, none of the fixes suggested in the above thread resolved the issue, and Verizon suggested that I reset all of my apps to their defaults, which seems like a pain. If I'm wrong, please correct me.

I'm here to tell you the Bluetooth, handsfree calling, and talk to text on these phones is a joke.
Half the time my phone does what you describe, it's connected to the truck, but tries to "talk" through the phone. 
The other half of the time it won't connect at all.
After trouble shooting and multiple resets, I'm done with my Moto.
I'm having my old HTC Windows Phone reactivated tomorrow. Yea, it's won't stay charged anymore, but it connects 100% of the time to BT and WI Fi.
This is not how I wanted to spend $700

replies.text:
I'm here to tell you that I have had 0 issues with WiFi at home or work. 
I'm here to tell you that I have had 0 issues with Bluetooth in multiple vehicles.

I also have no issues with WiFi anywhere. My issue is with BT/SMS Can you reply to an SMS through your vehicle's system without having the phone out? What if it's locked? Can you send an SMS in the vehicle under the same conditions? Lastly, do you use the Moto app or OK Google? Sorry for all the questions, but thanks for any advice you can offer.

I use Moto Voice. For the most part, Moto Voice is now just a gateway to OK Google. Essentially, it just let's you have a custom launcher phrase. 
With my car's Bluetooth, my phone needs to be out of my pocket in order to hear me say my launch phrase. The action button initiates my car's own voice menu. I had an older car where I could set it to my phone's voice prompt. 
With this set up, the phone can't be in your pocket to initiate the voice prompt. I put my phone in mount so I have no troubles initiating Moto Voice/OK Google. 
But if I get a text message, Moto Voice kicks in and sends it over the Bluetooth connection as a phone call. I have 0 issues listening and replying to text messages - even if I happen to leave my phone in my pocket. 
I haven't tried this while locked because my Moto 360 and my car are both trusted Bluetooth devices.

Thanks very much for the detailed reply! It just may be that I'll have to keep the phone out to use SMS. That way, I could initiate an SMS and engage in messaging. However, I'd be happy to just reply to an SMS as you do, with the phone in pocket.

replies.text:
#1 - Not sure, never had to use my Z Force overseas. I am sure others will chime in!
#2 - Wifi calling works very well for me. My house is in a dead zone of cell reception for all carriers and wifi calling has made things so much better. I even had TMO for a while due to their wifi calling but their actual reception was terrible anywhere else down here so I had to go back to Verizon.
#3 - I have the Dual Pro and do not like it. It looks nice and is well made but I find it slippery (I have the red one if it matters). The bevels on the bottom side made it slide in my hands too much and I have pretty big hands. I had no issues at all with a screen protector and the case. My favorite case thus far is the Tech21 Evo Check. Buttons are easy to push, offers good protection and it is grippy while still sliding in and out of my front jeans pocket easily. title: How did I get a lock screen image

thread.text: Just got my Moto z force a few days ago and today I noticed when I press the power button I have a screensaver image that is different from my home screen. I don't know how it got there and even though I deleted the image from photos and from Zedge (where I originally got it) it still remains. Anyone know how to get rid of this?

It'll stay there until you change it to something else; go to Settings -> Display -> Wallpaper and choose a new one. Alternatively you can also use the Zedge app - IIRC from using Zedge when setting wallpaper you're given "Lock screen" as a choice in addition to Home and perhaps your launcher.
My home screen wallpaper changes but not the lock screen image which I didn't think Moto phones even had. I tried Zedge, but I don't see the option for lock screen. Not sure what I'm doing wrong

replies.text:
On Nougat-
Long press on a home screen.
Select the Wallpaper option.
Select a wallpaper. Press Set.
Pop-up should appear that gives you the option to set home, lockscreen, or both.
No need to use Zedge.

It appears Zedge only sets for the Home screen, my mistake. Your photo album should include an option for "set as" or "use as" from the menu or if you press and hold on the photo, depending on the app.

I feel like it should be something obvious that I'm missing. I have updated to nougat.

replies.text:
Settings -> Lock Screen -> Wallpaper. 
Really, I've been using Android for a couple years now. Not sure why I'm being a noob tonight.

title: Keep Awake for Amazon Kindle App

thread.text:
Even when I'm not using (and haven't used for some time, the battery usage shows CPU usage and unusually high "Keep awake" minutes. I've tried restarting the Z, but even then the app shows up in the battery usage with abnormally high keep Awake minutes...Certainly for an app I haven't opened. 
Any ideas?

Install GSam Battery Monitor. Open it and let it run. There's an icon on the bottom of the main screen that looks like a vacuum. Its called app sucker. Tap that and it will show you what apps are using the battery. 
Let it run all day. Then open the app and take screen shots of the main screen and the app sucker screen. 
Post them here and someone will help. 
Without knowing what apps you have its hard to tell.

replies.text: I already know from the standard battery usage screen that it is the Amazon Kindle app I'm concerned about...

thread.text:
If you want to restrict it from running in the background (or any app) here's the path to the setting.
Settings>apps>amazon kindle>2nd down is data. Open that and restrict it from accessing background data. 
You can do this for almost any app. It helps my battery life a lot.

replies.text: Thanks! I'll try that. Does that limit the functionality? I.e. if I "am" using the Kindle app, will it still sync my book reading place or would I need to turn this switch back on?

thread.text:
I don't use the kindle app so I can't say. But every app I do this with hasn't shown any issues. I've never had to turn it back on. For that matter I do this with almost all apps.
It just saves battery and data. Apps still access data when connected to wifi. It only restricts them from accessing data on 4g when the app isn't being used. 
The nice thing is if it causes you any issues just go in and reconnect the access. 
In fact go in sometime and look at some apps and you will be surprised how many apps have access to background data. I've always shut it down and never had any issues.
I hope this helps. If not ask away......Glad to help!

replies.text: That's great info. Actually I do simetimes use the app (reading a book) while off wifi. But it should be easy enough to verify if the sync or other functionality is working...I'll test it out. Also interesting about the other apps. I'll check them out as you suggested. Thanks again for all the feedback!
You can also read through the forum in the stickies. There's one there labeled apps safe to disable. I've learned a lot in that discussion.

title: Is Moto Z Force Droid significantly better than Turbo 2?

thread.text:
If I don't care about the Moto mods, are the Moto Z Force camera, video (e.g. will I notice 60 fps for video as better than 30fps), battery life, processor, charging, fingerprint feature , etc significantly better things than in the Turbo 2?
I was contemplating the Turbo 2 as well because I want a waterproof case, which Lifeproof only makes for the Turbo 2 not the Moto Z lineup. I am really hard on my things, so I need to decide if the Motorola Z force is such a superior phone that I should buy with a basic case or if I should stick to the older Turbo 2 and will it feel like it keeps up with new phone tech?

There is supposed to be an Adventure mod, which is basically a waterproof case released. I don't have a T2, but rather an MXPE but I did look at the T2. The shattershield on the T2 reduces the quality of the screen. They fixed that with the Z Force. Camera and performance should be significantly better on the Z Force.

Trouble is, what one person considers "significant improvement" another will consider "marginal improvement", and what one person considers expensive another considers chump change. "Worth it" is always up to the person opening their wallet, so you'll need to spend time reading reviews, and go check out a display to put one in your hand. If I had a Turbo2, and it was meeting my needs, I most likely wouldn't consider it worth it, because $500-800 is a fair amount of money to me, but I was upgrading from an older phone. 
Hopefully someone who specifically upgraded from a Turbo2 can chime in here, though, since their input on what they like better/worse would probably be helpful.

My daughter has my old T2 and I have the Force. The Force is a better all around performer (camera, speed, finreprint reader, etc.) but I would struggle to say it's "significantly" better. I think some of the other posts hit it on the head - if some if the features in the Force are super important to you, it could be (significantly better). My thought is it's just an evolutionary upgrade.
I went from a Turbo to the Z Force. While the Z Force is an awesome phone, I would not do it again. When I consider the $$s spent, the upgrade was just not worth it for my needs.

Tried a Force coming from a T2 and returned. WiFi dropped in and out, ring and notification tones too low (not changed by recent update) and expensive. Actually, since my coverage is so bad at my office, switched back to a MXPE, loving the bigger screen and dual speakers and better reception.

replies.text: Didn't have the MXPE, but I had a Nexus 6, and every phone I have had since then, I have wished they had that size a screen and dual front speakers

I had the MAXX, and while I didn't find that camera to be super slow (the camera on my Nexus 6 is much worse), the Z Force is faster. Not instantaneous, but pretty quick.I was actually really glad to downsize from my Nexus 6. It was just a bit unweildy IMO, and I'm surprised I didn't drop it more than the couple times I did (no damage to anything but the case, fortunately.) That's totally just my opinion, though, and I can understand how some people want as much screen as possible.
I've also found that I'll never be satisfied with phone speakers for music, so I quit caring about stereo v mono, etc. It's all tinny garbage sound to me, and I won't listen to music unless it's through a real stereo or headphones. Even the JBL mod is only borderline worth listening to IMO. I may just be spoiled with really nice stereos at home, work, and car.

title: Considering a Moto Z Force. Have some questions.

thread.text:
I have a Note 3 and was going to upgrade to Note 7. Don't need to say much more on that, obviously. After doing a lot reading online, I feel like I'm narrowing choices down to the Moto Z Force. I have a few questions ...
1. If I don't care about the Mods, do you feel this phone stands alone without Mods as a good choice? Its specs impress me, independent of the Mods.
2. Do you feel the ShatterShield screen makes installing a protective case unnecessary? I realize that a case will make using Mods unrealistic, but I don't think I'll be using any of them. Still, it would be nice to finally have a phone that doesn't need a protective case.
3. From what I've read here, it looks like the ShatterShield glass will still need a screen protector. Do you agree?
4. Any former Samsung users here (especially former Note users) who now use a Moto Z Force? Any culture shock I should be aware of?

replies.text:
1. I only have Style Shells right now (I swap between the Charcoal Ash wood that ships with the black DROID and the Crimson Ballistic Nylon). The battery life is amazing so I don't need the battery mod right now and I have a ZTE Spro 2 Android projector (review coming soon) that's way better than the Moto Insta-Share Projector.
2. ShatterShield scratches easily. Put a screen protector on it. ShatterShield doesn't protect anything else. See Phil destroying Android Central's Moto Z Force Droid review unit.
3. IMO, yes.
4. "Stock" Android interface. There will be some bells and whistles that Samsung adds that you may like that won't be on the Moto Z Force Droid.

thread.text:
Welcome, 
The Z Force would be a great choice. 
#1 I truly believe the Z Force stands on its own without the mods. They are a bonus. I have the battery mod with wireless charging and have used it the first day to see how it would work for me. Definitely happy to have it for when I'm in the middle of a big project but haven't used it again since day one. Battery life is very good and turbo charge is very fast. 
#2/3 I have the black Verizon bumper to protect the frame (I don't always use it) and the Verizon flexible glass screen protector. I really enjoy the piece of mind the ShatterShield provides. 
Edit: I have the leather style shell back, strongly recommend it. Very nice feel and look. 
#4 I had every Note other than the original and that edge Note that came out a few years ago. I switched to the Z Force when I turned in the Note 7 on the first battery issue and never went back. After playing with the Z Force for a day or two I was sold. So smooth and fast, I never really understood why people would say the Note had lag until I spent a few days with the very close to stock Android Z Force. I ran in to a few things I thought were Android that ended up being Samsung TW. Nothing that I would call a problem at all, mostly just finding a different way to do the same thing. Sometimes just needed to find an app to do the same thing. Very few (2 or 3) of these, nothing I have issue with.

Connert,
Thanks for the reply. Do feel the Bumper offers much shock absorption? That is, enough to prevent destroying the phone like that mentioned by Ry above? I have used Otterbox products so far for shock absorption.

replies.text:
I have mine in an Otterbox Defender. I tried a cheap gel case and the Verizon bumper case mentioned above. Nothing wrong with either. I just couldn't adjust to not having a brick in my hand. 
The phone is awesome and battery life is amazing. I have posted somewhere in these threads screen grabs showing almost 3 days with the battery mod. I typically have 50-70% at the end of a day, depending on signal strength and usage.

thread.text:
Yes, I think it's plenty of protection. If you watch the video of Phil dropping the Z Force on a sidewalk, it took 5 times face down from a good 5.5 to 6' before the phone stopped working. Even then the screen never cracked. I think a heavy case is overkill on this device. I use the bumper or nothing at all. I have the bumper to protect the metal frame and I believe it will absorb the shock of most drops.
Phil's drop test.
Thanks, Ry and Connert. You both helped a lot.

It's an awesome device. I have the Incipio battery mod. Although you don't really need it. The battery life itself is amazing. More than likely will improve when we get nougat. Just as stated above, there will be bells and whistles that won't be on this device coming from a Samsung device. All in all... You won't miss them

I would definitely consider a screen protector. 
Mods are just a plus, the Force is awesome as is.
Battery is not an issue as it easily lasts all day
I use use the Incipio DualPro case on mine and doesn't add that much bulk to the phone. The lip on front keeps the screen from touching any surface and the camera lens is just slightly recessed on the back.

All these replies have been very helpful. I'm now considering how I'm going to reproduce what I was occasionally doing with my Note 3: using a stylus to take a quick note. I think I'll invest in a stylus for my pocket for this.

replies.text:
This is the only part of the Note I miss. I used the spen as part of my everyday life. 
I had to train myself to just type out the notes I would take otherwise. I'm going to recommend Google Keep for this. I set up labels and added the chrome extension to my desktop. I'm also learning to use Google now with voice input and set up some of my notes as reminders. Google keep is the best way to keep notes across devices, although you will have to train yourself to type them out. 
BTW, I also tried using a capacitive stylus. You will hate it. It will not even come close to meeting your expectations. But good luck.
Well, I just ordered a capacitive stylus with a 5mm writing tip, from Amazon. I'll see if I can live with it. I'll experiment on my Note 3.

thread.text: So can you use the leather back style shell and the bumper case simultaneously?

thread.text: I have had several generations of Android cell devices over the years. The most recent was a Motorola MAXX Ultra for a couple years. I then decided to research a new phone choosing the Moto Z Force. Having this cell phone for a couple weeks now, I love this phone. I love the speed and the tweak's you can perform to make it faster between screens. The JBL Speaker mod has incredible sound to it and attaches very easily. Image on the screen is sharp and crystal clear with some auto adjustments for proper back lighting. I love the ability to fully charge the unit in under 1/2 hour (Only if it is below 70%. There is only one thing I don't like about this phone and that is.... the glass. So what if it doesn't shatter? This screen will nick and scratch sitting by itself in the corner. I think Suran wrap has a harder surface. I had my Droid Maxx for two years, used it in construction job sites almost every day and never using a screen protector, that screen still looks brand new. In two weeks I have a series of scratches and a small nick in it already. I just now installed a glass screen protector. I would rather have my old glass that could shatter than this crap. I also dropped my old phone on more than one occasion on it side, front, edge with no effects to the phone at all. This while using a slim $5.00 gel skin/glove. If you don't want your cell to shatter, use a 4 level case which I purchased on Ebay. for 1/3 the price of Verizon. I hope they revise the glass on this phone, other than that, it is a great buy.

replies.text: After researching how the DROID TURBO 2 stood up (Shatter Shield Generation 1), I didn't start using my Moto Z Force Droid until I put a glass screen protector on it.
Smart move. Same for me. If you get a good tempered glass, it feels the same as any other phone.

I actually had Verizon install their Flexible Glass protector on mine when I activated the phone. By leaving the OEM protective film on until doing so, the installation is perfect and virtually undetectable.

thread.text: I did the same.

I would consider myself an average user, and I don't know how you guys are getting decent battery life out of this unit. I have the battery Mod, and if it and the phone are both charged at 7am, buy lunch they're both dead. 
Between that and my other post in the Bluetooth connectivity issues, I, personally can't recommend it. Going to return it and reactivate my Windows Phone.

replies.text: You're talking about the Force and not the regular Z? Obviously everyone's usage is different so comparisons aren't totally useful but I average 6 hours screen on time, over 24 hours with the unit on. Some do much better than that if you have a strong signal; others do somewhat worse.

What's the screen on time? What apps are running? Even if we're talking the regular Z with its smaller battery, either you're using it near constantly during that time, or an app is running constantly in the background, or something's wrong with the phone and/or battery mod. That's not normal at all. If you're willing to post more details, folks on this forum can help you figure out which.

The number one cause for this lately seems to be the Facebook apps. If you have them installed, can you try uninstalling them for a day? i followed these directions, trying to get my Hotspot to come on when it sees a bluetooth connection to my head unit:I prefer to create my tasks first.Enter Task
Go to the Tasks tab and click the plus sign. Name your enter task, for example, "Hot Spot On". Click the plus sign to add an action, select "Net", "WiFi Tether", and set to on. Exit Task
Go to the Tasks tab and click the plus sign. Name your exit task, for example, "Hot Spot Off". Click the plus sign to add an action, select "Net", "WiFi Tether", and set to off. Profile
Go to the Profile tab and click the plus sign. Select "State" as the first context. Next, select "Net", followed by "BT connected". Under the "Name" heading (where it shows optional) click the magnifying glass and select the Joying BT address. 
Add the "Hot Spot On" task for the enter task. Then longpress the "Hot Spot On" task and select the option to add an exit task. Add the "Hot Spot Off" as the exit task. 
Now, each time your phone connects to your Joying it will automatically turn on your hot spot. When your connection ends, your hot spot will turn off.

- maybe toggle your WiFi radio off first, to make sure that you are not connected to WiFi when you turn on the hotspot??

title: Was I sold a used phone?

thread.text: I bought my phone Dec 23rd. I noticed in the status area it shows "last factory data reset Nov 8th". Does that mean someone else had this phone and it was returned, or is that something different?
If you bought it from them then it was new -- it would be illegal to sell you a used phone marked as new.
Thank you
There is a good chance that November 8th was the date Android was first installed on your phone during the manufacturing process.

I bought my Z Force mid October. I believe that it had a last FDR of early October. I would certainly hope that no one is ever sold a used or refurbished phone, when expecting a brand-new device. At least, not unless told so in advance.

When recording a video, the image quality is fine. However, the audio occasionally makes a fast stuttering/clicking sound similar to a bad fan. Maybe it's related to noise cancellation? It happened when I was recording a video of a part of a TV show, at normal volume in the living room with no other noise. 
Anyone else experience this issue? (Fyi, this audio issue happened for every video setting available on the phone, from 480p to 4K)

replies.text: Post an example.

It could be noise cancellation. Is there are a case on the phone? Or is there a chance that you are covering one of the microphones when you hold the phone?
This diagram shows the location of the microphones. 
Sometimes the phone's radios interfere with audio (though that's rare with CDMA/LTE compared with GSM). Just as an experiment, what happens if you record with airplane mode on? (Or, airplane mode and then manually turn on WiFi)? I'm not suggesting this as a permanent fix, just to see if the LTE radio is causing interference like this.
It was the microphone being covered with the palm of my hand that caused the noise. Had no idea it was located there, thanks for the helpful information.

thread.text: Anyone not able to activate wifi calling? Every time I try to do so, it says something like "cannot activate wifi calling at this time. Please try again later." Per Verizon customer support, I reset network settings and did a restart. Anything else I can try? It's been like this for well over a week.

replies.text: No issues for me.

How fast is your network or WiFi (i.e., what upload/download do you get from the Speedtest app or from the website Speed test - how fast is your internet? | DSLReports, ISP Information in Chrome ? Do you have any kind of Quality of Service or other firewall on your network that might be preventing the phone from connecting properly to the network?
Can you try at a friend's house on their WiFi?
My wifi signal at home is incredibly strong, so I doubt that is the issue.

I'm not talking about your WiFi signal - I'm talking about your ISP's backhaul speed from your router to the internet (particularly upload speed, which is usually slower.) What are your speeds? Did you try it at another location to rule out a firewall issue, or a blocked port?
I've never tried WiFi calling with a double NAT, but, if you have a router inside a router and it is not set to bridge mode, it could be that as well. Verizon doesn't say that's an issue, but that can cause problems. (This is another reason to try another location.)
Last thing - did you se up an emergency address when you turned on WiFi calling? That's required in order to have it work.

thread.text: If you haven't already tried this, try putting your phone in airplane mode, which turns off data and WiFi. Then turn on WiFi. You should then be able to use WiFi calling. You can test this to make sure that your WiFi calling is activated.

replies.text: I'll try this when I get home. Thanks!

thread.text: I forgot to mention that you will need to connect to a WiFi network.

replies.text: I tried this and it didn't work. The Verizon tech support person seemed to think it could have something to do with me having switched my sim card from one device to a second one. Not sure why it would matter though.

You are not connected to WiFi. (There is no WiFi icon in the status bar.)

The Moto Z Force Droid uses a more advanced 21MP Sony sensor with deep trench isolation (DTI) technology for improved color fidelity. It also uses a hybrid autofocus system that combines laser, phase detection (PDAF), and contrast detection methods, which should provide faster, more reliable focusing performance in a variety of lighting conditions.
And here is the camera test section in the Anandtech article:http://www.anandtech.com/show/10493/...droid-review/5
FWIW, the Pixels do not have true (I assume you mean optical) image stabilization. They have software ("electronic") stabilization for video, but it's still not OIS.
What do you mean when you say the Z Force does not have "true" image stabilization?

thread.text:
I was pleasantly surprised by the camera and it was high on my list of needs with 3 kids. I had a LG G4, Moto X Pure and Nexus 5x to compare it with and my wife had the iPhone 6 and now the 7. The G4 had way more controls and tweaks available which is nice (I also shoot with a DSLR and micro 4/3) but 9/10 times with my phone I want to grab and just shoot, not tweak. If I want those shots for a Christmas card I take out my big cameras. In full auto mode I would say the Z Force compares very well with the iPhone 7 and is better than the others in overall usage. iPhones still manage to do color balance really well as far as getting it "correct". It is not muted nor is it punchy like a Samsung phone. The low light shots are fine for every day use and sharing with the OIS helping a ton. You can get some pretty slow shutter speeds to let in enough light and still have a clear shot if you hold well. 
From my usage I would say the Z Force is better than all other than iPhone 7. The 5x was pretty decent but is sloooow, especially with HDR on. The MXPE was just OK even brand new. You could get shots that were OK on FB but dont blow them up at all. The G4 is just showing it's age. When new I was blown away, now it just sort of decent. 
I'm heading to Disney for a week and I want to really compare the Z Force vs. my wifes iPhone 7. We'll be in bright sun to indoors to full night for shots. I am trying to avoid bringing my Olympus 4/3 to the parks if I can.

replies.text: Thanks for the info. How is the Z Force for capturing action and motion (i.e. kids running around?)

Well... no phone camera does all that great for fast motion. If you are outside in bright light with the phone picking a nice fast shutter than sure. Sometimes you sort of need to anticipate the shot a bit. I have a fast 4 yr old boy and I get a lot of motion blur unless in full sun. I tend to get that with any phone though. One thing that can help is just hold down the shutter button. It will keep on firing and one shot may work better than the rest. I do that with my DSLR as well.
Indoors you need a manual camera app so you can pick a faster shutter to avoid blur but then you run into dark shots with too little light getting to the sensor. OIS does nothing for capturing movement, it just helps combat your hand moving when taking a photo of a still object.

title: Incipio vs. Mophie Battery mods... Which is better?

thread.text: Which do you all prefer, the Incipio Battery Mod, or the new Mophie battery Mod for the Moto Z Force? Which do you recommend I get?

replies.text:
Recharging will be the main difference. 
Incipio has two, one without and with Qi wireless charging. Capacity is the same. The only way to charge the Incipio model without wireless charging is to connect it to the phone and plug the phone in. The wireless charging model can be charged separately via Qi charging. 
The Mophie can be charged while connected to the phone or via its own USB Type-C port.

thread.text:
The morphie is better! Imo!
The 3150mah battery vs 2200 mah! It gives 50% more than all the others!
The ability to charge by itself. No need for the phone attached! 
Battery indicator that lights up and tells you when it is low or full! 
Textured surface for better grip vs. Smooth and slippery! 
It does add weight but not bad and the shape makes it easy to hold! 
I use the incipio bumper case and mophie battery! 
VERIZON has on sale! $79 recently and where I got mine. 
Best mod of them all if you ask me. The speakers are loud enough that I don't need the JBL. Plus, the jbl is bigger and more clumpy than the mophie. 
I miss the kick stand but have a generic cell phone stand that works great. So, I am on cloud ☁ 9 and love my purchase! 
Kd

With 3150mah battery external and 3300 mah battery internal! 
6450 mah of battery! I prefer the economy mode as the phone runs much cooler and does not heat up as much. It switches back and forth. Giving the batteries a break and cool down period! 
I just charge up at night when I think about! Even missed a night and no problem! 
Hardly ever use my car charger any more! The battery is AWESOME 😆! 
KD

Mophie, Mophie! Is the Hands down winner! My Moto Z Force with this battery Mod cannot be matched by anything...I love the look on my fellow friends at work when I tell them I don't need a charger at work... The look of disbelief is priceless 😠...all the Samsung Galaxy whatevers, iPhones, LGs, HTCs are just phones that once you buy them, that's all you get. The Moto has jumped so far ahead of the Competition (along with Nougat 7.0 I might add) they are in a league of their own.

Do yourself a favor and physical check both out first. The Mophie is noticeably bigger and heavier than the Incipio. For the most part, I don't even like having my Incipio mod attached unless I know I wont be near a charger.

I use the Incipio non-wireless charging battery mod. It's a little lighter than the wireless charging version and makes all the difference for me for overall weight as I leave it on my Moto Z Droid all the time. 
I would prefer using the wireless charging battery, which I also have, but the extra bit of weight matters to me.

replies.text: When using this, does the mod get drained first, prior to using the phone battery? Also, do you chair separator while connected to the phone?

There are 2 options:
deplete the battery mod first, then the phone battery
deplete the phone battery to 80%, then the mod battery, then the rest of the phone batteryhuh?

The phone is always getting power from the internal battery, but with the mod attached and depending on which mode you choose, it'll either start trickle charging the internal battery immediately or after the it gets down to 80%. The phone will use the mod until it's depleted and no longer charging.
So just to clarify for those that are wondering, the phone never draws power directly from the mod. The mod is a battery charger.
It works very, very well. I keep mine on 24/7 using efficiency mode and the mod never goes below 30% for me after a full days usage. And that means I still have 80% left in the internal battery as well. Would have no problem getting 2 full days, and that's with the Moto Z and not the Force. I'm using the non-wireless Incipio because it's a little lighter which for me makes a difference.

thread.text: Sorry... That should have said, do you charge the mod and phone separately or as a single device.

replies.text:
I personally charge as a single device. I'm not 100% sold on wireless charging but have a battery with wireless charging because it was on sale.
That being said, I could totally see the use case for just simply placing the battery on the wireless charging pad when not in use.

The Incipio without wireless charging has to be charged on the phone.
The Incipio with wireless charging can be charged on the phone or on a wireless charger (on or off the phone).
The Mophie can be charged on the phone or with USB-C.

thread.text: OK, thx. From what I've read, the Incipio seems to be the more popular one.

replies.text: It also launched with the Moto Z. The Mophie was within the last month.

thread.text: Great reply. It helps allot. How does one distinguish between the wireless charging and non wireless charging version? I don't do wireless charging.

replies.text: You can get the non-wireless version of the Incipio battery mod from the Incipio website. That's where I ordered it, and it's clearly stated which is which. Runs about $59. Best Buy ONLY sells the wireless version. Best way to distinguish is the wireless one is around $79 or more depending on where you see it.

I have the wireless Incipio and bumper case also. At night I charge them both wirelessly on a Samsung charger I got for $15 on eBay. I want to take advantage of the VR capabilities of my Z Force. Where do I begin? Headsets, software, etc. I see all the software downloads but I don't know where to start. Any Suggestions?

Please point me in the right direction. Thanks!

1. I don't know (or care) all that much about VR headsets. 
2. But what I do know, I think that you're best off with Google's DayDream headset. The Z Force with the Nougat update is compatible with Google's new DayDream Viewer. https://store.google.com/product/daydream_view

replies.text: Yep, that's the conclusion I am coming to...

thread.text: Daydream is much better than a simple cardboard viewer. It's a big step forward.
Daydream. The only way to go if you don't have a Samsung.
Thank you all. I got it.

I've got 2 gear VR headsets (Gen 1 and Gen 2) as well as the daydream headset for the Z Force. I really like how VR is getting a presence in the play store and more Android devices vs being forced to buy from Oculus through samsung. The gear vr is a little more refined, but the wii like controller on Daydream I believe opens up a lot of opportunity that gear vr doesn't have. I would say that Daydream may actually have a little more momentum going for them right now. 2017 will be interesting as far as VR goes.
Point being, don't feel that daydream is any lesser of a product or experience than gear vr. They are both pretty good. I'm hoping for lower CPU temps and higher resolutions from both in the future.

I'm hoping to see some options in the future for a more sophisticated Daydream controller as well. Currently it seems it would be difficult to implement more complex controls, like walking around. It's very user friendly, but not very deep. For example, I'm having a hard time imagining Minecraft programmed to work with the Daydream controller. It could be as simple as offering (or supporting) a more standard bluetooth game controller, which would be less immersive in a way (not using your hands to point at things), but would allow for more complex games. 
But the Daydream headset is totally worth it if you have a phone that supports it (such as the Moto Z / Z Force). It's at least a clear starting point.

thread.text: I had to go digging a 6th time but found them.

Hi all. I have a Z Force as my work phone and a Z Play as my personal phone. In all aspects outside of battery life, I prefer the Force ever so slightly. It has a better screen, feels a little more premium in hand, has a more sturdy feel to it, etc. The Play is extraordinarily close in all respects, but ever so slightly behind. 
However, despite the fact that the two phones have almost identical size batteries, the Z Play gets literally double the battery life to the Z Force. In SOT, standby, usage - with all metrics it doubles up the Force. I know all about the specs, but the Force really shouldn't be getting half the battery life of the Play, right? The phones are set up exactly the same way, so that can't be causing the variance. Is it really possible that the more powerful processor, more resolute screen and 1 extra GB of RAM halves battery life? Screen resolution can't be that huge of a factor because the same holds true with standby when screen is off.
Any thoughts?

replies.text: ..Screen resolution is a major factor, IMO.
That's true, but then how to account for the huge discrepancy in idle drain (when the screen is off)?

I doubt that the RAM has much effect (more RAM should be better for battery life, as the OS would have to spend less time managing RAM usage), but - yes. It's not just the screen resolution (which affects processor usage for apps which draw a lot on the display - that's 75% or so more pixels on the Force, and the GPU probably needs to do a lot more calculating for each change on the display), but also that the Z Force probably has brightness pushed up a bit because of the multi-layer shatter-resistant display.
But, if I were to make a guess, it's the processors that make the most power difference compared with the Z Force (and Z).

title: Dreaded 'To Start Android, Enter Password' after reboot. PLEASE HELP

thread.text:
Last night I got home, threw my phone on my charger with and realized I hadn't restarted my phone in quite some time, so I decided to power down. Upon powering on, after the lenovo/droid splash screen, I get this black screen with a prompt to enter my password to start android. I never set a password, just a pin. Entering the pin doesn't work, entering my main google account password doesn't work either. 
There were 2 times where I entered a password and instead of the usual 'wrong password' message, it said 'To start Android, turn the device off and then back on'. Following the directions only gets me back to the original black screen prompting a password entry.
I've gotten to the point where it says I have 8 more attempts at the password at which point the device will be wiped.
I also tried to boot into safe mode to no avail. Pressing the down volume button and power gets me to the Android boot/recovery menu where I have options for 'Recovery Mode' and 'Factory Mode', what's the difference between factory and recovery modes?
Has anyone successfully gotten past this screen without having to wipe the phone? ANY advice is appreciated!
Thanks

The Recovery mode is normally used to wipe the cache partition, which gets rid of unnecessary files and cleans things up. The Factory data recovery resets the phone to new, erasing all data, etc. Do a Google search for your issue, as others have run into this predicament. Hope this helps.

Thanks, yeah, I've Googled it and it looks like its most common among people that have rooted/unlocked bootloader/or flashed a rom, none of which I've done. The only thing close to that that I've done is running a line of code via ADB for the Tasker Plugin AutoTools. Last night was the first reboot since running the ADB. I don't think there is a way to get past the password screen, and am thinking I'll have to reset.
Odd. I thought this should be your PIN.
Do you download anything outside of the Google play store ? Wondering if your phone got infected with something.

Ended up calling Verizon tech support. They walked me through clearing the cache (he pronounced it casháy... smh) partition, which got me past the password blockage, but it did reset my phone too, which neither of us thought would happen, but it did. 
I thought it was maybe the AutoTools plugin for tasker that made the phone hiccup, but I can't seem to repeat that. 
This similarly happened to my wife's Nexus 6P about a month ago, hers had a message saying the password was wrong and because of the device being encrypted, it would have to be reset. The only common circumstance I can think of was that both phones were plugged in (USB-C) when powering on. I wonder if all the kinks have yet to be ironed out with USB-C standardization across the different android manufacturers.

replies.text: Do you use only apps from the Play Store, or do you side load some apps? I'm thinking that some app had administrator privilege and somehow encrypted the phone with its own PIN. I'd almost also wonder about Android Device Manager and remote locking, but that's obvious that it is ADM doing the locking. Do you have any other security apps on the phone?

I use tasker coupled with the Secure Settings plugin to set PIN access. I've been doing it for a while on several different devices though, and never had this issue. My wife had the same thing happen to her, but she doesn't use the Secure Settings plugin. I don't sideload apps except for my own that I create from Tasker.

thread.text:
I guess you should see the below link before you res-set the phone.How to Bypass ‘To Start Android, Enter Your Password’ Message, If You Set a Pattern Lock (No Root) - techtrickz
I landed to a similar issue when my phone had an android update, this is the very annoying thing from android.

replies.text: If you look at the photo in the first post, that's Android asking for your passphrase in order to unlock the encrypted file system. If you cannot supply that passphrase, the only way to restart the phone is to factory data reset it.

Where does this passphrase get set? On both phones this has happened to, the PIN was not the passphrase. The main gmail account password was not the passphrase. And I've never set up any pattern security feature. I think next time I read somewhere that 'default_password' might work. I actually get really anxious every time I restart my phone now. I make backups of all my apps that can. It's a real headache.

When you encrypt your phone, it requires that you have PIN or passphrase security before it does anything else. The PIN or passphrase that you would use to unlock the phone also unlocks the encryption key at boot up. I'm not sure what happened on your phone, though, if your unlock PIN did not decrypt the full disk encryption key.
As far as I know, these phones ship with encryption on.

I never executed any encryption function on either of my two phones that this occurred on. The phone was encrypted to start with apparently. No PIN or password that I ever used on the phone allowed me to access the phone. Always have had to do a factory reset.

thread.text: I just checked in Settings/Security and it appears that my phone is encrypted with no option to do otherwise. Hadn't noticed that before. There is an option to encrypt the memory card, but I have not done that. Interesting.

replies.text: I believe all phones that are capable and shipped with Marshmallow and above are encrypted by default.

So then what is the default passphrase? If the devices are encrypted by default, it's kind of silly that when something goes wrong on the software (or hardware) side, it requires some passphrase that is unknown to the user. This is a major flaw, and it sucks when it happens to unexpecting customers.

Looks like it's supposed to be default_password.http://android.stackexchange.com/que...rk-technically
Once a pattern, PIN, or passcode is set, that also gets set as the key.
