title: 3 Things I Wish I Could Change

thread.text:
First of all, I am loving my Z Force! But there are 3 things I wish I could change or knew how to change.
1. What's the deal with the ringing? Ascending, disappearing, quiet, loud. waves of ringing
2. Sometimes I need to use the keypad and enter numbers while on a phone call and as I try to touch the number with my finger, the screen goes black. The next number it may not. I just keep working until I sneak up on the key pad and am able to hit the key before the Z Force is able to go black. Sort of like my own little "whack a mole" game with my finger and the keypad.
3. When I go to my gmail (I have 5 accounts) and open it up I want ALL my emails to show up for ALL accounts every time without having to go back and highlight "All Inboxes" every single time. There has to be way to fix this.
If you can offer any suggestions or assistance, I would be greatly appreciative. Like I said, I'm so happy to have finally come to the Android side. It's seems to be a lot to learn if your brain has been conditioned to iOS.

replies.text: As I understand it, for some reason - either by design or a bug - the phone does this. I do not believe that there is a fix, yet.The Gmail app does not offer unified in box, but there are a lot of email apps that do, and can connect to a Gmail account if you set up IMAP access in your Gmail settings. One good app that offers unified inbox, access to Gmail accounts, and intelligence to separate important from non-important emails, so you don't get notified about every single crap email message, is Microsoft's Outlook app.

The ascending ring is a "feature" that was introduced to Moto phones with Lollipop. At least it was with my Droid Turbo. I think a specific third party app can address this.That is weird. You might check:
Settings > Display > Sleep
and change it to two minutes (or longer) if it's not already set to that amount. Although your phone should not go to "sleep" if you are using it. But it's worth a try. (Sleep is how long it takes for your device's screen to go black when you're not using it.)

It appears that ringtones and notification alerts are designed to star low then ramp up volume. Sounds like you're getting close to the proximity sensor. The phone probably thinks you're putting it back up to your ear. This is as designed.

title: Flip For Do Not Disturb: a problem

thread.text: When I first started using Flip For Do Not Disturb, it behaved as I expected: the phone would go into Priority Only Allows mode when face down, and then when I turned it face up, Priority Only Allows mode would be terminated. Now it stays in Priority Only Allows mode after I turn it face up. Am I remembering incorrectly, and this is normal behavior?

This is working the way it was before, now. I think what solved this was going back into the Moto app and turning off this feature and then turning it back on. Now Do Not Disturb is turned off when I turn the phone back so it's facing up again.

Well, this undesired behavior is back again this morning. Last night it was charging while faced down. Resetting the phone fails to resolve this. Again, if I turn the phone face down, Do No Disturb turns on, but when turning it face up, Do Not Disturb remains turned on. I imagine sometime later today, this will change back to normal behavior, but don't know why.
And Force Stopping Moto and restarting it, fails to resolve this.
This behavior is not fixed when booting Safe Mode.

Clearing Calendar Data/Cache seems to have solved this. No problem when I woke this morning. Luckily I don't use the phone's built-in Calendar app, and rely on Calengoo for direct syncing with Google Calendar, so I didn't have to do a Google Calendar sync after that. Must have been some rogue event somewhere in the built-in Calendar app.
What made me delete Calendar Data/Cache is that the problem went away everyday at 10am or so. Couldn't find an event in there at 10am, but figured it must be something in Calendar data that's doing this. Support over at the Lenova forum pointed me to a repeating event somewhere.

My phone lately never leaves DND Mode when turning it face up. It used to do that between 10am and 10pm, which was a problem as well, but not as annoying. Now, after turning it face up, I must manually turn DND Mode off, 24 hours a day.
So I have given up on Flip For Do Dot Disturb until the Android 7 update comes out and I install it. Not a big deal. Until this phone, I always had to manually control DND Mode anyway. Love the phone otherwise.

So far, Nougat seems to have fixed this for me. I'll know more in a couple days, since I have occasionally (in the beginning) seen the problem go away for the weekend and then resurface on Monday. Today is Saturday, and I installed the update on Friday.
Problem solved when updating to Nougat.

Hi All!
I picked up my Droid Z Force over the weekend (BF special). Today I made a couple phone calls using my BT headset (for the first time) and the people I called said they could barely hear me. On one call, the other person couldn't hear me at all after a few minutes. I then took off my headset and used the handset itself and people said I sounded way better. The headset I have is a Plantronics Voyager 5200 and that headset worked great with my old phone, a LG G3 so I wouldn't think it was an issue with the headset itself. I also have the phone paired to my "hands free bluetooth" in my Honda Accord so I gave that a try and people still commented they couldn't hear me very well. Granted that isn't a large sample but the common theme I was seeing was people having a hard time hearing me if I was using a BT headphone/speaker. I am running 7.0 as well since I upgraded Android right after I got the phone however I wanted to see if anyone else has experienced anything like this? 
TIA
Might have something to do with advanced calling. It causes some issues with people being able to hear you.

I use my Force in my Nissan all the time for phone calls and it works fine. Calls are never as clear as using it as a handset but that is normal with most car BT systems. They never complain they cant hear me or understand me though.
I havent made any calls with my BT headset, I use it strictly for music and havent needed to make a call or received one!

What is the volume control setting on your Z Force? On my Droid Turbo if I don't have the volume turned up at least 2/3's of the way up, I get complaints that I'm hard to hear.
Have you tried calling your phone, letting it roll over to voice mail and leaving a message, then checking for sound quality?

Thanks for the tips and ideas! I did try disabling the advanced calling but that didn't make a difference. I did turn up all the volumes (media, alarm, ring) plus I did a "network reset" based on something I found online. It's too early to tell, but the one test call I made tonight worked fine. I will need to make some more calls to be sure if it is fixed or not. Thanks again for the suggestions!

Just a quick update
So far, so good. My Plantronics BT headset is working well now. I'm not sure which step fixed it, but I had turned all the volumes up and did a "network reset" which reset both wifi and bluetooth.

title: Nougat update bricked my Moto Z Force 11-30-2016

thread.text:
I installed it this morning when it was shown on my phone as ready to go. Two hours later, the screen flickering on and off every few minutes, I drove over to VZW and they are having a refurbished device sent to me.
Fortunately for me they didn't accept my old Razr HD Maxx as a trade in because of a cracked screen. So at least I have a phone in the meantime. They reactivated the old device.
I still have the Moto Z Force. I'm supposed to send it back when I receive the replacement. I know better than to do an update when they are newly released, but I figured I'd dodge the bullet. No such luck.

replies.text: Not sure what waiting is going to do if it's the same update though.

thread.text: In the event that the update is buggy, as this one apparently is, I would read on the forums posts such as mine. Once it seemed all was cleared up, fixed, then install the update. I don't like beta testing unless I volunteer for it.

replies.text:
That's rare though. 
There usually isn't an update to address anomalies with a previous update (in the case of most Android OS updates).

thread.text: Past few years I recall reading about updates on the Razr, and what not, where the update bricked the device. Doing a google search for nougat update this morning showed many had problems like mine with their Nexus devices following a nougat update a couple of months ago. I should have googled first and updated later, if at all.

replies.text: What happens with one device has no effect on another device. Each device has a specific update, and the reports of bricked devices from this update are rare (frankly, I think that yours is the only one I've seen on this forum.) If there was a widespread issue, there would have been reports all over this forum. I think that you were just unlucky.

I totally agree! This is the first instance I've heard of anyone making this claim. It would be better not to create posts like this without more data to back it up. It gives the readers here a false impression by warning of a widespread issue as if there's reason for all of us to be concerned, especially for those who are still mulling over the possibility of going through with the update. If I were to follow the same logic based on my personal impression of the new software, I'd come to this forum imploring everyone to download it right away based on how smoothly everything is currently operating. But I would never do that because there's always some level of risk involved, and occasionally some people under anomalous circumstances, such as this, end up with bad luck, and I would hate to feel responsible by having that type of influence over anyone experiencing that who made the decision even partially because of me or my advice. But in this case, this will influence people not to download the software and miss out on what many are enjoying and perceive as benefits. If you have an issue, please come here to ask for help and of course feel free to question whether others are experiencing something similar, but don't report problems as if they're widespread unless you have good reason to believe it's not isolated, which does not seem to be the reality at all with this update on this particular phone.
If an update bricks your phone, I'd expect you to make a thread about it here.

Agreed, it's the ideal place to come; and having frustrations is totally justified. I certainly would be royally dismayed myself. 
I only took issue with the fact that his grievances seemed to imply it was an issue with the software as opposed to a more isolated issue with his particular phone. On a forum with many visitors looking for sound advice and information, I wouldn't want anyone to draw false conclusions and be fearful of future updates based on one experience and generalized speculation. Given how well this update has apparently faired with the vast majority of users, I take issue with cautioning other users in the broader sense by attributing the problem to something more systemic the way that he did, especially considering there doesn't seem to be a lot of evidence to support that. At the same time, I apologize if the tone of my post was harsh and insensitive to someone who clearly is frustrated, had a very negative personal experience and has absolutely every right to write about it, even if it's just for the sake of griping.
Just going by the title, it was clear to me that it was the OP's particular device.

thread.text: I had a similar issue caused by an incompatible 3rd party app. Based on timing of the crash, I was able to guess which app, boot in safe mode, and uninstall. Solid for at least a week now, without the problematic app.

thread.text: It stinks when you install an update and it ruins a previously good phone. It seems like this update for the vast majority of people has been fine, but I'd you're one of the unlucky ones your failure percentage is 100%. Still good to share as it's a valid experience.

No bugs for me and I installed the day it came out and have had the phone a while. I use Swiftkey as well as my only keyboard with no issues. I do normally wait for updates as they can be buggy but 7.0 made a huge difference on my 5x so I jumped when it showed up for the Z Force. My 5x was a like a new, nicer phone after 7.0. The Z Force wasnt as drastic but it is still butter smooth and my BT headphones actually connect more reliably.

My Z Force got the Nougat update this week and I've noticed some odd behaviors, some things I've found work-arounds, other things I'm stumped. So I was thinking of making a thread and seeing if others have found odd behaviors and work-arounds.
1. The phone vibrates every time I unlock it, whether I have a pin, finger print, swipe, or Smart Lock.
2. Secure Settings (tasker plug-in) no longer works, so disarming the pin/fingerprint while on my home wifi doesn't work. I don't like how Smart Lock requires GPS to be on for it to recognize that I'm home.
3. The display sizes are different now in the display settings, I thought there were 5 levels before, but now only 3. I've noticed that some apps won't even open unless I'm on the 'small' setting.
4. OfficeSuite spreadsheets go into this really bad ongoing flickering when trying to enter text into a cell with a keyboard.
5. Most apps in multiwindow mode force the screen to be split 50%/50%. A couple will let you go 75%/25%, but not nearly I was hoping for.
If anyone has a solution to any of these or have other things that don't seem quite right, let us know!
Thanks

replies.text: I don't have any solutions, unfortunately, but hope others can help with these.

thread.text:
Found a couple more:
6. Officesuite doesn't let me open or save csv files.
7. When selecting an mp3 file to play from a file explorer (Solid Explorer), PowerAmp no longer is an app to select to play the file.
I've reached out to both app developers/forums to see if any fixes are in the works.

title: Upgraded from iphone, no longer receiving texts from other iphone users

thread.text:
So I just upgraded from the Iphone 5 to the Z force. I'm not able to receive any texts from other iphone users. Their texts are trying to send as an imessage, which is what it would do if I still had an iphone...
How can I start receiving texts from iphone users?

replies.text: Did you disable iMessage before switching?

thread.text: not before switching. I wasn't aware this would be an issue at the time. I've disabled it now, after the issue was present, but I'm still not getting texts from iphone users.
Please see the following article. https://www.google.com/amp/amp.andro...ere-s-easy-fix
When I switched from apple back in 2014 I had to call apple and tell them to remove my number from their servers. Just ridiculous.
Your friends need to change in THEIR phone, your number from imessage to regular SMS. It has nothing to do with you changing your imessage setting.

replies.text:
Please research before giving advice - this is a clear iMessage issue that is going on for many years. The user switching from Apple to Android has to disable iMaessage - not the other users.
For your reference: https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT204270

Not entirely true. The iPhone user should always SELECT "Send as SMS if iMessage is unavailable". This from the iPhone users side ensures that regardless of whether their phone or the other users phone is the issue it goes through. Not relevant to this Android issue per se but in situations where iMessage is unavailable to iPhone user like poor service areas, their messages should go through as SMS anyway. But I digress. Yes, as you said it is the new Android owners responsibility to to remove iMessage correctly but also requires old messages to be deleted and new threads to be started.

Guess you missed the part that stated: because they're still being sent as iMessage. So, like I said. If the "sender" will simply change the phone number setting imessage to sms, it immediately solves the issue.

thread.text: Right, Apple added that web page to remove your phone number from iMessage a year or two ago. Before then it was really a pain in the neck.
So the issue is fixed. It took about 12 hours from the point of me turning off imessage from my old iphone until it went into effect.

Google "deregister iMessage"
Click on the Apple Self Solve site
Scroll down and enter your phone number
You'll get text with a code
Enter that in the website 
Your phone number will be deregistered. 
Tell friends to delete threads and start new convos with you

I just got my new Z Force. I am having trouble staying connected to a specific WIFI Access point that I use everyday.
This is the device: 300Mbps Wireless N Access Point - TP-Link (version 2) 
The Z connects and can browse the web fine. However, after a few mins, the WIFI shows "Connected, No Internet" then connects again. I have "Always keep WIFI on during sleep" and I do not have "Avoid bad WIFI conneections" checked. This happens if I am right next to the router. 
Steps I have tried:Add/Remove network from the ZUpdate router access point firmwareRebooted router
Other devices connect to this Access point just fine. It is the Z having issues. The Z can connect fine to my home wifi and other access points I tried out and about (Starbucks, etc).
Is there anything else I am missing? Any Ideas?
I suspect a router issue - be sure it's running the latest firmware & see if that helps.

2.4 GHz or 5 GHz? Which channel? If you change the channel, does that make it work better? If it's not working on 2.4 GHz, does it work on 5 (or vice versa)?
If 2.4 GHz, does turning off Bluetooth make it work better?
BTW, you say that it is a router that you access every day, but you also say that home WiFi is fine, so this is not at home? Does that mean that you don't have the ability to make these changes?

replies.text:
This is an AP at my office that I installed and also manage it. It is 2.4GHz. 5GHz is not an option. 
Tomorrow I will test:Turning off BluetoothChanging the channel
Thanks for the tips.

thread.text:
I just looked at the web site for this router. A few other things to look at that *might* help, if those didn't help:
- which security are you using? WPA or WPA2? If it's WPA, does switching to WPA2 help?
- which mode? Is this a router, access point only, bridge with AP, or repeater?

We use this as an Access Point I just ran some test.Bluetooth On/Off - No differenceChanging channels, no differenceI use WPA2. I tried WPA, no difference
Thank you for all your help. It could be that I have a defective Z Force. I have to call Best Buy and see my exchange options.

replies.text: If this is the sole WiFi connection you have a problem with it's almost certainly not an issue with the phone. Time & time again this is a problem created by a new device with the latest radios trying to connect with outdated routers/AP's or outdated firmware.
At my office, other new iPhones, laptops, and tablets connect fine to the Access Point. I updated the firmware on the AP, as well.

A few other things to play with (I'd try these one at a time):
Wireless encryption: Automatic, TKIP, or AES? If it's not AES (on WPA2), does changing to that help?
Channel width: This shouldn't matter, but does changing this help?
Max Transmit rate: This shouldn't matter, but does changing from 300 MHz help?
You're not using any security options like hiding the SSID, or MAC filtering? Are you using VLANs at all? Is this the only access point, or do you have more than one, all set to the same SSID, so that you can roam between them?
Have you tried deleting the SSID from the phone and re-connecting again? (Again, that shouldn't make a difference, but maybe worth a try anyway.)
(Just curious - is it possible to purchase something else and replace the access point if all else fails?)
This is what I am leaning to. I tried all the other suggestions. This is a very simple setup WIFI-wise.

thread.text: Well, it is definitely the phone. I bought a brand new Netgear access point. AC1200. Every device can use it but the Z-Force

I know that this would be a pain in the neck to change, but do you have a weird SSID for this AP? I'm wondering if the ZF has some weird bug with some SSID name pattern. (Space in the SSID? Non-alphabetic character?)
The other idea is to use some sort of WiFi scanning app (on a device that connects to the AP without dropping the connection) to see if the SSID is being rebroadcast by some device that isn't set up to share the network or something. (So, your phone is reconnecting to it and cannot get a route to the internet.)
Of course, it surely could be the phone, but you said you're not having issues with other APs, so it just sounds like something is fishy. I hope you solve it!
Scanning app for Android: https://play.google.com/store/apps/d....wifi.analyzer
Windows (I'm not a Windows user, but this looks like it would be fine): http://forums.androidcentral.com/e?l...token=YRwb3W_j
MacOS has one built in: How To Access The Wi-Fi Scanner In Mac OS X El Capitan - Let's Talk Tech

Thanks for all the tips. I really appreciate it. 
I have been using WIFI Analyzer. Everything looks good. I changed SSID's, as well. Some with underscores, some without. Some with numbers, some without. I have a unique SSID. 
I have a Droid MAXX, and iPhone 4 or 5 (small one) on my desk with the Z Force for testing. 2 out of the 3 work great on the old Access Point and the new one I just bought.
It must be the phone...

title: AT&T SIM in Moto Z Force

thread.text:
If I am not mistaken, Verizon Phones are unlocked and an AT&T SIM card should work correct?
That said, how are updates handled? By IMEI correct? So if and when Verizon pushes an update, a Z Force Droid on AT&T should still get the update, correct?

replies.text: Yep. Verizon doesn't push updates - Motorola does.
Cool and good to know.

thread.text: Possibly. If not you can always take the sim out and check for update over wifi. That would work. Something like this happen with the Moto X Pure Edition where cdma carriers got marshmallow first then GSM carriers got it but the work around was to check for update over wifi

replies.text: Thanks...will give it a try...we are ending up with a spare Z-Force and going to let an AT&T user give it a shot...

thread.text: Verified...AT&T SIM works perfectly in a Moto Z Force. You will get two NOT A VERIZON SIM messages when you reboot but that's it.
source? has it always been this way?

replies.text: I used to have sources, but can't find them at the moment. For a carrier-proprietary phone like the Droids, Verizon must approve an update in their testing labs. Then they give the go-ahead to Motorola (or whichever OEM) to actually start pushing the update. It's usually pushed out to a small percentage of IMEI numbers randomly the first few days, then gets pushed to more, then is finally available to every IMEI to pull at any time.

thread.text:
Yeah. Cinemablend was doing that to me for a while. It's annoying. Freaked me out at first, but realized it was spamming me.
Fun thing is I know carrier sales reps who say people come in with all these antivirus apps because of ads like this that take them to the store to download that crap.
nothing here yet

They are praying on people's inexperience with Android... Android DOES have malware, but how an Android device is compromised is far far different than a windows desktop system... the simple act of going to an infected page on a desktop can wreak havoc on things. But on Android, everything is so compartmentalized that this is either impossible or extremely difficult to pull off. I haven't heard of any instance where a browser page has infected an Android device with malware... To infect a newer Android device, you really need to sort of trick the user into installing an app, and even then the damage is limited unless the person has in some fashion compromised their phone's security measures (such as rooting a phone and not paying attention to what they install).

title: Good idea to do factory reset?

thread.text: As much as I hate doing that...is it recommended after a software update?
Personally, unless you are experiencing issues i don't see a reason to perform a factory reset.
Usually no - the update deletes any files it's going to replace. Clearing the system cache, though (in Recovery), is a good idea.

replies.text: Thanks I did that just now!

thread.text:
Actually the update deletes the cache. That's why it rebuilds on first boot.
I found this to be the best update I've experienced. I absolutely needed to do one after each update on my LGs.

replies.text:
Just wondering -- do you know that for certain? I ask because I've seen issues crop up after system updates that improved after a cache partition wipe.
What you're referring to sounds like the Dalvik cache, which makes sense: http://www.urtech.ca/2015/09/solved-...the-galaxy-s6/. But does it apply to the system cache partition as well?

I love Blue Mail . . Personal opinion of course . . .
If you use your Gmail account you should use Inbox. It is far superior to the Gmail app

replies.text: FWIW, there are a few things that the stock Gmail app can do that the InBox app cannot - mark an email that you've read as unread; star a conversation; mute a conversation. It also seems more flexible about replying to messages. I use InBox for almost everything, but I do use the stock Gmail app for things like that.

thread.text: I have been using Maildroid for a while. Works well with multiple accounts (6)

Nine for Exchange
Aqua Mail for Gmail (imap sync)
Not only do these work great, but they both have Calibri font and email headers that look identical to your desktop Microsoft Outlook. So your phone emails will look professional as if coming from your work computer.
Google Inbox

My biggest problem with using any other app than Gmail or InBox is GMail's category inbox - Primary, Social, Promotions, Updates, and Forums. I have InBox set to alert me only with Primary and the rest - which Gmail does a fantastic (actually, perfect) job with sorting out for me - are all not worth being reminded of every time I receive one.
Again, Outlook comes closest with its Focused vs. Other mailboxes. Again, it learns what is critical/important over time. What I love about InBox (and Outlook), in addition, is the ability to "snooze" a message to come back later / tomorrow / this weekend / next week / whenever I want. I' couldn't manage with any other email app without these features.

thread.text:
Moto is using a very lightly skinned stock interface. So it uses google apps rather than its own. Google calendar. Google calculated. Google clock. Etc.
For the gallery it is the photos app.

Posted via the Android Central App

For some reason they didn't include the Moto gallery app in this build, even though it's on the G4. I personally can't find Moto's app in the Play store from this phone, but I guess YMMV. But I really like their app for its custom photo-roll videos and built in editor (more options than Google Photos and even Snapseed, including the ability to export at a different size).
If you Google around, someone liberated the apk for Moto Gallery from the G4 and posted it. I tried a bunch of Moto Gallery apks out there on the various apk archive sites, and none of them worked. But the G4 gallery did. No problems so far.
The Google app will let you backup your photos online. Unlimited at a slight reduced compression for free. A good way to never lose your photos.

replies.text: You get that merely from having the Photos app installed and backups on. You can have any other gallery, camera, or photo-editing app installed at the same time with no conflicts. So it isn't a question of "one of the other," unless you chose to disable Photos or never log into it.
There's an offer with the Moto Zs (and Moto Gs) where full res/no compression won't take up Drive space for two years.
Really? How do you access this? And then what happens in 2 years? You're screwed because you have your whole Drive taken up by your photos and are forced to pay for more space.

http://forums.androidcentral.com/e?l...token=L12UOw16
Just turn it on in Google Photos.
I believe it's just like any other Google Drive promotion - if you exceed your limit at the end of the promotion, you have to either delete or buy Drive space.

thread.text:
I use Google photos and Amazon photos there are free and automatic backup. Both work great
Posted via the Android Central App

OK, so I'm not sure if it and app, and its not terrible, but in the past few weeks the battery seems to be losing power more quickly. I used to be able to leave it at night and it would drop 10-20%, not its dropping about 40%. I'm also using 10-15% more during the day. Any suggestions? If I have to do a factory reset, how do I back up my texts? Thanks.

Seeing some battery stats might be helpful. Charge up to 100%, then let it drain to 20-30% with normal usage, without charging in between. Then show us:
1. The main Settings>Battery screen.
2. The fullscreen battery graph screen (which shows Awake time and Cell Signal Strength).
3. The Screen category (to see total Screen On time).
4. The Cell Standby category, if present (to see Time Without Signal).http://forums.androidcentral.com/gen...d-central.html
You might have to install a 3rd party battery monitor, like GSam Battery Monitor, to get the Cell Signal Strength graph.

I've also noticed that my Z Force has been draining battery somewhat quickly while in my pocket. Not anything crazy, but 2-3% per hour with virtually no use. I thought this used to be more like 1%. What are your experiences with standby battery? 
As an aside, Doze is working because I lost only 3% overnight. Is it possible the Z Force just isn't that well optimized for background activity?

I bought a z force two weeks ago and so far I love it. It's fast, and coming from a S5 I have got no complaints. 
However I have noticed last few days that my battery drains overnight while in standby. Last night it was almost 18%, day before it was 10%. It wasn't like that before. 
Initially I thought it was my wifi but when I looked in GSam Battery Monitor I can see the issue could be with my screentime. 
If you look at the screenshots you will see that the battery discharge % while off is higher then while on. Is this normal? Is anyone else seeing this? 
I restarted my phone recently as well prior to the battery drains. Also applied the latest updates. 
any thoughts? really appreciate it. 
Karan

I don't know much about whether GSAM stats are right or wrong, but I will say this: plug in your phone to charge while you are sleeping. If anybody ever told you that it was better to deeply discharge your battery before recharging, or that it was bad for your battery to leave it plugged in while fully charged, they were wrong. That way you start each day with a fully charged battery and you don't have to worry about any discharge during the night.

Thank you for your response. I agree that I should be charging the phone overnight but it still does not help me understand why the battery drains when the display is off. 
Even now it's over 54% discharge while off.
All the usual things to try, any rogue apps, have you cleared the system cache? Hopefully you won't have to do a full factory data reset.
Yea thats one of the things on my list to try. Just want to see if there are others who have experienced this and have a different approach.

thread.text: I left my home and went out for about 7 1/2 hours last evening. I turned WiFi off since I was out and about. When I returned home, the battery stats showed WiFi used 5% of the battery and was running the entire time. Does anyone know why this may be the case?
Go to Settings>Location, tap Menu, then Scanning, and make sure Wi-fi Scanning is turned off. (On some phones, it might be called "Improve Accuracy," and it might be in the Settings>Wi-fi​ menu.)

replies.text:
Thanks, I will try this. It is a bit different on the Z. There are 3 options in Settings / Location: :High AccuracyBattery SavingDevice Only
I will try "Device Only". However, if I turn WiFi off, shouldn't it be "off" in all cases?

thread.text: Actually, I'm talking about something a little deeper. On that screen, tap the Menu button and look for Wi-fi Scanning in either the Advanced menu, or as its own setting.

FWIW, the last few Droid phones ignored the wifi scanning entry in settings - they kept the WiFi radio on. I'm sure it's kept on for rapid location services locking (the "a" for "assisted" in "a-GPS" - GPS radios can take some time to lock into three satellites) and better battery life (GPS uses a lot more for location). My guess is that Moto designers decided to keep the radio on for that, and turning the radio "off" merely turns off connecting to access points. (I'm sure that airplane mode turns it off off, though obviously that's not an answer for on the go.)
I suppose you can try toggling WiFi off, then airplane mode on and off, and see if the WiFi radio stays off that way.
See http://forums.androidcentral.com/mot...-turn-off.html and http://forums.androidcentral.com/mot...2-battery.html for issues with the T2 that sound similar to this....

title: use sd card as portable or internal storage?

thread.text: Which is better?

Portable is better for many reasons. Formatting to internal storage is no cure for low memory issues, SD cards are slow and will make your phone laggy, they fail frequently and as the data is encrypted there is little chance of recovery. Factory rest your device and the encryption key generated by your phone changes so you lose access. As portable storage, they are not secure.
Hi folks. I have the 256 GB card from the Samsung Promotion so I figured I would use it as Internal storage and so far so good.
Just remember - you can't save anything to the "SD card" - you don't have one any more. (Logically, the SD card is just "storage" - the same as internal storage.)

replies.text: Yes thanks I'm aware.

thread.text: Z Force isn't considered because it's a Verizon exclusive.

replies.text: Are you sure? I thought there was a Moto Z Force, which could be used on several carriers, and the Moto Z Force Droid, which was Verizon exclusive.

There are 5 Moto Zs: Moto Z Play, Moto Z Play DROID, Moto Z, Moto Z DROID, and Moto Z Force Droid. 
There is no non-Droid Moto Z Force.

The Moto Z Force can be used on other carriers, although you might be missing a few bands. But it's still a Verizon exclusive and that perturbs the cognoscenti at several Android websites. So it's not judged on its own merits because of this.

It is definitely optimized for CDMA and Verizon's LTE bands, though, and comes with Verizon-specific apps that you cannot remove and are unnecessary on another carrier. The unlocked versions of the Z phones are not that way.
I certainly would not suggest to anybody that they buy a Z Force to use on a carrier other than Verizon, except for an extremely knowledgeable user. Sites like Android Central are probably an even split between technically proficient users and users who are not so curious technically about their phones. AC also has a list of best Verizon phones, and the Droids are on that list.

thread.text: I wouldn't recommend anyone doing that either but it can certainly be done. As for the Verizon specific apps, they can either be deleted or disabled. The bloat argument is now tired and weak.

replies.text:
Almost every non-technical user I know has no idea what disabling an app means, or even that it can be done, or how. Bring this phone to T-Mobile and you have apps for Verizon, Verizon Cloud, Verizon Messages, Verizon Navigation, etc., that are useless or redundant. So, it's tired to you, I can get by, but there are ways for Verizon to provide these apps without forcing them onto the full Android build, when a Verizon SIM is inserted into the phone, but Verizon chooses not to do it that way. (Well, none of the carriers do, but we are talking about a Verizon proprietary phone here.) See https://source.android.com/devices/t...g/carrier.html and https://www.androidpit.com/android-5-0-lollipop-apps (see update at the bottom.)
If there was even a Z Force version specific to AT&T, T-Mobile and/or Sprint, like the Samsung Galaxy phones, I bet the phone would be listed more often as a top phone.

title: Cable, Charger and Screen Protector Questions

thread.text:
My 2 Z Forces (black and white) have been shipped and on their way. I couldn't pass up the "buy one-get one free" from Verizon.
This USB-C thing confuses me and I hope you can help me understand. I understand it's just a type of cable that allows you to simply insert without having an up or down side. I'm good here. But if I want to be able to "Turbo Charge" my Z Force do I need a USB-C cable with USB-C connector on both ends? OR can I keep on using my current chargers (auto and night stand) with the regular USB ports and use a cable with the regular USB on one end with the USB-C on the phone end and still get "turbo charging"?
In other words, what is the very best cable I can buy to guarantee the quickest charge? Does it have to be USB-C on both ends to maximize charge rate?
What do you use on your night stand to charge and hold the phone as a night time clock? Do you use a cradle of some sort? 
What is the best car charger you have found that works the best for the Z Force and iPad/iPhones?
I was told that buying a tempered glass protector was a waste of money because the Z Force has the shatterproof glass. "They" said to just purchase a flexible scratch protector for the front. Is this true?

First, you have to be careful about USB-C cables, though things are better now than they were. See https://www.google.com/amp/s/amp.the...s-usb-c-cables
Yes, there are cables that have a USB type A connector (the kind found on almost every computer these days) on one end and a USB-C connector on the other. For charging, you really are best off using the cable and charger that shipped with the phone. 
When it comes to buying cables, I find that Anker makes cables that are reliable, long-living and compliant. I'm not sure about car chargers in particular, but I would trust one made by Anker, and you can find them easily on Amazon.

I am definitely gonna use the chargers that come with the phones. I guess I'm more concerned about the car chargers. I realize my computer hookups will have the USB A on one end. Since I already have USB A car chargers, I was wondering if I should purchase new car chargers with the USB-C connector hook ups?
From what I have read, Anker seems to be the "best" overall cable company. 
Thank you for your advice!

replies.text: on the verizon wireless website they sell a fast car charger with a usb c connection, that is waht I use

thread.text: Definitely buy the Flex Glass Screen Protector from Verizon. Just because the phone's screen is shatterproof doesn't mean it's not scratch proof. It actually scratches quite easily. The Flex Glass is the only one I've found that will lay down without any bubbles. The phone comes with a turbo charger which I use for the bedroom. Buy an Anker USB C cable for use in the car.

replies.text:
The Anker C cable, is it USB on one end and USB-c on the other? Did you buy a car charger with just USB-C ports?
Thanks for your advice!

thread.text:
It took me about 2 weeks to find charger setups that worked for me. 
1. The only way I've ever been able to have it say Turbo charging is using USB-C to USB-C cables. It might only be charging at 300 mah but still says Turbo. 
2. I actually get faster charging speeds using USB A to USB C cables with a USB 2 and 3 fast chargers. 
3. Vehicle charging I use USB A to micro usb cables with Choetech micro usb to USB C adapters. The chargers I have been using are various 2.0 fast chargers. 
I do have the Verizon car charger USB C. But hardly use it. I also have the Verizon USB C charger for home but it's usually in my work bag. 
Your mileage may vary. These are just what I've found that works for me. I had a bunch of micro usb cables and find the little connectors work pretty much everywhere. But be sure you read reviews. The first set I ordered didn't work.

This is a bit redundant from what others have said, but just a review:
Included charger (with non-removable cable): fastest charging - no aftermarket charger so far seems to be capable of matching it. Maybe a Macbook USB-C charger... maybe.
Aftermarket USB-C charger with proper cable (Type-C to Type-C): Fast charging, "turbo charging"
Any USB-A charger with USB-A to USB-C cable: can be somewhat fast to charge, but will not be labeled as "turbo charging". Same goes for any micro-usb to USB-C adapters.
As far as screen protectors go, the Verizon flexible glass screen protector is pretty great

title: Straight Talk and Moto Z Force?

thread.text: Is anyone using Straight Talk on their Moto Z Force? Is everything working fine?

replies.text: I don't know for sure, but I would imagine you will need to get Verizon to unlock the device for use on another carrier. It'll work if unlocked; however, you may not be able to take complete advantage of the data speeds may not be fully supported. I checked Straight Talk T-Mobile and some bands are missing. You may need to verify with AT&T's network to see what's supported.

Well Straight Talk also uses Verizon towers and I am currently using a Droid Maxx that is not unlocked and it works fine. Yes I think the speeds are a little slower. I am pretty sure it should work but I just wanted to see if anyone else is doing it.

thread.text: I know the Droid Maxx was never a carrier locked phone, in spite of being a carrier exclusive model. I would imagine the same is likely true for the Zf, so it's more a question of compatible radios and what settings have to be set to make it work.

Hello
YES! I am currently using the Moto Z Droid Force with Straight Talk, Verizon sim Bring-Your-Own-Phone (BYOP). It works great. LTE speeds are limited to approx 5Mb/s. Calls, texts, streaming iHeartRadio, watching Netflix all works fine. Also, you will get security updates pushed to your phone. I got an update a few days ago for bug fixes and an android security update. (Software Version: MCL24.246-36. Call audio improvements; Latest Android™ security updates and bug fixes)
Most notably, the Advanced Calling, VoLTE feature will NOT work. This feature, amongst other things, allows users to make calls and surf the internet or use the internet for that matter. For example if your using your phone as a hotspot for your laptop and someone calls, you will have to drop the internet connection in order to talk on the phone, unless that feature is activated via MyVerizon App. Its possible that other Verizon specific feature won't work, but this is the only one that I was concerned with. 
Wifi calling: I haven't tried using this feature. This may be another feature that needs to be activated via MyVerizon App on the phone in order to use it. 
To activate you must have a new BYOP sim card from straight talk. You can order the sim from straighttalk.com, walmart.com or go into walmart. I believe if you buy it on the Walmart.com or StraightTalk.com sites you can get the sim for a dollar plus shipping. But if you got into Walmart they bundle the BYOP kit (includes sims for all carriers) but its $15 plus the plan you want ($45 plan or $55 plan). For example, if you want the $45 - 5 GB plan, its $59.99 for activation sim and 30 day plan. (I don't like to wait so I opted for the in-store kit)

thread.text: Is there a default app or just google photos?
Just Google photos by default but I use QuickPic (from Google Play Store). It's super fast and simple. I prefer it over Google photos.
It seems that we get the same deal as the Pixel... unlimited uploads of high quality?

Nope. You get Unlimited photos at high quality for all devices. Pixel phones get unlimited FULL QUALITY backups. The first gets compressed by Google to the equivalent of a picture about 6.5MP I believe, so if you take a 16MP picture, Google will store a resized, recompressed version. For Pixel users, they get full, original file back ups, so their pictures won't get resized or recompressed. 
You can still have that in Photos (the full back up thing), but unlike for Pixel users, yours would count against your Drive storage quota.

Actually, I had to look this up. Very good point here and I'm going to include a screen shot from Google support. 
It looks as if the 21 mp photos are being compressed to about the quality of a 16 mp camera if I'm understanding this correctly. Funny thing is, the original quality of the Pixel XL is a 12.3 mp file. So, are we getting unlimited larger/better photos than the Pixel XL?

replies.text: Wow could be lol

thread.text: Mine had full quality unlimited for 2 full years
I have the same. What happens after 2 years?

replies.text: They'll count against your Drive storage.

This ^... but only if you keep the 'original file' back up option. After the two years you can switch to 'High Quality' and get re-compressed versions still stored for free without counting against your quota. 
What I don't know, though, is what happens to pictures you backed up while in the Full Resolution promo period. Ry, do you know if those files will then suddenly count against your quota or if only what is backed up after the promo ends will?
As far as I know, the full resolution backups will count against your quota when the promo ends. You'll either have to switch them to high-quality or delete them to get the space back.

thread.text: Do y'all have any advice on starting up? Maybe I should ask this in a general forum.

Welcome to Android Central! Check out my Getting Started guide (but please pardon the dust -- I'm in the process of updating it from last year, when Lollipop was the latest OS!)
Regarding bloatware -- if you never use it, you can usually Disable it in the Settings>Apps menu. Select the app there, then tap the Disable button. This will uninstall any updates to it (reverting it to the factory version), and then prevent the system from opening it. Although you can't completely remove it, you can at least prevent it from updating (which typically makes the app larger). And since the system will never open it, it won't cause any potential interference with the system or any other app.

title: "Your device has failed verification and may not work properly" message upon boot

thread.text:
On October 30th, I purchased a brand new Verizon Moto Z Force Droid smartphone. The first thing I did after I charged it and powered it on was check for system/Android updates. It found one, which seemed to install correctly. After that, I checked for updates again, and it found a second update. That update failed to install on the first attempt. On the second attempt (to install the second system update), it succeeded. Ever since then though, I have a some sort of "bootloader" error, every time I power on the smartphone, that says: "your device has failed verification and may not work properly." Further, I can not use the "Android Pay" app on the device, because it says my device "can not be verified" (or something to that effect).
Also, I am not the only person having this exact problem with the Moto Z Force Droid smartphone: https://forums.lenovo.com/t5/Moto-Z-...k/td-p/3438410
Please help me fix this (seemingly) significant problem. Thank you in advance!
From what I can tell it's a Marshmallow thing that is not specific to this phone. One plus 3 folks had it too....can you factory reset?

title: Fingerprint Sensor Question--Pulling Phone Out of Pocket

thread.text:
As of right now I'm considering the Z Force or Pixel XL as my new phone. One thing I really want in a new phone is a fingerprint sensor. The number one advantage I see is the ability to reach into my pocket, cover the fingerprint sensor and pull it out of my pocket unlocked and ready to use. A couple of questions:
1. Is this technique possible? Can I cover the sensor with my finger/thumb in the pocket and pull out the phone ready to use?
2. Fingerprint sensor on the front of phone or back of phone would be best for this technique? (Note: I always place my phone in pocket with phone's screen facing my leg and top of phone goes into pocket first. It seems to me with this pocket placement the rear fingerprint sensor would be better.)
3. Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of front and rear fingerprint sensor placement.
4. What else do you use fingerprint sensor for beside locking/unlocking the phone?

replies.text: That's up to you. I know that people on this forum have said that they like to use the phone laying on a table, so in order to unlock with fingerprint, they'd first have to pick up the Pixel. If that's not you, it's irrelevant as a concern.Android Pay. Apps can use fingerprint to unlock rather than ask you to enter a password (Dropbox, Lastpass, Authy are examples of apps like this, where they allow you to set a PIN security when they app has been unlocked after boot but can use your fingerprint to unlock the app.)

I'm trying to think of a reason I would unlock my phone if I wasn't going to pick it up. With the Z Force a wave of the hand will get me my notifications. Maybe voice commands? I know with my Turbo is always listening. Is this not true with Z Force? (I know you have to say OK Google with the Z.)Thanks for the info.

I also do not use my phone that way. It is almost always in my hand. Maybe one time in a few hundred I have the phone sitting on some sort of surface and scroll through content. (For those few times, I could probably get by tapping out a PIN number.)

Ways I use my phone without picking it up (and therefore like the front sensor):
- reading news while eating (scroll with my knuckle)
- read an email while the phone is on a stand
- glance at something in more detail than the lockscreen provides, but without picking it up (usually when it's sitting on my desk)
I don't usually need to use the fingerprint sensor with voice commands, as I've set up trusted places where I most often would use voice commands (car, home, office).
Yes, it does the always listening (and offers custom phrase support via the Moto app).

thread.text:
I prefer the sensor on the back much more than the front. Especially for the simultaneous pull out of pocket and unlock move that you had mentioned. Also, I feel like I always have to move my hand more and awkwardly to active the front sensor versus shifting my index finger a smidge for the rear.
Even laying on a table activating the front sensor is awkward so I always just use the power button and pin the unlock if my phone is laying on something.
FWIW, I went from 6P - Z Force - Pixel XL.

replies.text:
Thanks for your input on the fingerprint sensor.

title: Pro's & Con's of using SD Card as internal

thread.text: Just curious of what everyone's opinion is on using the SD Card as internal storage. I started out just using it as storage, but, recently changed it to internal storage, using a samsung 128GB evo+ which is one of the faster cards out there. When setting up I got a message that said "This Samsung SD Card seems slow you might see lag or studdering when using certain apps". If this card is not fast enough, which one is? I really haven't noticed any lag, just curious of how many are using SD Card as internal, what card you are using, and what the pros and cons are in your opinion.

Using it as internal allows for installing apps to it. But those apps won't run as fast as they would on internal, and can lag. It can also screw with your apps if the card dies.
I don't expect to need more than the 32gb internal for apps, so I have my Google Photos and Google music set to store their media files on the SD card, which is most of what usually eats up my storage space. 128gb card should allow for a lot of music, photos, and video while keeping free space on internal memory.

Unless you have a phone with a small amount of storage (e.g, 4, 8, or 16 GB phone), IMO there are no pros, just cons. It's almost a kludge. The SD card could fail - there goes your apps and data. If your phone fails and you have to exchange it for a new device, you can't bring the SD card over with your data - it is encrypted to just the phone that it was created on. This, of course, is the same with internal storage on the device - but - if you store music, photos, videos, etc., or portable storage, it is just that (portable) - the data can be moved over to another phone.

As mentioned it may run slower, I haven't experienced that but it does bench slower.
Even with my sdcard as internal, the actual internal is using just as much space.
Here is a good article from Jerry. Inside Marshmallow: Adoptable storage | Android Central
I put a 64g one in mine and adopted it. Its a bit slower but not terribly so.

I just took advantage of the "Buy One, Second One 50% Off" promotion from Verizon to upgrade from the Turbo 2 for myself, and from the Samsung Galaxy S5 for my daughter in law. 
Here's what I immediately noticed compared to the Turbo 2:
1. The screen shows a purer white and is measurably brighter.
2. The reduction in width and thickness makes it more comfortable to hold for extended periods. The small differences in weight (lighter) and length (longer) are not significant.
3. The fingerprint reader is extremely useful, convenient, and accurate.
4. Battery life appears to be slightly better, but I haven't had the phone long enough to confirm.
I do suggest the Verizon glass screen protector which went on bubble-free.
Also, the Tech21 Impact Clear Case for Moto Z Force Droid - Clear is extremely thin and the slightest amount of pressure from your fingers gives you an excellent non-slip grip. I would have preferred a choice of color other than clear.
The old Turbo 2 is now my son's cell phone, meaning we are all a shatter proof family (the wife is very happy with her old flip-phone).

Glad to hear that you are enjoying your new Z Force phone. I put the Verizon glass screen protector on as well. I'm using a flexible vinyl shell (not sure what brand) that I can easily remove when I want to use a mod. So far I have the Incipio battery mod and the JBL speaker mod.

thread.text:
Do you think you're shortening the life of your battery by keeping it at a constant 80% charge from the battery pack? 
It would seem that way to me as it would mean that after the first 20% is used by your battery it would stay in constant charge to maintain 80%.
Posted via the Android Central App

replies.text: Haven't really thought of that. Only had it a few days now. But I still haven't charged it. It's been over 2 days now. I plan to drain it then charge again. But this time run without the battery mod to see how it performs. The battery mod got me an extra 24 hours.

No! It's much better for the phone's battery to be held at that level with a low power, low heat trickle charge than a high heat, high amp, high voltage turbo charge. Plus when the battery in the mod gets worse, you can buy another mod - something you can't do with the phone's internal battery.

Thought I'd share this in case anyone else would find it useful.
I picked up the inta-share projector, but wanted to be able to use it for meetings/etc as well as projecting Netflix on the wall...
Nothing I found on Motorola information, or at the local store (two employees there have the insta-share, but had never tried to use it with a computer) was any help.
So I went on a search..
After trying several of the ones I found on App Store (there are 1000's more to send your phone screen TO the pc, but pc TO phone...not so much), I found most of them either dont work at all (crash the app on Windows 10 as soon as the phone connects, even though they insist its compatible), or are shaky in performance and have varying costs, usually around $6-$9, with at least one not telling you WHAT it costs anywhere on the play store or its web site... just a 'buy' button (?!)
Anyway, I came across 'Spacedesk'. It is a Beta program (and free), but I have had no problems with it so far.
You install a small app on the computer (I have it on a Surface Pro64 and an Asus T100TAF, both running the latest Windows 10), it runs in the background.
You install the client on the phone (I have it on the Z Force and my Nexus7(2013) tablet). When you are connected to the same WIFI, the Android side will show the available 'server' IP addresses. Select the one you want to use and thats it. You can configure the android to be the 'monitor 2', and PowerPoint picked it up and used it as the presentation display perfectly.
Spacedesk also (it started out with this purpose) will allow you to use a second PC as a second monitor for your computer. So if you have an extra computer/monitor, but your pc only has one monitor plug, you can still get dual monitors.
If you have the insta-share, this definitely makes it more worth the price and much more useful.
My only suggestion so far on this app, is if they can make it connect thru Bluetooth, so you can do presentations on the insta-share without having to be around a WIFI that you can connect to.https://play.google.com/store/apps/d...spacedesk.beta
Cool app find man! I tried it out (not with the projector) with the Z and my desktop! Kinda cool!
Great find! Going to give this a try.
I am having an issue with OTG storage where as only the stock file manager sees the OTG sd card, I use ES file explorer pro and this does not detect the OTG storage. Any ideas why this is?

The first time you insert mass storage into the phone, there should be a pop up asking for permission to access that particular drive. You then have to 'allow', and select the root directory of the mass storage in order for your app to access the drive. If you don't select the root folder, things might not go as expected. Did you get the permission request and directory select request?

I have a Turbo and did not move to the Turbo 2 because of my fear of the ShatterShield tech. Everything I have read indicates that the top layer of the screen is plastic and scratches easily. My Turbo is naked and has never been scratched. I feel that it is odd to expect to put a glass screen protector on top of the ShatterShield tech just to stop it from scratching.

thread.text:

- use it naked & replace the shattershield top lens (~$30) whenever it gets bad enough to bother you. If you're deeply OCD this could get pricey.
- throw on your preferred screen protector. Some of the glass ones cover the full screen, and it's hard to tell they're there if installed properly.

thread.text:
I've had all the Note devices with exception of the original. I never really understood why some people would say they had lag. Then the battery issue happened and I decided to take a look at something from someone other than Samsung. Man I'm glad I did.
Your video is a great example of why, after 2 days with the Z Force I decided I wouldn't be going back to the Note. After posting the video and claiming I didn't use much of the features in the note 'like iris scanner and things like that', I realize that I actually did use many of the features and will miss things like multiwindow/penwindow, Gear VR, and spen screen capturing capabilities. Also went from Note 7 to Z Force. Last several phones have been Samsung (S4, S5, Note7, with a Tab3 in the mix)... I didnt realize how much they tamper with the OS! How much is either missing or disabled....
I use Tasker (a LOT.. I have probably a dozen Profiles, and 2 dozen tasks... and that grows all the time) to automate things and make 'mini-apps'. I am amazed at how much just WORKS on the Z Froce that you had to either work around, or just skip, on the Samsung because it wouldnt work 'as OS advertised'. Yeah, there were a few things added to the OS that could be handy, but overall I like the less-adulterated OS on here.
One thing I never can understand is WHY Samsung turns off the ability on the Note 7 to have it format an SD card as part of the overall memory... Part of the rebate we got from Samsung before the recalls ever started, was a 256G mico-SD... The note forced it to be a secondary drive... The Z Force lets you incorporate it into system memory and let the OS handle management... To me it seems that would have been a GOOD THING for the Note to do, not something to have removed from the options?!
Faster memory? Faster storage?

Oh yeah, another feature that i use every now and again on Note devices is Miracast. I think it's a little silly that Lenovo/Moto built in Screen Cast function in the Z, but it only works for chromecast, not miracast devices...

title: Does the Battery Mod cause device to get hot?

thread.text: Does the Battery Mod cause device to get hot. I don't have the mod yet and my phone still gets hot during games. So I'm wondering how it will be with the mod? I'm considering picking one up. Thanks in advance for your help.
The mod most likely won't help with cooling. The heat is generated by the screen and mainly the CPU.
I know it won't help, but considering it already gets pretty warm, I'm wondering how bad it is with the mod on it charging while using the phone?

replies.text:
I don't play a lot of games but I use the battery Mod daily, and it definitely does not get as warm as my Turbo 2 used to with my usage habits. I've used it for navigation a decent amount and never noticed any additional warmth, which I have with other phones, especially when plugged in.
Here's an idea of the battery life with the MOD. I'll also warn you that it does throw off the battery stats a little. Phones do not register SOT while charging, so it loses track of SOT while the phone is getting those little bursts. In the screenshot below, I'd say there's about a 2.5 hour gap of SOT missing. So I'd say I can get about 10 hours of SOT over just shy of 2 days without any juice. That will not be the case while gaming I'm sure, but the battery life with the Mod is a real game changer for me. I used to feel that way when I first got the Droid Maxx, but this is next level.

title: Square card reader does work on headphone adapter

thread.text: It occurred to me that I should make sure this works, and it does. It recognizes the square card reader being plugged in & unplugged. I haven't actually run a transaction, but generally devices that don't support it won't recognize the reader.
As long as the port pinout doesn't change, it should be fine.
It also occurs to me that if the Mod platform proves popular, perhaps a Square (or other payment platform) mod would make sense.

It does recognize it, but I just tried running a sale and it was a "no go". The reader makes the clicking sound, and alerts if you unplug it, but it will not recognize the card being swiped.

title: Note 7 Refugee thoughts on new Moto Z Force

thread.text:
Just got a Moto Z Force from Best Buy including the $150 gift card (that I applied towards the device payment plan to minimize my cash outlay for the phone). During the whole N7 fiasco, I was also able to try out the S7 and S7 Edge as well. After playing around with the phone a bit, here are what I think the main Pros/Cons of the Moto Z Force compared to the Note 7.Pros - Very snappy UI. No lag. Turbo charging is really quick. Cons - No waterproofing. No wireless charging. Display not as bright in daylight. Lack of case choices. Larger in hand. 
Same: Camera is comparable in my eyes, battery life, 256GB capable SD card slot, don't care about lack of headphone jack
The main differences boiled down to Performance vs. feature set. I'm not planning on buying any Moto Mods as well. As I got the Moto Z Force with a $150 discount, it seemed like a fair trade and I will definitely keep it until the Note 8 is released. 
Any other opinions from the other refugees?

replies.text:
I picked up the Moto Z Force yesterday and so far it seems like a good phone.
Pros: in addition to the ones Milt K listed, the fingerprint sensor is super fast! Better than crApple and even the Note 7.
Cons: Not as feature rich as the Note 7, camera doesn't focus quite as fast
Still on the fence about the lack of headphone jack. I did pick up the JBL speaker mod since I was refunded the cost for the Note 7 cases I purchased and I was in the market for a new bluetooth speaker anyway
I promised myself that I would give it the full 14 days to evaluate before deciding if I will take it back.

thread.text: I do know there is tons of cases on Amazon. I really suggest buying the incipio power pack with wireless charging. One of the best investments I did for this phone

I'm in the same boat I'm at a point where I'm trying to find something wrong with this phone to justify the reason I bought the Note 7 over it you **** most of the key features but this phone is such a power house I can't put it down

I am also a former noter. Really liking this Moto phone. Cannot find much wrong with it. This cycle will be a nice break from Samsung products. I know its ages old but this device has the feel of my Xoom tablet. By the way still works!

I moved over after the first battery recall on the Note 7. I've had every Note except the original. 
It only took me a couple of days to decide I would not be going back when the Note was re-released. The Z Force is very smooth and fast. I agree it really is a choice between performance and features. For me, I've found that I prefer the performance over the lost features. The only features I've missed so far are all Spen related. 
Wireless charging is nice but not really an issue for me. I have the wireless battery mod but don't use it on a daily basis. Waterproofing is nice but not a deal breaker. A quick Amazon search this morning indicates the case choices are not likely to be an issue any longer. Seems like some of the major manufacturers are joining in at this point. 
The battery life for me is much better on the Z Force. I got the battery mod and have used it one day to see how I liked it, it's awesome but I'll probably only need it on rare occasions. 
I also don't really care about the headphone jack. I use an LG Tone + Bluetooth headset everyday at work and connect Android Auto in my truck. 
I was kinda snobbish and thought if you didn't have a Note device we couldn't really have a meaningful conversation about mobile devices. Lol, little did I know. This whole battery issue has opened my eyes, now the next Note will be something I look at, but not the only choice, like it once was. There are so many options I would never consider before, that's all changed now.

replies.text:
Love the part about being a snob. I too was that dude... Ordered my Moto Z Friday and expect delivery tomorrow (10/17). I think I've seen every YouTube review and read every blog about this phone. Wanted to make sure I got a device I might keep even after the release of the Note 8. After the handling of this last matter there's no guarantees I'll go back to Samsung especially if this phone meets my needs excellent battery life above-average camera and fast performance particularly web browsing. 
Actually getting excited about having this phone in hand! Had been a very loyal Note user but I'm seeing this recent Note debacle as an opportunity to see what else is out there. Going to miss the S pen and not sure what to do with the wireless chargers I have at the house and office lol. Hoping performance outweighs features. thread.text: Thanks for the info

I too am an ex-Note 7 user who feels like an 8 year old kid who has to give the puppy he just got for his birthday! LOL After a few hours watching all of the YouTube videos on the Moto Z, I decided to give this bad boy a try. As a former Droid Incredible, Droid Bionic, Droid Razr M and Droid Turbo owner, I am certainly familiar with this line of devices from Big Red. And after picking one up earlier this afternoon at Best Buy, I can say with confidence that the Moto Z Force is no exception. The device itself is impressive for all the reasons listed above. And the mods are truly a game-changer and done right.
If I have to complain about anything, it will be the little personalization tricks that Samsung includes in their devices since the SG3. I'm talking about the ability to change the font and themes. I know, it sounds silly. But everytime I felt bored with my Sammy device, a quick switch of the font and the menu colors would instantly give me the impression of a new device in my hand. (Hey, that's just my 2 cents!)
PS: In my opinion, I would have loved to see Lenovo put the shatter-proof screen and better camera on the regular, thinner Z model. The addition of a batter mod or style mod would then bring the phone to the perfect thickness. Thoughts?
Lastly, what future mods might we see from manufacturers that would make this phone even better?

replies.text:
You should be able to get most or all of those personalization options through launchers. Takes a little more work to hunt down specific features you miss, but most can be duplicated.There's only a couple that have shown evidence of development (but no confirmation that they'll be finished/released):
- OneCompute mod
- Waterproof "adventure mod"
Lots of people are hoping for things like
- style shell with wireless charging (no battery, just wireless charging for the phone itself), or a smaller/thinner battery mod w/wireless charging
- DAC w/headphone jack mod
- better quality version of the camera mod
Unfortunately, if companies are working on mods, they're being very quiet about it.

Just checking back in. After a day and 1/2 of experimenting with the z Force I think I'm going to swap it out for an s7. I won't even attempt to compare the Moto Z with the Note 7 (because no other device can touch the N7 with a 10 foot pole).

Yeah, no device can touch that Note 7 without taking some serious heat...

I definitely notice a difference in the photo's especially low light or outdoor nighttime shots. Ironically, I never put too much thought into pictures and took for granted my Notes capabilities apparently. Wasn't until I took some shots on the Moto I realized the noticeable difference. When scrolling through My photo gallery. 
I found myself continuously hitting the finger print scan button on the Moto expecting it to also act as a home screen button. I suppose I would've gotten used to that over time. Found the volume and power buttons to be oddly place and kept inadvertently turning off the screen. Also would've eventually figured that out too. 
I prefer Samsung pay over Android pay. Nice being able to swipe up from any home screen to launch the app. Also, with Samsung pay I can still use it on legacy card readers. I love the look on the cashier's face when he/she tells me "we don't accept Apple pay." my response is "good thing I have a Samsung" as my payment is accepted. Also For some reason neither the Verizon sales rep nor I could load my outlook email without having to install the Outlook app. The stock app simply wouldn't accept my login credentials. I absolutely love the stock Samsung calander, its display and the full screen notifications. Not a fan of Google Calendar and found myself in the play store looking for something to replicate the calander. Wanted multi window. As another poster advised that was coming in the next update but knowing Verizon, who knows when that would be and what else Verizon would tack on I'd end up disabling or unable to remove... 
The absence of a blinking notification light was something I'd miss and wished I had back if I were to keep my moto. Nice being able to see from across the room whether or not I have a new message.
TouchWiz had a bad rap, deservedly so. It's been scaled back and in my opinion blends well and is very functional. Just found Moto's too bland and would've had to run a 3rd party launcher. With my Note 7 I never considered another launcher (always ran a different launcher on my note 2,3 and 4). 
All of the above I could have likely lived with but The biggest deal breaker for me was the low earpiece and speaker volume for voice calls, alerts and text messages. I found I needed to position the phone perfectly over my ear to hear a conversation. Also was in zedge looking for loud alert sounds for notifications. While in a restaurant I had to twice step out to hear the caller on the other end. Not used to having to do that. It was possible I had a bad device but figured if that were the case I'd might as well get an S7E if I were going to get another phone. For sure the z is a premium device and the gestures are nice. It's a very comfortable phone to hold knowing the screen is shatter proof! 
Hope this doesn't come across as being nitpicky. I really wanted the Moto Z to work for me. Still annoyed with the handling of the Note 7 matter. 
While some of the above are personal preferences I believe you should get what works best for you considering the cost of these high end devices.

Hello all,
My Moto X 2013 DE has seen better days and is ready for retirement. I have finally decided that the Moto Z Force Droid is the one for me. I just have a quick question which I have tried searching but cannot find the answer to. 
My wife and I honeymooned in Ireland this past January. I got a prepaid sim card in Ireland and had full functionality on my Moto X. We are planning on going back to Ireland in the next year or two. I would like to use it for local calling to hotels and GPS Navigation (Cheaper than rental car GPS). Will the Moto Z Force droid have full functionality with a prepaid sim card in Ireland or does it not have that capability?
I appreciate all assistance.
Thanks,
Sean

It should, but that depends on which network you get your card from (and of course, that the phone is unlocked). The site below shows that it is compatible with all of Ireland's networks on 2G and 3G, but only some networks are compatible with 4G (and in only a few bands, so it's up to you to check which bands are used in the areas you'll be visiting). Also, check the networks limitations: some companies impose restrictions to 3G-Only, etc. to prepaid cards or roaming phones. WillMyPhoneWork.net - Check if your phone works on a network
My suggestion? If you'll use it just for calls, it'll work. For GPS, save yourself the prepaid card money and download Ireland as an Offline area in Google Maps. Done! No data needed to use for navigation (NOTE: Not sure that turn-by-turn navigation will work Offline; IIRC it's limited on some areas). If the phone supports WiFi calling, you can even save yourself the roaming/long distance charges by piggybacking off any WiFi to make calls (coffee shops, hotels, airport, restaurants, etc.).

Yes, like the Moto X DE, the Z Force is also not SIM locked, so you can put in a local SIM from an Irish mobile network, and uses the same nano SIM size as the Moto X did. As SpookDroid says, you may not get LTE connectivity, but there are more LTE bands supported with the Moto Z Force Droid Edition than with the 2013 Moto X.
Awesome. I really appreciate the info. It is a great help. I was worried it would be sim locked but it is great to hear that it is not. Thank you for the help.

replies.text:
Because of the rules of the auction that Verizon Wireless won to get the band that they use for LTE, they are not allowed to SIM lock any of their devices that use that LTE band (band 13, 700 MHz) - which all of their phones use. VZW phones are never SIM locked - one of the best things about buying one from Verizon.
Enjoy the trip!

title: Why are my contacts randomly changing themselves or deleting all together?

thread.text: I have a Moto Z Force Droid phone by Verizon Wireless and I have been having contact problems in regards to contacts that have changed names on My Messenger plus app. As well as in my contacts app. When I go to the contact that has a wrong name associated with the number and go to edit the name it shows the original correct name that it should be but when I back out of editing it shows the altered name as the contact I don't know what to do I have found that on some contacts I can delete a letter from the name and retype it in and save it and then when I back out of editing it shows the correct name. My latest encounter with the with the contacts getting changed is that now the number is still correct but when I go to edit the name it shows as it appears on the contact with the wrong name I have backups of my contacts on both Verizon Cloud and Google that way I have a secondary backup in case either goes down. I believe there may be a problem with keeping both a backup on Verizon cloud and Google but I don't know how to fix it without messing up my contacts since not all my contacts are in either my backups between Verizon cloud and Google. Can someone please explain to me what I need to do to fix the situation so that my contacts stay as I had entered them in my phone.

If you're simultaneously syncing both cloud backups, stop. Pick one and periodically switch to keep the other one in sync. (Google will sync all Google contacts - but not other category contacts - so make sure that all your contacts are "your-google-account", not Device, Phone or SIM.)

If you're going for more than a week, try a prepaid local SIM. You should be able to find them at all the major train stations.
