replies.text: Buy it.......do it.....Moto wants you.

thread.text:
Wifi calling was working on my moto z force. Tonight I noticed it was not using WiFi on a call. I put in airplane mode and turned on WiFi and I could make a call with wifi calling. But once I took it off airplane mode, now connected to both WiFi and vzw, a call used vzw and not WiFi calling. Same with my wife's new iPhone 7.
Anyone else see this?

Shouldn't it use the carrier network if it's available?
My Note 5 (on T-Mobile) has a setting to always use wifi calling if on wifi, or use wifi calling only if cell isn't available.

It would use WiFi if on WiFi over the carrier. Just noticed tonight it is not working like that. At my house my signal goes in and out so having wifi calling has helped.
Edit: Must be related to signal strength. I went in my basement where I have the weaker signal and it jumped on wifi calling. I'd rather it always prefer wifi calling but do not see a setting for it. there is a setting for when roaming to favor wifi calling, but at home I am not roaming.
Is the z force screen more narrow than the turbo 2?
According to dimensions, the phone is not as wide, but the screen is larger so the side bezels are smaller.
I came from the turbo 2, that was a very wide feeling phone when in your hands. The Moto Z Force feels allot narrower in hand!
The Z is a little more North/South and Turbo 2 East/West. Z feels better in the hand IMO.

title: Tip on making the Z Force more one hander friendly

thread.text: I sometimes leave my JBL Mod on my Force for quite a while or days without swapping it up. Not sure if any of you have found this or discovered this but by accident this morning the kickstand was still in the pull out position and I picked it up to text. I realized right away that my middle finger was actually supporting the phone under the kickstand in the pulled out position. It was like the phone was resting in place on my finger under the pulled out kickstand and it was 10 times easier to hold and use with one hand. Hope that makes sense BC it works awesome. It was never easy to find the right grip when using just one hand on this phone but the kickstand keeps the phone in one place only and makes it stable to hold comfortably in one hand while either using both to type or if your hand is large enough only the one hand to type. No more of the phone slipping into another position while holding it. The kickstand eliminates all of that. If you have the JBL, give it a try. Definitely works.
Works good.

For me the easiest one-hand assist is the screen shrink gesture. Super fast to turn on and off, so you don't even have to rock the phone in your hand. Swipe to turn it on, reach, tap to turn it off. I especially like it for typing with one hand using swipes. As I'm doing right now. 😀

I have the same thing with the otterbox defender belt clip/holster. I'm able to hold it from the back clip. 
I need to try the screen shrink more. It's one of the things go I disabled but it's a good idea.
Yeah sure here. I forgot about the screen deal

title: Using Moto Voice with Fingerprint Security Sensor?

thread.text: Droid Turbo 1 owner here looking to (possibly) upgrade soon. One feature I want is a fingerprint sensor, but I'm wondering how it works with the Moto Voice feature. I currently use a screen pattern security setting on my Turbo. I've gotten so accustomed to asking my Turbo questions and getting answers, for example while watching TV, (example: when was Grace Kelly born? Who led the AL in home runs in 1952?) or getting to the last clues when doing crosswords. I do this with the phone in my pocket or else lying on the table. If I have the Force Z with fingerprint sensor security set up, will I be able to ask the phone questions without scanning my fingerprint? Or will I have to pull it out of my pocket and scan my thumb before Moto Voice will be turned on and active?
The very short answer is you will be able to use the Z just like you do with your Turbo. You don't have to unlock it to ask it a question.
Some voice functions do require unlocking to use. For those, it's useful to set up trusted devices & places, so you don't have to unlock your phone as often.

replies.text:
Do you have a list of the functions that require security unlock?
I suppose I could set up my home wifi router as a trusted device and be done with the problem, correct?

I don't have a list, sorry. Yeah, you can set your home as a trusted place (which it determines largely based off of what WiFi network it's connected to), and you won't have to worry about it while you're at home. Similarly, if your car has bluetooth, you can make the car stereo a trusted device, and not have to worry about it in the car.
Does the trusted places work with location settings set to low battery consumption or does gps have to be on?
It can be set using the "Battery Saving" mode. I use it for home and my office. Also use it with my Bluetooth headset (LG Tone). Works great, one of the best innovations I've seen.

thread.text: I think if it can know the location by wifi network, it might not bother with other methods, but I'm not sure.

title: Trying to Decide on What to Replace Note 7 With

thread.text:
I am trying to decide what to do about my Note 7, and right now, it seems my main 2 choices are a Galaxy S7E or the Moto Z Force. I am really upset I have to make a choice in the first place, but that is how it goes.
So my question to the Moto folks is how they like their phone. Besides the stylus, what will I lose by going from the Note to your chosen phone?
What gotchas do I need to consider?
Thanks in advance!

replies.text: I returned my Note 7 and purchased the Z Force and I really like this phone. Only dislike is although a big phone, actual screen space is smaller than comparing to Note 7. I plan to keep this phone for a while.

Can you get a phone on the 14 day trial deal? 
If so, try the ZForce to see how you like it. If you do fine, if not, get the S7E, sounds like you have some familiarity with Samsung phones.
Good Luck, hope you can get a phone that fits your need/wants

thread.text:
There's a few bells and whistles you'll leave behind coming to a moto z. I also had an s7e but sold it to get the z force. I'm happier with the z force. Fingerprint sensor is faster and easier to use. It also locks the device. Battery life is extremely fulfilling. Yesterday I had 4.5 hours of on screen time with 22% left. That was after a day of heavy use. Unplugged at 6am. Camera is nice and the mods are awesome.
If you have any specific questions. Feel free to ask.

replies.text:
One of my biggest concerns is lack of updates. Also, how visible is the screen in full sun? Also, I have a Macbook as my main computer ( I know, but there is one piece of software I have to use and it only runs on a Mac). Any idea if I can move files back and forth? Samsung had Sidesync that helped with that.
Thanks.

Sunlight doesn't seem to be an issue for me. But I can test it shortly. 
Updates. I don't know. Marshmallow isn't bad at all. I don't mind the extended time if it's needed. 
Download "android file transfer" I have a windows 10 laptop so connectivity isn't an issue. My wife has a MacBook and that is when I use android file transfer.

With Android File Transfer, yes - https://www.android.com/filetransfer/ - though I always did this sort of stuff wirelessly myself.
And, yes, the app is kind of crappy.
(I would be apologizing if I was still using Windows myself. What a complete pile of junk that crap is. The best decision I ever made was switching to Mac for good 9+ years ago.)

I have had to support both, so I have to be "bilingual" so to speak. I am a firm believer in whatever platform works for you, but since I am in IT and most of my colleagues hate anything Apple, I usually throw in the caveat about needing to run a particular piece of software. It helps curtail side arguments.

thread.text:
You also gain some bells & whistles, though. Customizable always listening phrase, twist for camera, chop for flashlight. I was working on a customer's home theatre system this morning & did the chop for flashlight, and he was in awe. He mostly uses his smartphone for basic stuff. Being able to instantly turn on the flashlight without looking at the phone is super useful, and he was pretty jealous. lol
People have also consistently said the Z is a smoother operating phone, and makes the Note 7 look laggy.

I had the Note 7, the S7 Edge and now the Moto Z Force. Each of them have pros and cons but really, none of them are bad phones. For me, I really liked the speed of the Moto Z (BIG, HUGE difference), the Moto Mods (fun and cool) and the Moto Gestures (or whatever they're called). I wish the Droid was waterproof and dustproof (not a deal breaker) and that its camera was on the same level as Samsung's - particularly with focus speed. I know there are reviews out there that indicate the Moto Z is on the same level; I don't agree. I know there are several other minor (to me) differences - screen quality, battery life (a wash), etc. For me none of them move the meter enough to sway my decision.
Overall though, I really like the Moto Z more than the other two. It may boil down to personal preferences, I'm not a troll and certainly am not trying to instigate but would recommend the Moto Z over any of the Samsung phones on the market today any day of the week to anybody.

I just swapped my Note 7 for the Z Force this afternoon with Verizon. The guys in the Corporate Store were very helpful. I have a business account with 37 lines so they know me (definitely not my first visit with them). 
When I came in and said I'd like to go ahead and get out of the Note 7, the first thing they ask was what would I like to try out until the Note 7 was re-released. I had already been doing a little research and decided to give the Z Force a try. I also got the Battery Mod and the JBL Soundboost was half off due to a deal they have going (second mod 50% off). 
I'm taking the attitude that I'm going to keep the Z Force instead of going back to the Note. This is hard for me, I've had every Note except the original. I'm liking the Z Force so far but all I've done so far is the initial setup. I will say, as I installed SwiftKey, Nova Prime, and several other apps, the experience kept getting better and better. I'm sure just the familiarity with my preferences make it better. But now I can play around with something new for a week or two (who knows) and get a real feel for it before I have to make a decision. 
I just have to know if I've been drinking the Samsung Kool-aid too long.

I am very extreme on disabling bloat ware and unnecessary apps......but I'll just post a couple battery use screens hots from gsam. I hope it helps you or anyone else make a decision. But no matter what I am extremely happy with mine. The second one is with the battery mod on and set in efficiency mode.

replies.text: Are you running the Tumi or Incipio mod?

Incipio. But I honestly don't think it matters. Without the battery mod I go almost 2 days without trying. 
I'm not sure which one so don't quote me on this but I think Incipio actually makes the Tami mod....or its the other way around. Maybe someone else knows.
Very impressive!

thread.text: Why is your app usage so low? What are you using your screen for?

replies.text: I disable apps from running in the background. I figure why would I want an app running if I'm not using it. It's not for everyone. I know I'm in the extreme minority that stretches battery life as far as I can. I only post that to show just how amazing this phone is.
You're not alone. I do the same types of things.
What do you use, greenify? Your screen still has to be using some app. Anyway, I'm impressed.

I've never tried it sorry. I've seen other posts about it being good. I manually shut stuff down. At night from about 10 pm to 6 am I shut off 4g. Dim the screen and don't sync anything during those hours. I also went into each app and restrict the background data. I started out just looking at the chart of app usage and which ever one was a battery hog gets restricted. 
I used to use Tasker but from lollipop on the ability to do all that was disabled. 
If I'm at work I also shut down 4g. Texts and calls still come through without issues. Most everything I need to look at during those hours is available on my laptop. 
I think, don't hold me to it, that was over a weekend. So there I'm connected to a 4g network extender. It doesn't have to search for a signal so that helps a lot. I also go I to location settings and tap the 3 dot in the upper right hand corner and shut off wifi scanning. I don't use wifi at all. I still have an unlimited plan and since I pay for it I'm going to use it. 
I'm glad to share if you have any questions at all. Either post here, I check daily, or PM me. I hope that helps some. 
Maybe I'll give greenify a try and see what that does. I gave up on that battery cycle simply because I was bored. But I would put down money it would have gone 3 days.
Edit: Bright screens bother me so I usually have that turned way down also. Not sure this was the information you were looking for but if not feel free to tell me.

thread.text: I won't troll other forums but sometimes I think it's funny when I look at them and see someone post how happy they are to get 12 hours. I always think to myself if they only knew.......
Id get an s7/s7 edge.

I've had both the s7 and s7 edge. Now I have the Z Force. Two words for me are the difference. Software interface. Moto Z Force blows Samsung software interface away. I know for sure bc I tried my hardest to stay with Samsung but in the end it's choppy and sticky. Moto is seamless and smooth. If this is a factor for you, I highly suggest the Z Force. You wont regret it. Probably the best phone I've had ever.

If battery life is your priority, get the moto z force. I use the battery Mod and I honestly I go to sleep with the battery Mod having some life left and my phone still at 80%. I can literally go 2 days of full usage on this phone without remotely thinking about a charger. And I'm a heavy user - about 4hrs SOT a day and usually around 3 hours of phone calls. 
And then every other aspect of this phone is rock solid. Smoothest interface of any android phone I've used without a doubt.

I went ahead and got the Z Force yesterday. My Verizon store was out of the s7E's, which was really my only other option at this point. I have some questions that I will post in a separate thread.
My initial reactions are mixed. It is certainly a different way to do things. Not necessarily bad, just different and I am struggling in getting used to them. In some ways, the Note spoiled me, but hopefully this will spoil me in other ways.
I got the battery mod, and what I can say is that it really makes the phone thicker and heavier. I will have to see if I can get used to that as I have some wrist issues. Maybe it can be my wrist exercise routine.
Oh, I support Windows, too. Which is how I know how bad it is...
The one thing I will miss on Note 7 is fast high quality snap shots
I can hope, but not expect a minor camera update may help a little.
I agree; I too miss the snappiness of the Note 7's camera (the S7 and S7E are just as snappy). An update to "fix" this would be great.
Some people say if you go into the pro mode but don't change anything it takes faster photos.

Smart select is all I'm missing at this point. And the feel of the note 7. Yes, it had me spoiled. Lol. But Moto is a good, solid, non fire hazard, non recalled phone. Lol. And the battery mod is crazy long life.

I dropped the hammer on this phone yesterday, coming from my Note 7. Well, I didn't really drop a hammer on it...
Anyway, It is different enough that I have a few questions. I will try to group them by how they relate to each other.
Problem: I synced up my Yahoo account to the stock email app and though it worked, I noticed that when I click on a link in an email, it does nothing. I am used to it opening a browser and going to the site referenced. I have looked and looked for settings to fix this, but can't find any. Does anyone have any ideas about where I can change that?
No Gallery app. I noticed that there is no Gallery app like I had on my Note. I don't really want to use Google. Does the Google app actually look at photos on my phone, or does it move everything to the cloud? Are there any other ideas out there?
Related to that, I bought an SD card and want to move all my photos, videos and documents to there and have them automatically go to the SD card when I take photos, videos or download them. Same for documents. I mostly want apps on the phone itself. How can I accomplish that?
Finally for now, on my Note, when a post from a friend on Facebook comes in, or anything from someone I am following, or one of the pages I manage, the icon on the screen has a red dot with a number denoting that there has been activity. I can't seem to get it to do this on the Z Force. Is that just not possible on this phone?
Thanks in advance for the help. I know I will have more questions, but I don't want to over do it.
Wendell

replies.text: It backs up to Google servers. You can clean out the device through a setting in Photos to delete the device copies and preserve the cloud ones. You can opt which folders get synced as well. The upside to Google Photos is as long as you choose High Quality, there is unlimited space. Given that benefit, I am not sure what to suggest for your followup question. I have used Box and DropBox, and while both are good, I have already uploaded enough pictures that I would be on a monthly plan with them.

Use the Yahoo mail app from the Play Store instead?Yes, Google Photos is the gallery app for the photos on the phone, or both photos on the phone or the cloud. You can set it not to back up to your Google account (though I STRONGLY suggest you back them up to something, whether it's Dropbox, Flickr or Google, so that you have them in case of an issue - lost phone, broken phone, battery explosion, etc. You will be much happier if you have them backed up somewhere, and Google is a great place for that IMO.)
Also, there are plenty of great third party gallery apps in the Play Store. I don't use them anymore, but maybe somebody will recommend their favorite.

thread.text: For the gallery app, i use QuickPic. It works great, and really looks like the old gallery app. As for the stock email app, i use TypeApp instead. I get my gmail & hotmail almost instantly(as push email). For messaging, i use the stock Message+. It's better than the Textra app, that i used in the past. It's a fabulous phone, so good luck with it.

I also use QuickPic for my gallery and am very happy with it. I do also run Google photos as a backup, especially since all my old photos are on there.
For e-mail I use Blue Mail which has been great and also instant push mail. I still use extra for messaging but have played with messages+ occasionally. One of the big things I like about extra is if i hit the home button to exit, when I go back in I'm at the conversation list. With messages+ I end up in the previous conversation and have sent to the wrong person occasionally.

Textra is a good messaging app, but i never liked where they put the "send" button. Too close to the "back" button for me. With Message+, i can go to My Verizon on my laptop, and see all my messages, and also send messages. Very handy.

I did the switch from the Note to the Z Force yesterday. Liking it so far. I'm trying to keep the attitude that I'm keeping this device and not switching back. 
I went looking for a photo gallery also, QickPic seems to be the favorite and also has a private folder setting you can password protect like the Note. 
As I keep putting my stuff (Nova Prime, swiftkey, and other apps) on the phone the better it gets. At this point I'm very likely to keep this and skip the Note this year. 
I'm really enjoying the battery mod and also have the SoundBoost mod.

replies.text: I switched from the Note7 to the Z Force last night as well and I'm liking it better than the Note7 so far. Absolutely no lag (didn't realize how much lag I had on the Note7), fingerprint reader is the fastest I've ever used and I've had iPhones. I got the battery mod and SoundBoost mod as well and think they great. The Z Force is a great phone.

thread.text: I did the same thing. Went from the Note 4, with AT&T, to the Moto Z Force Droid, and Verizon. Call quality, inside the house, and outside is much better. It's the best phone i've had in years. I do miss the 5.7" size, but i can live with the 5.5".

You don't have to back anything up to Google using Photos, and if you do, you dont have to automatically delete the device copy.
Photos is a good gallery app, you should give it a try. I like Moto's Gallery app that they put on almost all their phones, just not the Zs for some reason. I downloaded the apk for the Gallery app from the Moto G4 and it works great. I like because it has a built in editor with the ability to export a different image size, unlike most gallery apps and even editing apps like Snapseed.
To move photos to an SD card, install the card (I recommend NOT to use Adoptable Storage), then use the preinstalled "My Files" app to move the photos from the phone to the SD card. You can then also set the camera app to automatically save photos to the SD card.
For email, the absolute best email apps out there are 9Folders and, yes, Outlook. Both are killer. I'd use either over the standard email app.

replies.text: I use TypeApp for my gmail & hotmail. 9Folders doesn't do gmail, so i'd rather have one email app for both.

thread.text: OP, FWIW, you can also use the Gmail app to access your Yahoo Mail account. The GMail app supports Yahoo, Outlook/Hotmail, and Exchange.

replies.text:
That's what I am doing. Gmail for all! I got lazy when I got my new phone and am just using Gmail for Yahoo, Gmail and my IMAP work account (GoDaddy servers). Works fine.
If I keep it I may go back to K9 mail just for my work account. It's much faster than Gmail with push email setup. I had both setup on my old phones for work and K9 would alert me minutes ahead of Gmail's app. K9 is just an old school interface a little clunky.

thread.text: Really put this baby to the test last night and once again, it came up aces. Got to the Mets game around 5:00 - at 100 percent, no battery mod. Turned off WiFi and Bluetooth, as usual. Took some pics and videos, texted, surfed the web a bit. After eating, sat down and watched the rest of the LSU-Wisconsin game (nice cheap-*** clothesline LSU) with my son on the ESPN app, for about an hour or so. Texted, took pics and videos during the Mets-Nats game, used MLB At-Bat app to check in on other games of importance to Mets' Wild Card chances (Cards, Pirates). Game ended around 10:30, they had fireworks following game, so I took a few fireworks pictures before heading to car for the ride home, around 11:00. The Z Force was at 83 percent after all that. Yes, 83 percent. I'm starting to think I wasted my money on the battery mod, since I haven't even used it yet.

replies.text: I agree with all of this. I really feel like Moto is under-selling the battery life on the Z Force. This is easily the best battery life I've gotten since the original Maxx, and maybe even better than that. It's truly a 48 hour phone if I were to push it (which I don't). Battery mod would make it a 3 day phone, but that's just overkill.

I think I must get crappy cell signal near my house. I'm lucky if I get just over 3 hours of screen on time before it's under 10%. I know app usage makes a difference, but I rarely do anything besides twitter, internet surfing, and Android Central app. I leave wifi on all the time as well as Bluetooth, but certainly those don't suck battery life to the extent that my screen on time is so much less than what many are reporting here.
What's your cell reading? (The actual number, not the bars.)
-92dBm 48asu (listed under settings > about phone > status > SIM status > Signal strength)
That's not a terrible signal, though for comparison's sake, I get between -69 to -79 in my house, with an LTE Extender. At Citi Field it's about -82.
What Google apps do you have syncing? Are Bluetooth and WiFi constantly scanning?

Gmail, calendar, and drive for 2 Google accounts. And I suppose Bluetooth and WiFi are constantly scanning because I never turn them off. But even when I'm at home, when I'm connected to WiFi the whole time, I still don't get nearly the battery life folks are reporting here.

Brother I'm with ya.. I might get 15 hrs and I'm down to 30%.. But I'm not complaining ... plug it in for 30mins and I'm good for another 15 hrs.. I also have the battery mod.. if I need to use it. Phone is awesome..

thread.text: I mean, this is just silly.

Yesterday was kind of a slow day for me but when I went to bed the phone had been off the charger 16 and half hours, had 4 and half hours of SOT and I had 20% battery left. A couple of the screen hours was using GPS with screen on auto all the way up, probably 1 1/2 was streaming some type of video and the other hour social media etc.. Maybe a few other things in between. 
I'm coming from a LG G4 which had a slightly smaller battery, but I easily get double the battery life with the Z Force over the G4.

So I have been using GSam Battery Monitor and I love it but I have noticed that it does not keep an accurate time since full charged. I do have the battery mod but that only kicks in at 80%.
Example:
I unplugged my phone yesterday at 6am and it was at full charge, it is now the next day at 5pm but it is only displaying its been 32 hours when it really has been 35 hours since last charged. 
Any ideas?

replies.text:
It's definitely related to the battery Mod. Mine is always off a few hours by the end of the day. It also doesn't capture SOT correctly because it doesn't register the screen on while the charging is taking place. I find this frustrating because I can't see what my SOT is at the end of the day. But it's really more to quench my curiosity. Every night I go to sleep, my battery Mod has about 10% and my phone is still at 80% (in battery efficiency mode). I'm using my phone the same as my last one, so in all likelihood I'm about 4 hours SOT after 24 hours and about 2-3 hours of calls. To go to sleep with that type of usage and still have a little juice in the MOD, plus 80% on the phone is absolutely ridiculous. I love this phone. 
Anyone recommend an app that interprets battery stats correctly while wearing the battery Mod? 
Anyone else not experiencing this on GSAM?

thread.text: Any phone that YOU decide on will be good because it would be YOUR decision. Not someone else's!

I'm sure plenty of folks (including myself) would recommend the Z Force. It's a great phone with excellent battery life and smooth operation. The mods are cool too, but it's an excellent phone without them as well.

I got the Z Force for my wife, she loves it. I wouldn't not recommend it, but it's too expensive for a 6 month phone and IMO the security updates and other updates aren't necessarily up to par enough for it to be a 2 year device.

I too am a T2 owner and I share some of your priorities. Each of the phones you listed has their pluses and minuses. For example the Force is shatterproof but not water resistant. Plus, the N7 has a better camera. On the other hand, the N7's screen durability is questionable, not to mention the lessor/exploding battery. IPhone 7 is now water resistant, but the screen is not as tough, no SD card, etc. 
Pick your biggest priority and get what suits your needs best. Good luck!

I switched to the Force from the original Turbo. I bought the Turbo when it launched October 2014. I feel the Force is the best out of them all. Battery life is amazing. I am pretty severe with disableing apps and controlling background data. I can EASILY get 2 days without the battery mod. With the mod I could go 3 days. I don't believe any of the phones you listed will do that. 
But everyone may not place the level of importance that I do on battery life. 
I typically keep a phone for about 2 years. I felt this was the one that would allow me to do that. 
It's also the most vanilla android OS out of the ones you listed. Can't stand Apple, except for the stock. I like to be able to change the look of the stock launcher. I use Action launcher. 
Not sure if I've been able to give you an opinion helping you make a choice or not. But those were the factors that went into me making my choice. All phones have different things so it's whatever works for you.

replies.text: Just a question for clarification. If you are going to use Action Launcher on any phone you have, why does it matter how close to vanilla Android the phone is on its own?

I can understand why your asking. But my point is the plain OS is the most vanilla out from what I've seen, besides a Nexus device. My choice to use Action launcher doesn't change that. 
I'm just amazed at how different manufacturers change the OS. 
For example a family member was having some sound issues with a galaxy 5. I tried to help him and was amazed at how much Samsung changes things. I tried but wasn't able to figure it out. I looked in the forums here, on XDA, and YouTube. After messing with it for an hour I gave up. He bought a Z Force soon after.
And for full disclosure every smart phone I've ever owned had been Blackberry or Motorola. I had severe crackberry addiction. I then switched to the original Droid, to Droid 4, Droid Bionic, Droid Raza Maxx HD, original Turbo, and now the Z Force. Not sure if my order is correct. I didn't start using Action launcher until the Turbo. 
So as you can see I'm partial to Motorola. I'm not sure it will continue after this now that Lenovo is involved. Time will tell.

thread.text: Being an apple user for so long or until this year, I would narrow it down to two phones. Z Force and iPhone 7. I watched the release videos and I have to say that I want one. My plan is to hold out for the iPhone 8 since it's supposed to or possibly show me some creative innovation which is huge to me. My vote is go for the Z Force. This is coming from someone who couldn't stand android until I got the original droid turbo for a while and kept me with Motorola. The Z Force is a pretty awesome device all the way around and is as smooth as you can get interface wise. Let us know what you decide. Also it will come down to size too. That is why my other phone is the Sony Experia X 5 inch. I love a small phone and I actually use it more than my Force. It's a grab and go one hander. Plus Sony has similar software interface to Motorola. Seamless. Not choppy like Samsung which I tried my best to like. I say go Force. You'll be happy with it.

I have the z-force. This isn't something I would make an official recommendation on, because it's mostly subjective, and comes down to what you prioritize. For me battery life is the most important thing, and I've been using the battery Mod with this phone. It's absolutely ridiculous! I go 2 full days of serious use. I usually go to sleep with the battery Mod about kicked and then wake up with 80% left on the phone battery. The 80% easily lasts me the next day, and to this point I haven't had to charge again until bedtime on the 2nd day. So it's a for real 48 hour phone with the battery Mod, not just a phone with the capability of getting 48 hours under very particular use. For me that's a game changer. The battery Mod makes it a little heavy and adds thickness, but in my opinion not too thick or heavy given what it does. I personally don't mind the weight, but when you hold a much lighter phone, it's definitely gonna standout. 
And... 
Camera is excellent. Definitely better than my wife's 6s and up there with the S7 from comparisons I've done in person. I didn't really test low light in those tests but I don't look to take a lot of low light photos, so not a big deal for me. Overall I've gotten excellent photos, and the flash works perfectly well in dark settings. In marginal light conditions, it's been more than adequate. The T1 camera really wasn't very good as a reference point for my opinion. The T2 had a solid camera, but you needed a really steady hand. I think it's similar on the z-force in terms of what you need to do to optimize your photos. You probably need a steadier hand than you will with the S7 or Iphone. So it might not be quite as easy to point and shoot and get an incredible shot, but the capabilities are right up there with anything on the market. 
And the operation is the smoothest of any android phone I've used. I've had the last 3 Motorola flagships, and I thought all of them were buttery smooth, but this phone is on another level. It doesn't lag in the slightest and the screen transition and sensitivity is easily the best on any android phone I've tested. It's right up there with an iPhone in my opinion in this regard.

title: Help, can't get the phone to read messages while driving

thread.text: OK this may be a noob type question, but when it comes to Android I guess I am. Via bluetooth I've connected my phone to my cars UConnect system. When the phone connects to the car I get a notification telling me the device is configured to read my messages and gives me an option to select not now if I don't want it to (which of course I don't select). However when ever anyone sends me a text I get no verbal notification and opportunity to have the text read aloud. I did notice that driving mode settings (which I only seem to be able to find when I'm attached to the car) there is a section that says something like enabled devices that Android will add and remove from automatically and its blank. I can find no way to manually add the car's UConnect to this area and to be honest I'm not even sure if I need to. Am I missing something, or does Android not offer this feature at this time?

It does have the ability to display notifications and read texts via the head unit, at least on some cars. I know that it works in my truck. 
So it could be dependent on whether or not your head unit supports the current version of Android. 
Also, something weird, try having the screen unlocked and on when receiving a text to see if it then displays. The first couple of times I paired this phone it wouldn't show the texts without the screen being on. It eventually worked itself out and now works as normal, Screen off and locked.

I'm not familiar with UConnect at all, so I can't really be specifically helpful, but osubeavs728's suggestion of trying it with the screen already unlocked is a good one. A number of folks have had frustration with using hands-free features, because the features end up getting blocked by the phone needing unlocked. You can set up "trusted places" and "trusted devices", so (for example) when the phone is linked to the car stereo, it doesn't require being unlocked, because it's in a known location. If this isn't set up, it can block a lot of features in effort to try to keep your device/info secure.

Thanks, I'll try unlocking the phone. I also suspect some incomparability as when I try to download my contacts list to the head unit it tells me something along the lines of the phone is not compatible with the head unit, but I can make and receive calls via the head unit so I'm not real sure. Thanks again for the ideas.

title: Switched to the Moto Z Force DROID (verizon) AMA, I LOVE IT

thread.text:
Hey All,
Took my Note 7 back to the verizon store last night, no restocking fee and they even gave me several deals on the Moto MODS and a bluetooth ear LG Tone set.. amazing...
First thoughts
----------------------
*LOVE the screen, it's almost just as good i can't tell a difference (also i put a tempered glass on it with zero problems)
*NIGHT AND DAY difference on speed and performance, everything is incredibly fast and snappy right out of the box, even while i was setting things up and installing things, not a single hiccup on speed what so ever, it's still fast as we speak.
*Never charged it over night and the standby time even after setting up the Moto voice LISTEN at all times, the battery only dropped 5% over night, incredible (just right on the same level with an iPhone with Siri listening)
*Camera is just as good, inside pics almost look better they aren't as washed out
*The moto mods are cool, not sure what people are talking about, I got the JBL Speakers and also the Battery pack... i'm actually liking this concept of how EASY they are to take on and off (strong magnets) I might keep them in my car so when i feel like switching out i can. 
I'm currently keeping on the JBL speaker one because it has a cool kickstand and also a built in battery.. adds a nice solid feel to the phone.
More thoughts- I can't believe i didn't decide to go for this first.. i guess the marketing of the note 7 sucked me in, but this is by far a better phone.

replies.text:
Nice. Sounds like you made a good choice for you. I want the mods too! Good luck!
p.s. Over time, I would bet you will notice that the screen and the camera (especially) don't compare..

I've had the S7 and Note 7 and the camera comment isn't even close to accurate. This camera on the Z is excellent and I get more clear and in focus pictures on average than I did on my Sammy. I do like the Note though so I'm not a hater.

I haven't played with the Note 7, but I was doing picture comparisons between my z-force and my friends S7, and they were very very close. To be honest a decent amount of the z-force photos appeared to be a little crisper upon zooming in all the way. I think the S7 might be a little easier to snap a great photo in that you just point and shoot fast, and the outcome is always excellent for the most part. I think the moto camera takes a little more skill. It seems more sensitive to motion and it doesn't snap quite as fast, so you really have to keep a steady hand. So if you're looking for a camera that's the easiest to get great photos, go Sammy, but I wouldn't bash the camera on the z-force. I get fantastic photos on the z-force that are 100% right up there with the S7 (and I imagine the Note 7) under the same conditions. 
I'm more than happy with the camera on this phone. It gets under appreciated for its camera because most people don't know how to take good photos. It got a solid Dxomark rating, and I don't think there was any bias involved in that testing.

A) great choice. If I didn't want the S Pen, I'd have the Moto Z 
B) Motorola makes super awesome and under rated devices ever since the Moto X. I have had 3 of them and the Motorola buds. 
C) camera is not as good
D) I'm super jealous of the mods. 
Great choice.

At the end of the day, it's about what YOU WANT! The Moto z and z force are great phones! Great screen, super fast and smooth, great battery life and the mods just give it an added bonus! 
I had the note 5, but when I got a chance to check out the z force I was hooked! I thought that I was gonna miss the S-Pen..... Not at all! My co-workers are jealous cus they don't have Verizon. The ones that are android users love my phone. Of the iPhone users be hating lol. I have different color style mods along with the jbl speaker and they swear that I have more than one phone. So enjoy your new phone! At least it won't catch fire lol! 
I know that everyone was hype when the note 7 was announced! People were like "man when the note 7 comes out it's going to be hot! That thing is going to blow up!" No one guessed that it would be literally lmao.......

thread.text: Well, see that's a problem, I LOVE THE SPEN, use it constantly to edit, cut. Paste, etc ...i'm an artist and depended on it.

replies.text: The ipad pro might be something better for you, the pen on it is FANTASTIC!

thread.text: I think it's hilarious on the it's a better phone post. My son has that phone. When he grabbed my phone to check it out his exact words to me were "wow. My phone sucks". Lol.

Not trying to crap on your post so please front take it that way, but a co-worker and his wife got those a few weeks ago and he was showing it to me at work talking about how great it was... super fast, great battery, etc...
Week and a half later help came up to me and showed me his new note 5. I asked what happened and why he returned it. He said both phones dripped off on battery life after only a few days. Could be how they used it so that doesn't mean anything. He also said the phones lagged so much it was driving them crazy. 
Everyone uses their phones differently and who knows if they downloaded something that was bogging their phones down. I would just pay attention to performance and battery life during your trial period.
Get what you like, like what you get. I have the Z Force and like it a lot. I can see why people would really like the Note 7. That's the beauty of Android.

All phones have great battery life out of the box for new phones, and all phones run super fast new or after a factory data reset. That's because there isn't a bunch of crap in the cache, we don't have 100% of our apps, widgets and other stuff running in the background. 
With that said, the Motorola should be a little faster and use a little less battery stock, Motorola is more stock Android, meaning it's not loaded up with all the extra UI, I call it eye candy. You will notice more black and white screens. I personally like the eye candy of the Samsung and lg's, it's a personal choice, but it comes at a small price in battery consumption and speed, all though I think the battery does good on the note 7.

I came from the Moto Z Force and I will agree it's a bit smoother and that it has marginally better battery life. I think the mods are a cool idea and I had the JBL speaker & Incipio battery mod.. My main problem with it was the 2- 3 second delay when activating speaker phone and a similar delay in an audible ring tone -- If I was looking at the display I could see I was receiving a call but nothing audible for 2 - 3 seconds. A couple more negatives for me was while playing games it would get VERY hot and the "feel", I never got it to feel comfortable -- with no back on it, it felt too edgy and with the stock back on it -- it felt too thick. With regards to the Moto voice -- unless I was doing something wrong -- it was just a different way to start Google, basically instead of saying "ok google" you can choose whatever phrase you desire. 
I totally disagree on the camera! The Note 7's camera is vastly superior to the MZF -- night and day difference in lower light. The display on Note 7 is also much better, as I feel the top plastic layer (shatterproof protection) on the MZF makes it slightly distorted at certain angles. 
I find the Note 7 to be almost perfect as I love the S Pen and all the functionality it offers, as well as the water resistance, camera, display and it's stunning look and feel. 
I'm glad I did try the MZF first so I wouldn't always wonder if should have got it instead of the N7.. Note 7 for me, is the best phone on the planet right now and Samsung stepping up to the plate on the battery issue just shows what a stand up company they are and that means a lot in this day and age!

Will keep my Note 7 till they get a replacement. 
I ain't jumping ship cause people are scared.

The New Moto phones look great. I just don't think I can deal with that company long term.
Will be taking a look at the iPhone 7 instead.

I'd buy it too if they had the unlocked version out yet. No way am I switching to Verizon. I believe the speed/camera/display for sure. My Moto X Pure with a SD808 is about the same speed as this Note with the SD20...sad...My apps load 2x faster on my Samsung Tab S2 with a SD652 as well...I think this phone is extremely under optimized and a little over priced. I do love the always on display / wireless charging.....but those are about the only 2 things you can't get elsewhere for hundreds of dollars less, other than S-Pen, which I think I have used 3 times. I get people have use for it. I wish more phones had wireless charging. As someone who is in and out of the car all the time, the Qi Phone Mount is a great convenience.

The only mod I'd be remotely interested in would be the projector. It's not enough to make me divert from the Note at this time though. 
Conrats on finding piece of mind!

thread.text: Insignia usb-c car charger from best buy triggers turbo charging
So basically normal fast charge speeds I get on any fast charger, QC or not. But not actual Turbo (like 3000+ speeds).

replies.text: That was my thought - it's the same as a good normal charger. The difference being that the phone seems to require "Turbo" to charge attached mods.

thread.text: From what I can tell, any charger that can deliver 2.5 A or more will enable the fast charging notification. The 110 V turbo charger will provide up to 5.5 amps and is extremely quick. Less amps longer charging time...

replies.text: If it elicits the Turbo Charge, does that mean it will also charge the battery Mod?
Yes it will. I have tried several different chargers over the last month. As long as it says turbo charging it will switch to charge the mod no matter what the speed is.

It doesn't matter if you are turbo charging or not. Once the phone is fully charged, the battery-containing mods will begin to charge. With a low-output (2.0 A or less) charger, it takes a loooooooong time after the phone reads 100% before the mods begin charging, but they do charge. If you throw your phone and mod on a charger and leave it for a few hours or overnight, everything will charge up fine. The Moto turbo charger just crams 5.5 A into the phone so everything happens faster. To be honest, I think any battery will likely last longer if you charge slower anyway if you can wait.

thread.text: Does anyone know if the only way to charge the Tumi battery mod is with the turbo charger? I've tried plugging into my trucks USB outlet and it will only charge the phone and not the mod. Just wondering if anybody would know why.

So u have just a regular USB C charger? If so it will probably charge the battery pack after the phone is fully charged. With the turbo car charger it still waits until the phone is charged a good amount before charging the battery pack. This holds true for both the incipio and tumi power packs (I have both)
Posted via the Android Central App

The battery mod won't charge until the phone is fully charged up first, regardless of the charger. Depending on the wattage of the charger, it may take a while to begin charging the mod. If you get the wireless battery mod, it can charge separately wirelessly.

title: Battery Life of the Moto Z Force DROID Edition

thread.text: Is anybody else disappointed by the apparent battery life of the Force? For example, Phone Arena puts it at 7 hours 9 minutes, well behind the T1 and even the T2 (not to mention several other flagships). I expected more from a 3500 MAH battery. I realize that you can buy a mod, but of course that increases the price of the phone (not to mention wireless charging and an IP rating).....

I'm having trouble finding the review that says that to see what the testing conditions were. I could believe that number under a very heavy load, but would expect to get through a day pretty easily under normal or even somewhat heavy usage.

Yea, I have no idea how accurate their testing is. I haven't seen any other "objective" numbers either. 
It will be interesting to hear what the battery life is like once these phones hit the wild.

replies.text: I'm mostly assuming that the Moto Z (non-Force) battery size (2600mah) was chosen to be able to just get through a "day" of "average" use. That would put the Force's 3500mah battery at something like a day and a half, or a day of moderately heavy use, or 2 days of fairly light use. Time will tell what real world use gives.

Most of the reviews I read had the Force lasting a full day with no problem. Don't forget the phone charges extremely fast. So long as the phone can get you through a day, what more do you want? 
That said, I'll still be buying the battery mod for days where I'm traveling and don't have access to an outlet.

2600 is a bit short for a day of average use. That would have to be very conservative average use but one mans ceiling is another mans floor. No playing that stupid Pokemon for this phone.
Posted via the Android Central App

If the phone can actually get through a day, I'm fine with that as are most people. I work in an office so battery life is usually a non issue. That said, there have been days (at a wrestling tournament for example) where I blew through the battery on my T2. I hate having to worry about running out of juice! If I get this phone I will probably get a battery mod as well. 
My original point or concern is that the battery on the Force doesn't appear to be as good as I would expect. And, a mod is an added expense....

thread.text: Reports seem to differ on how good or not so good the Force battery is fwiw.

replies.text:
Because of the variables of use: Apps used, duration of time, brightness, data, wifi, signal strength, ambient temperature (this is bigger than some might appreciate), volume, headphone impedance, bluetooth, GPS, motion sensors..... The point is there are way too many things for anyone really to compare battery life. Also, looping a video via wifi in an office like most reviews do does NOT extrapolate real usage well at all.
In most reviewers defense, they are not scientists so ignorance is bliss. This is true for some scientists too- or perhaps willful ignorance...

thread.text:
Too many variables, so best to compare with your own use and network area. Reviewers that actually used the device with heavier apps state the device runs hot and the battery drains quick. That's par though for more devices than not. MXPE has this issue too. That and weak signal areas pulling data are battery killahs'.
Added: If all of the sensor bling is similar to the MXPE, all of that stuff on results in 15% drain on battery life. All that bling comes at a cost.
Good point about the sensors: I disabled all those wave/approach sensors on the MXPE.

thread.text: Unless it's a defective unit, I agree it sounds like a rogue app or process. I understand it's frustrating when you read other people getting awesome battery life and yours is absolutely dreadful. But this could easily happen with another brand. It's probably a good idea to learn how to do some very basic troubleshooting or ask us or someone to help.

title: Screen on time giving false read when using battery mod

thread.text:
Not sure if anyone else has noticed that the screen on time does not properly register when the phone is being used with the battery mod attached. 
It seems to happen when the phone heats up a little during heavy use. 
I noticed the my SOT was coming up less than normal recently at the end of the night, despite feeling like I had been on my phone a ton. 
Just now I checked my battery stats and was at 1 hour 49 min, then read an article for about 15 min, and low and behold, I checked my battery stats, and my SOT was exactly the same. 
My suspicions have been affirmed. 
Now I just wish I could calculate how crazy ridiculous my battery life is. All I know is I've been going to sleep with my phone at 80% because I still have some juice on the battery mod. 
It's unreal to have a phone that legit will last 2 days of awake time and really high usage. 
And I actually like the thickness and weight with the battery mod. It feels super premium.

replies.text: I don't mind the thickness, but the weight gets to me. It feels a little bit like a brick.

The battery life is fantastic without it, but I'm a very heavy user for work, and by the time I'm at 4 hours SOT and 2 plus hours of calls, I'm down to 20-30% towards the end of the night. 
Of course that's like 20 hours off the charger, and most nights that means I'm going to sleep soon, and will still have a little juice to spare. But it feels amazing to have a day like that, and then let's say I decide to go out and stay out really late, and instead of worrying I'm gonna run out with only 20% left, my battery mod hits zero and I have 80% left instead. 
From the Droid Maxx, T1 and T2 I went all day and maybe juiced up a handful of times before going to sleep (and that was with extremely high usage), but there were still instances where I found myself preoccupied with the thought that I was cutting it close. 
With the battery MOD, I'm really happy with the form factor, I really don't mind the weight, and the thought never remotely crosses my mind that I might run out of juice. 
On my worst day I'm going to sleep with the battery mod depleted and the phone battery at 65%-70%.
I'm honestly thrilled with this phone in every way!

thread.text:
I guess that's not surprising. Android's native battery stats measure "off charger" battery usage. If you've got the mod on, your battery is constantly getting topped up. It's like plugging in to the wall wart every 5 minutes. :-) 
And yes, this phone is awesome.

title: shattershield not as protective as it sounds

thread.text:
I've been going with no screen protector because of the shattershield. I've seen the drop tests and was convinced I'd be fine without one. Turns out though that while I'm confident my screen won't "shatter" if dropped, it doesn't seem to protect against chips any better than any other screen. I was sitting on a concrete step and the phone slowly slid out of my pocket and onto the step face down. I mean, this was about as lightly as the phone could have touched the concrete without purposely setting it down. When I looked at it there were 2 small chips in the screen. I guess I would have thought a screen marketed as super tough would be able to protect against such a light interaction with concrete.
So this got me thinking... What good is shattershield anyway? If I drop the phone from my hand while standing, even if it doesn't shatter this experience tells me it would still be messed up pretty bad with chips and scratches. So what's really the difference? I'd want to get the screen replaced anyway.
I can understand a few light scratches appearing without a screen protector but never thought I'd get chips from such a minor accident.

replies.text: Picture of these "chips" Because im thinking its just deep scratches from rocks.

I don't really have a convenient way to take a picture so I'm probably not going to do that. But I will say that you very well could be right, they may be deep scratches. I don't consider them to be scratches because they are not linear, as though something was dragged across the screen. It's as though a tiny rock was pushed into the screen and made an indentation. And again, the phone fell so slowly and hardly any distance that it's hard to believe there was enough force to leave such a mark.

thread.text: If you replaced the Shattershield (they should have them available at some point) would there still be a chip?
That's the point though. It won't be free of blemishes after a fall. But the screen won't shatter.
And you just need to replace the top layer. The whole screen isn't damaged. The top layer is a screen protector. It is kind of ridiculous that they don't have them available yet though.

replies.text: I wasn't aware that this is how the shattershield works. In that case, it's not a bad concept. I didn't know that only a layer on top needs to be replaced.

thread.text: ^Yeah, that's the design, a replaceable top layer. Many of us put a glass screen protector on top of that to get the feel of glass plus replacing that is generally cheaper and easier than replacing the Shattershield.
Well it lived up to the name, it didn't shatter. I always use a screen protector no matter how protective the factory glass is.

The major downside is that because they use a hard plastic instead of glass (thus it can't shatter, though there's more to shattershield than that), the top replaceable layer is more easily scratched than a gorilla glass screen. Sounds like your plastic layer has some slight gouges that look like chips.

Sorry to hear that man. Definitely get that replaced or if not maybe somehow you can find a material that will smooth out the chips somehow then throw you a Tempered Glass on it and that may in fact totally hide it. Just a thought for a do it yourself quick fix.

replies.text: A tempered glass screen protector will no doubt smooth out the chips, maybe even to the point you start to forget they are there. Also, I think Lenovo / Moto are going to start selling the top plastic layer for the screen, so you'll be able to replace that too.

When you say smooth out the chips it sounds like you are referring to the feel of them. I can definitely feel them if I run my finger across them slowly enough, but I'm more bummed out that I can see them all the time.
I hope that top layer folks keep talking about does become available, but it's not worth it to me if it costs more than maybe $30. I have no concept of whether that is a reasonable price or not, but I'm still going to have to pay somebody to make the repair regardless. Not sure if this is just a regional thing (I'm in MN), but there are these places called CPR (Cell Phone Repair) around here that have a pretty good reputation. I imagine there is some sort of franchise all over the country like it. Might have to check into that.

From articles I've read, it'll be around $25 - $30.
It should be user installable as soon as it becomes available.

Basically they will or should have a compound similar to liquid glass. Actually the liquid glass should work just fine for what you need which is some thing to fill in the divits that will harden clear. Before you pay them 50 bucks research liquid glass filler. I believe it's cheap just for a small tube then after you do it yourself pick up a tempered glass and you should be 100 percent good to go man. Shouldn't be able to see it what so ever. Good luck.

thread.text: Here's a video of how to replace the lens on the Droid Turbo 2 with shattershield to give an idea of the process.

replies.text: Holy crap, so the shattershield is basically just a screen protector? That's kind of cool that the screen protector is pretty much built into the design of the phone. Not sure why people are putting screen protectors on these phones in the first place, other than that the replacements aren't available yet. Seems like that's just putting a screen protector on top of another screen protector. The only reason I can think of to do that is because of the feel, but I personally like the feel of what's already on the phone.

Yup, it's a built in screen protector/lens. The downside is that it scratches fairly easily. That doesn't matter as much since it's replaceable, but some prefer the feel of glass and don't want a scratched up screen.

thread.text:
Motorola has a solid relationship with Verizon.
Their options were: give exclusivity to Verizon or try to work with AT&T and T-Mobile and Verizon without Verizon getting upset.
Moto Mods needed a retail presence.

I kind of think the exclusivity could work this time around. The phones have received a huge amount of positive press.
They'll get all that press again with the international release, release more mods, which it appears they'll do, and it could be a win.

I can't imagine getting the projector even if the price came way down because it doesn't interest me, but I know a couple of people who can't wait to get it. Different needs I guess!

A) Verizon sells a lot of phones, and the Z and Z Force are going to be among their most-pushed.
B) Only the Force is Verizon exclusive (once the standard Z and Z Play launch soon)
C) Lenovo will be pushing these phones a lot in markets other than the US
D) Lenovo has indicated that future phone models will support the same mods
Don't get me wrong, I'm a little iffy on how the mods will do, but I do think they have a chance at being reasonably popular & successful.
The market for mods will hear up once the Z and Z Play are released to the general public.

title: One month with the Moto Z Force

thread.text:
One Month Later
I've had my Moto Z Force for a month now and it's the best phone I've owned. The battery pack comes in handy if you like to do outdoor things, yet need to be able to be reached. Most of the time I keep the standard back on it, but I do have a case I that covers it for added durability. I did end up getting a screen guard, the glass one, whatever its called, due to some scratches early on. The battery itself last me all day, even when using it constantly. I easily got used to the fingerprint sensor/button layout after about a week, but I was also a G2, G3, G4 user. The close to stock Android gets the job done with minimal junk on board. So, for the Pros, Cons, and Indifferent;Pros:
It's fast
It's easy to use, yet robust enough to do real tasks
The close to Vanilla Android is a nice touch after using LG for almost 3 years
The fingerprint sensor works well
Great antennas 
It does the job quickly and efficientlyCons
The screen scratched way too easily. I had it for two weeks before I noticed scratches. My G3, which I carried daily for almost 2 years has less scratches. I didn't do anything differently, and before you somehow think I have some sort of construction job, I'm an Archivist and also teach history. So, I'm not really hard on devices. Indifferent 
No Phone Jack and no 3.5 aux. It takes a little getting used to and a few extra purchases. I needed charges for each of my vehicles and each of my offices because it never fails, I will forget one somewhere. Your results may vary. 
Overall, its a great device.﻿ I recommend it to anyone who needs a powerful phone with great battery life.
It's truly been the most pleasant surprise of my phone life in years.

For the record, I'm not what people that disagree with my assessment will rush to call me - a Moto/Lenovo "fanboy." The last Moto phone I liked was the original Razr and before that, my StarTac. Since the Razr though, I've been Moto-free, using iPhones, Sammy's, LGs and the Nexus 6P. I tried the Moto X Pure last year and hated it. 
And although not the prettiest looking, this Moto Z Force Droid is likely the best performing smartphone I've ever used. I was ready to give it up after using it exclusively for a couple weeks when the Note 7 dropped, figuring the new Note would carry me for the rest of the year. However, after about a week comparing the two, aesthetics aside, there is no comparison. 
Right up front the Note 7 - which is using the same Snapdragon 820 chip as the Z Force - is much better looking and has a better camera. In fact, it has the best smartphone camera I've ever used and is the best looking/feeling smartphone I've ever carried. (Nothing will top the StarTac for best feeling phone of all time. Nothing!  ) And if you're a big S-Pen user, this post is meaningless to you, as the Note 7 wins decisively there. 
That's where the Note 7 advantages stop. Battery life, performance, software, convenience, modularity, durability, memory management - all land squarely in the corner of the Moto Z Force. And that's very surprising, considering they have the same battery size and same CPU. It's truly like using two different phones. The smooth operation of the Z Force compared to the Note 7 is an eye-opener. I don't want to hate on TouchWiz, because I think Samsung has improved TW by leaps and bounds from earlier iterations, but what else could it be? Same battery, same CPU and nearly the same display. I cannot imagine the .2 of inch in display size could make such a difference in performance. 
Unfortunately, Moto/Lenovo's marketing, timing and decision to make it a Verizon exclusive (why, oh why not offer the Z Force and not just the Z to everybody when they beginning selling them unlocked later this month?!) are going to prevent a lot of people from realizing this. By selling it in the window of the Note 7 and next iPhone iteration, well, that's like opening an expected blockbuster movie on the same weekend as The Avengers AND The Hunger Games - not many people will notice you. 
I don't like the long-term outlook for the Moto-Mods line, because the buzz and acceptance just aren't there, outside a few pockets of interest. The Z Force hasn't gone out of stock anywhere, there were no lines to purchase, no pre-sales hype and Moto/Lenovo really seems to rub a lot of former fans the wrong way with its business practices. But for as long as I have it, I'm going to enjoy it. It's my favorite phone since the iPhone 3G and I hope to get a good year or two out of the line before Moto tosses the idea aside for the "next" great thing.

That's the review I expected out of Ron Amadeo.

Are they not valid points though?
Everyone's points are valid. Again, that's the snark I expected out of Ron Amadeo.

A few other reviews point the same things out as well, so a perspective issue. I agree on these points:
The device pricing in relation to expecting decent levels of mod purchases is too high.
Why no 3.5MM on the Force? I recall using the G1 and disliked keeping track of another attachment and no way to charge at same time. Sure there is Bluetooth now, but another expense for good sound quality options and another thing to keep charged. 
Why no remote use option for the JBL mod? Seems a silly miss having to always attach to the phone. You can get
better sounding Bluetooth speakers with better battery life for same price and not have attached. 
The one point some reviews note (that actually use the device beyond token levels) is it runs hot and drains battery quick with heavier use. MXPE and other device do this too, so a metal unibody device with a 820 SOC should not be a surprise to run hot or drain battery. We are at least another micron level of fabrication reduction before we might reduce this issue. Might.
I read review after review talking about how great the S7 and S7 Edge batteries were and having owned both, they are nothing special at all. (And they have glass bodies.)

Too subjective. Only battery life that really counts is the user's own comparison.
The S7s do have good battery life if mainly light and some medium use and in good signal areas. Then again, most devices have good battery life in those conditions.

title: Need Car Charger. Will a Power Inverter work?

thread.text: I got my new Z Force and love it. Disappointed that they don't have a car charger that will Turbo Charge it. I am leaving in 2 weeks for a elk hunting trip in the mountains and was wondering if I had a power inverter if that would Turbo Charge my phone if I used the Turbo Wall Charger. Not a electrician and don't understand the Amp/watt thing so keep it simple. Thanks in Advance.
What about a big battery pack
There is a turbo car charger on the Motorola site
Supposedly that one isn't compatible with the Z Force like it says. I already have a battery mod but being out there for 8 days they won't make it to the end.

replies.text: Someone said it is, but it doesn't charge as fast as the 30W included charger.

thread.text: Yes, An inverter will work. I used to use them with laptops back in the day. You'd have no problem.

I did stop at Verizon today and the guy assured me it will work with my phone. I bought it and plugged it in. It did work but not quite as fast as wall charger. I am going to see if a inverter can go any faster. Already I can charge now in the mountains.

replies.text: I don't think there's anything out there that will match the included (wall/home) charger.

thread.text: Yes a power invertor should work. The only car charger I have found that will charge the phone and then switch over to charge the battery mod is the one Verizon sells. It's a usb c fast charger. It does trigger the pop up that says turbo charging.
Just bought the Verizon wireless car charger with quick charge. Works great. Plugged it in and my Z force said turbo charging.

I took about a 200 mile trip the other day. Phone was at 100% when I left. Used a QC 2.0 charger, micro usb cable, and micro usb to usb c connector. 
Used 4g, GPS, screen at 100 the whole time. I know it doesn't turbo charge technically but it kept my phone at 100% the whole time. I was more than pleased.

i tried my Nexus 6P 6" usb to usb-c cable that came in the box, plugged it into a 1.8W blackberry auto charger and it charged from 50 to 100 in about an hour of driving. It also was able to go from about 5% to 30% in 20 minutes.

I've noticed that when the photos are taken with HDR it seems to store 2 separate photos in the gallery. 
Anybody else notice this? Is there a setting to change this?

replies.text: If there is, I can't find it. And I hate it. Though I did find a way around it. When you take a photo, choose the "Pro" mode. Not only does it eliminate the dual photo, it also allows for the photo to be taken IMMEDIATELY, without that terrible delay that it uses on full auto. And the "Pro" mode still takes everything using auto presets if you want. You don't have to fool around with any settings.
Thanks, I noticed the pro mode but haven't messed around with it yet. I think the other workaround would be to turn off auto HDR. In pro mode does it still take HDR?
You would think so, right? (About turning off Auto HDR.) But no, there is still an annoying delay. You can still use the Pro Mode in full auto though and the delay is gone.

thread.text: By pro mode, do you mean the sliders or something else?
the 2 photos are a "feature". It does it with and without HDR. As already mentioned pro mode disables it.

replies.text: Good to know... What is the point of this feature, and is there a way to disable it?
It gives you both the normal and HDR picture, in case you prefer one over the other.
It'll take 2 photos with HDR off, and one with it on. HDR isn't the trigger.

Yeah, at this point I've noticed it happen with HDR on and off. I'm curious to know what the trigger is. Either way, this does not seem like a useful feature. If HDR was the trigger, I could see it being a desirable setting for some, but to just have it on by default seems ludicrous.
Old habits die hard.... That's the trigger on my (now) old iPhone. Burst mode is on, perhaps?

Nope. I assume it's a "feature." Just wish they'd provide a way to disable it, as I think it's the reason for the delay when trying to use the default fully auto mode. And unfortunately there seems to be no way to make the Pro mode your default option.

thread.text: They only time I have noticed it is in dim lighting, and if you zoom in on the two pictures one is clearly better then the other. They are not the same picture.

replies.text:

And movement isn't the trigger as stationary objects get it just as much if not more.

title: How to use the Turbo Charger

thread.text: I normally put my phone on the charger before I go to bed, and let it charge overnight. With these turbo chargers that supposedly fully charge the phone in just a few hours does it hurt to leave it on charge all night?

replies.text: Charging slows down when near capacity anyway.
It won't hurt the phone battery at all to leave it plugged in overnight, no matter how quickly the phone reaches full charge.

thread.text:
I haven't been plugging in until I'm getting ready in the morning. It usually puts good enough charge on it
Posted via the Android Central App

replies.text:
I'm probably gonna go this route.
I also have a long enough commute that TurboPower charging in the car may get me to 100% before I get into the office.

thread.text:
I've only really used the supplied charger twice. I use a couple of Verizon chargers usb c fast chargers. One for the house and one for the car. I only charge when necessary and don't leave it plugged in overnight. 
But I will also use a couple of QC 2.0 chargers most of the time. I have some adapters that are usb micro to usb c. I have way too many micro cables to give them up. 
The other day I used a QC 2.0 car charger for about a 200 mile trip. I had 4g, GPS, and screen at 100. I started out with the battery at 100% and it never dropped at all. 4 hours later I was still at 100% pulling up at home. 
It doesn't turbo charge the battery but kept it topped off.
All smartphones, tablets, etc will draw the power they need. The charger doesn't "push" the charge, the device draws what it needs. So there's no risk of overcharging, etc.
I like leaving it unplugged overnight to get the longer run times, ha ha.

Here's how it works: The battery is charged to 100% then, even though the phone reports it's charging, it's stopped until the battery drops sufficiently, then it tops it off again slowly.
This is how you often unplug and find the battery at 95% 15 minutes later.

title: OWNERS: What do you LIKE about your Moto Z Force DROID?

thread.text: What do you LIKE about your Moto Z Force DROID?

- Overall size. My previous phone was a Nexus 6, and it was too big to use comfortably, even with my fairly big hands. I only remember dropping it once (no damage, had a case on it), but I was always having to be careful with it. I don't have to with the Z Force.- Speed. Very fast & responsive, usually the only time it lags is if there's a network connection issue that slows it down.- Battery. I don't have the battery mod, and so far I'm not having trouble getting through normal, or even semi-high use days. I also like knowing that if I do find myself needing more battery, between fast charging and the available battery mod, it shouldn't be an issue.- Fingerprint scanner. This is on a lot of phones now, but it's the first I've had, and I love it.- Fast camera. My Nexus 6's camera was/is really slow to load, so I appreciate that the Zf camera comes up very quickly.- Moto features. 2 phones back I had a Droid Maxx, and I missed some of these features with my Nexus. The Nexus is supposed to do "always listening", but it never worked well, where the Motos have. The chop for flashlight & twist for camera is wonderful too.- Durability. I like the thought that I can't shatter my screen. I've never cracked a screen, but it's still nice to know. I did put a glass screen protector on, mostly for scratch prevention & feel.- Mods. I got the speaker mod with the BestBuy deal, and will probably use it on occasion. I might eventually want the battery w/wireless charging mod, for long trips & such. I'm looking forward to seeing what else they come up with.
The battery life is epic even without the battery mod.

Battery mod. speed and close to stock android.
Posted via the Android Central App

Speed: This is the first device I've had where scrolling in the launcher doesn't stutter at all!
Oddly enough, coming from the LG G4, I find the screen gorgeous.
Bumping for more comments. I may get the Force tomorrow, but will likely also keep my MXPE for now.

It's all around just a solid device. Battery life has been tremendous, it's fast and smooth, all the tidbits I missed from my moto X. Camera has been meh so far. 
But overall it's great, a tiny bit easier to handle than my 6P and my Bluetooth actually works!
Posted via the Android Central App

I actually like the big bottom bezel. It gives you something to hold on to when you're holding it in landscape. 
Speaker is loud enough. The phone is fast. The camera is way better than the MotoX was. Battery life is good. Overall love it. Still getting used to the size.

I'm very hearing impaired and I can hear on the rare occasion I use the phone. Battery life is awesome and the gestures are easy to use.

I had reported in a different thread that battery life wasn't great the first 3 days. After a bit of de-bloating around a dozen apps, automating the turning on and off of wifi, and using Greenify, I can now report that the battery is better than ANY previous phone I've used. That includes phones with comparable size batteries.... Nexus 6p, Galaxy S7 Edge. The phone literally sips power now. Lost only 4% overnight, so the idle drain is fantastic.
Everything else about the phone makes it the best of 2016 in my eyes. I considered maybe returning near the end of my return period and give the Note 7 a try, but I will no longer do that. The Note will offer nothing more than what I have with the MZF. And the mods put it way over the top.

thread.text: Oh how I missed AMOLED.

- The fingerprint reader is fantastic.
- Fast charging with the TurboPower 30 charger is fantastic.
- Moto Gestures to open camera and flashlight, etc are fantastic. 
- The piece of mind with the ShatterShield display is fantastic. A way better solution than GorillaGlass, full stop.
- The fairly vanilla version of Android on this is great.
- While not 100% lag free like some reviewers say, the Snapdragon 820 is very fast.
- Build quality overall feels quite good.
- AMOLED seems like a better tech than LCD for phones - inky blacks and lower power use for Always-On Display is a big plus.
- Adoptable Storage and MicroSD card slot is a big plus.
-GPS navigation with GMaps has been rock solid. I've seen Pokémon GO lose its GPS signal sometimes but using it to actually navigate is pretty reliable. 
- The ease of use of the Moto Mod power pack battery is fantastic.
- Promise of future Moto Z phones using the same form factor so Mods will have some longevity is a plus.
- Choice of StyleShells is great, when they come out. Would love a style shell with wireless charging built-in.
- Mods have great potential, hopefully there will be more. Especially excited about the camera mod. Also would consider more of the current mods when the price goes down.
The thing is smoooooth. Had it since launch and don't remember ever seeing the slightest hesitation.

I love the call quality, the volume, the size and the smoothness of the phone. I turned in my iPhone 6+ because the call quality was so bad, and I'm so glad I did. 
It's great to be back on Motorola. Once the prices of the mods come down I will get the battery mod. I purchased the speaker mod since I use a fair amount of media on my phone; well worth the money for me. 
This probably will wind up being my all-time favorite phone to date!
