I delete all the Verizon contacts (#bal,#upd,etc.) But every time ibreboot they come back. Anyone experience this?
Yes mine did the same thing.
Login to your Verizon Cloud acct from a computer and delete from there.
I have Verizon cloud disabled on my phone

There's actually an app that does this, preloadcontacts.apk.
I can't understand why they put apps on devices to do such mundane things.
I disabled it.
That did it. Thank you!

An easier way - 
Open Contacts app
In the menu, select Google only (you're using an Android phone - all of your contacts should be syncing there anyway ).
I have other apps that list contacts

1. Open your Contact app (not within Phone app) and find the setting that allows you to 'Export' your contacts to either internal or SD card (menus vary by manufacturer) 
2. Open the Verizon Cloud app and select the top left 3 lines menu, select Settings, What to Back Up, and uncheck contacts (and anything else you don't want backed up, like music to save space for more precious things like pictures...I put all my music into Google Play Music for free storage...you can also turn off pictures/video and use Google Photos to back you up with a much larger amount of free storage)
3. Delete your contacts on the phone, again using Contact app (your contacts are safe from step 1). Go back to Cloud app, from its home screen scroll to bottom to select the circle that says Contacts. When your contact's are displayed, select the 3 dots at top right to select contacts. 0 selected appears at top left, select the drop down menu arrow and select all. Select 3 dots again and choose delete. 4 Go back to the contact app, find the Import contacts and import your contacts into your Gmail. I use and enter my contacts into Gmail. Of course, you must never forget your Gmail account/password if you begin using Gmail anything (Google Photos, Google drive) to back up your content!
Posted via the Android Central App
That seems much more involved than disabling a service. But thanks for the reply. The service took care of my issue.

Just giving you the steps that will remove your contacts! We aren't digging ditches, my father use to say...just pressing buttons on a phone.
Posted via the Android Central App

title: Ampere app issues with wireless charging

thread.text:
Anyone familiar with Ampere can help me out here? Ive been using Ampere to tell me whats going on with my different chargers and Im stumped on this one. My Wireless car charger puts out about 600 mAh which isn't enough to charge the Moto Z with Incipio pack while running GPS and the screen always on. It annoying the crap out of me because the car is the only really usefull place for wireless charging IMO. 
I took the phone inside and hooked it up to a different wireless desktop charger. I turned on GPS, cranked brightness up to 100% and played youtube video while on Wifi. Ampere says the max mA is 350 but is hovering around 170 with about 4V yet the phone is charging, slowly but charging. Anyone have any idea what is going on here. Im leaning towards Ampere is not accurately displaying the charging amps.

If you're going by the large number at the top, I believe that's the net rate of charge gain/loss, so if it's showing positive at all, you're gaining charge. So if you have it running GPS, etc, and Ampere is showing 600mAh, then it maybe charging at 1,000 and using 400, with a net charging gain of 600 (numbers should be blue-green), and will keep up and slowly gain charge.
If I'm incorrect about that, someone please speak up & correct me.

REad the FAQ and you are correct. It shows the net amperage. That is good to know, I assumed it was total amperage. This still wouldn't explain why I show 600-700 mAh of excess current yet the battery slowly drains in the car. Going to have to try a different wireless car charger. Perhaps my is crap.

A little annoyed that Incipio didn't build in fast wireless charging into the mod. For such an advanced concept as the mods I feel it should have been done, maybe we will see a mod with it in the future.

Also I found a setting under data usage that restricts background data. Anyone with more knowledge than I have that could possibly explain what that would actually restrict?
If this is already a thread mods please move this. Thank you.

Restricting background data is pretty much what it sounds like - the phone won't let apps that are in the background (i.e., not being used right now by the user) use mobile data for things like updates. I believe this only applies to apps that periodically refresh, and not those with Push notification. So an email program would still receive messages if configured for push, but a weather app or Facebook newsfeed won't update until you open the app, triggering a refresh.
This phone sips power when it's not in use, so unless you are on a plan with a very low data quota, and also away from wifi a lot, I would leave it alone.
I had to go all the way to page 2 to find the thread: http://forums.androidcentral.com/mot...rce-droid.html

title: Moto Z vs. S7 Edge - My Comparison

thread.text:
I buy a lot of phones - about five per year. This year, I've had the S7, S7 Edge, G5 and now the Moto Z. I also have the Note 7 on order. I wanted to provide a quick comparison of the Moto Z to the S7 Edge (the best phone I've used this year). It's purely my opinion and am posting to maybe help somebody who is on the fence on which phone to buy.
Points for the Moto Z
- Speed: I know the internals are similar but the Moto Z is just much zippier. I'm not a benchmark guy, but the difference in my opinion is very noticeable in day to day use. Frankly, this surprised me.
- Battery life: Although the S7 Edge battery life is really good, I think the Moto Z may be even slightly better. 
- Moto Mods - I flat out love them mostly because I'm just a gadget guy. I bought all three. 
- Screen: I am not a fan of the curved screen and having used the S7 Edge for the last couple of months, it's nice to use a phone with a traditional (flat) screen.
- I love knowing the screen won't shatter. I'm still going to use tempered glass just to ensure it won't get any surface scratches but this is a sense of security that no other phone offers.
Points for the S7 Edge
- Camera. This is really, the only disappointment to me with this phone. With the S7 Edge, I know almost any picture I take is crisp and clear. Not so with the Moto. In my opinion, the delta is quite noticeable in all pictures with the exception of those taken in bright sunlight.
- Feel: Even though I love the feel of the phone, it's actually a little bit more slippery with the moto back on it than when it's naked. Probably a personal preference but worth mentioning. The phone is also a bit heavier than S7. Not much but noticeable. 
- Waterproof. I know the Moto Z is splashproof but I enjoy taking my S7 into the pool and take solace knowing if I drop it, it'll survive. 
Screen: The Moto Z screen is great and perfectly fine for use... until you compare it to a Samsung screen. Again though, the Moto Z is perfectly fine for every day use.
I usually don't post my thoughts on phones. I did for this one because frankly, I think the Moto Z is a better phone than some of the reviews make it out to be. If somebody were to ask me which one to buy, I'd fire back one question to then: how important is the camera to you? If it's super important, go S7. If not, you'll love the Moto Z.

replies.text:
I sold my S7 edge yesterday at Best Buy and I picked up the Moto Z Force Droid and I must say, I like this phone better. I'm a heavy user and battery life is really important to me. I love the Incipio Offgrid Power Pack motomod! It's really thin against the phone. I hardly even notice that I'm using a battery pack. I had the mophie juice pack for my S7 edge and it was massive. I had the LG G5 for a week earlier this year and the moto does mods so much better. I love that the mods are hot swappable. I don't know why any company would bother making mods for the G5, to be honest.
The camera on the Z Force seems fine to me. DxOMark gave it a score of 87. The S7 edge has a score of 88. They're pretty close in quality. The S7 edge took slightly better lowlight photos and it had quicker focus.
I hated the blue hue that was on the edge screen on the S7 edge. I didn't even use the edge features because they were pretty pointless. 
My only complaint about the Z Force is that it doesn't have an IP68 rating. It's splashproof so that is good enough for me.
I have 13 days to return this phone if I don't like it. I may switch it out for the Note7, but I honestly don't see that happening. I love this phone too much.

That doesn't appear abnormal. It isn't awake substantially more than when you have the screen on or it is charging. The phone has to be awake (meaning "processing") to update data in apps, etc. Just because you aren't doing anything with the phone, that doesn't mean the phone isn't doing anything. 
A likely culprit in my mind for a whole lot of activity when the screen is off is Google Now, or any news/feeds/weather apps you may have that have to update periodically. If you have voice controls on, that also could explain some of that activity.

title: A couple thoughts on the speaker mod.

thread.text:
I got the speaker mod for free from Best Buy, don't know if I would have spent my on money on it because I have a decent Bluetooth speaker already. 
The speaker does sound good and gets loud enough I can hear it with no problem when I'm in the shower. 
But I'm here to talk about the battery in the mod. The speaker mod has its on battery, the notification bar let's you know how much battery it has. I wanted to see if the speaker mod would also charge the phone if it is connected. So I left the mod on the phone over night to see. No. The speaker mod does not charge they phone at all. 
The speaker mod has a USB C connection on the back of it to charge while off of the phone. But once again I wanted to know if I could charge it while it is on the phone. So I plugged the phone in with the speaker mod attached to the phone. It charged both the phone and the speaker mod. 
So 
1. The speaker mod will not charge the phone. 
2. The phone will charge the speaker mod.

I guess it makes sense that the battery is for the speaker itself and not for the phone. I mean, you have to power a speaker somehow. Either it has it's own battery, it has a cord, or it gets power from the phone - those are the only choices. At least it doesn't drain the phone battery (unless it does so after the mod battery is dead? Can't imagine I'll ever try to find out, lol). Good to know it can't be used as a charger/battery pack in a pinch.

replies.text:
Yeah just figured I would try it out to see and then pass on the info so everybody would know. 
I wish it would have been a free battery mod instead, but I will use it.

Still nice mod.

title: Moto Z Force and the FITBIT Widget

thread.text:
Hey All,
Just got my MZF and really enjoying it. I just found one odd issue that I can't figure out. I wear a fitbit, and use the fitbit app alot. On any previous android phone I've had, the fitbit app includes a widget that allows you to have your step status on the screen. 
On the MZF, the fitbit widget isn't in the list. I've uninstalled and reinstalled for from the Play store, but it's still not showing in the widgets tray. If anyone else is using the fitbit app, can you please verify you see the widget?
Thanks.

I don't use fitbit anymore but could the app be on your SD card? This will remove the widgets.
Posted via the Android Central App

Kouki, you're a lifesaver. That is indeed what happened. I setup adoptable storage right off the bat with a 64gb card. Then I did all my app installs and just let the system put the apps wherever it wanted. The Fitbit app ended up on the card versus internal. Once I moved it to internal, BING, the widget appeared in the tray.
Thanks!

title: Quick camera test vs LG G4.

thread.text:
I'm coming from a G4 and figured just from everything I have read in the past that the camera of the Moto would not be as good but decided to go ahead and get it anyway. So I took a few pictures tonight with both phones where outside smoking a cigar. I did not edit any of the photos, only cropped one of them. The G4 camera was set on auto, the Moto was also on auto but HDR was also set to auto. I didn't notice until I was back inside. The color is better on the Moto pictures but the details are on the G4 blows it out of the water! Also a ton of noise on some of the Moto shots. 
Moto - cigar in decent light.
G4
Moto - close up of band in bad light (Was very hard to get the Moto to focus)
G4

Moto - full shot of cigar in decent light
G4
Moto - shot of trees and sky (noise is so bad)
G4

Moto - parking lot
G4
Moto - crop of the same picture
G4

My guess is you'd have had better results on the Z with HDR turned off. With it on, photos take just a little bit longer and it introduces an opportunity for blur from motion (from you moving too soon because you think the shot is over). Or at least I hope so, because those needs some help, lol! Love the lens flare on the parking lot shot with the G4.

replies.text:
If I get a chance tonight I will try again, in the same spot. But I don't think detail wise, at least in low light it can match the G4. LG really has some great cameras. 
But I was impressed with the color from the Moto. Got some real nasty over head lights in that area and that is what throws off the color on the G4 shots.

thread.text: Is anyone else impressed that phone cameras have come so far? Here we can analyze and scrutinize over details of photos, but the fact is photos coming from phones today are really very very good, and they're destroying the point-and-shoot camera market. It's getting to where you almost need a DSLR to bother with anything but a phone camera!

Quick reminder:Community Rules & Guidelines - Mobile Nations Forums

I agree with the general sentiment that there's no need for arguing in this way over things that are clearly subjective, but one thing about this comment just didn't ring true... 
Moto is really the only major manufacturer that has gotten battery life right for the last 3 generations of their flagships, well ahead of their time. From the Droid Max, to the Turbo and Turbo 2 they've consistently had battery capacities that for their relative sizes are significantly larger than the competition's. The other manufacturers, namely Samsung in this case, are just catching up if anything. So to ask how the phone reacts while you're using it, and imply it dies under 1 day just like any other phone, is completely erroneous. On the last 3 phones I've owned by Moto, I can get through more than a day with heavy use without any issues, and it sounds like the Force is comparable. Add the Mod battery pack and that's just icing on the cake. 
You can brag all you want about various Samsung features unavailable on the Force, and maybe Samsung got things right in terms of battery life with the S7 Edge this year, but don't make it seem like or forget that Moto has been the king of battery life for years at this point. Obviously you're entitled to your opinion, but objectively speaking Moto knows what they're doing when it comes to battery performance.

What's better and cheaper?

Most people plug their phone in at night, it becomes moot how well the battery performs while doing nothing. If the battery is so great it should last longer throughout the day not just the night. But that really isn't the case is it. At best it gets you through more than a day but you will most likely have to plug it in right away in the morning. OP3 is better and cheaper, Nexus 6P is better and cheaper, ZTE Axon 7, heck even the $300 Robin is a better phone. Motorola was good for a while, but they have clearly lost their mojo. replies.text:
Something is worth what someone will pay. I appreciate the fact you dont like it. But others do. You think it's ugly and that's OK. I happen to think it's the best designed phone all year. And that's even with my OP3, s7 edge, HTC 10, Note 5, iPhone 6s plus and other devices I have had this year. So what's that worth. Nothing. It only matters to me. 
So far I think the Z fares far better than all those other devices. But that's in my eyes. But to call something better or worse or ugly or whatever is the user opion not fact. The Moto Z is running almost the same hardware as everyone else minus the camera and wireless charging.

While I can see where someone might prefer some of those other phones, I disagree that they're straight-up "better". I can spell out why on a model-by-model basis if you like. It seems that you simply don't like Motorola phones, and think the Z is too expensive. That's fine, you're entitled to your opinion, though at some point sharing repeatedly without getting into why isn't productive, and you need to understand that some of your complaints are simply preference or opinion.
I do agree that it's disappointing that updates aren't as fast or dependable as they once were. That was one thing that made me hesitate at buying my Zf. However, while I was tempted to hold out for one of the new Nexus phones, my previous phone was the Nexus 6, and I really missed some of the Motorola features, like the enhanced always listening, twist for camera, etc. My Droid Maxx didn't have the chop for flashlight or the sensors where you can wave your hand & see notifications, and I'm loving those additions.
Also, while it's fair to be cautious about build quality with the transition over to devices developed under Lenovo, there's every indication that the build quality on the Z/Zf is excellent. You ask why it's worth similar money as iPhones or Samsung Galaxys, and the answer is build quality, features & specs, and discounts (few are going to pay full price for these phones, unless it's through a no-interest 2yr payment plan).
By the way, the camera bump is only there if you don't use a style mod, which is included, and I think Moto expects most people to use if they're not using another mod. You question the mods' usefulness, and that's fair, but the phone is excellent without them. And the regular Z has enough battery to go through a day for more average users, and the Force has enough battery to get through the day for somewhat heavy users. The fact that the battery mod is an option is icing on the cake. I have the Zf, and so far I don't see myself buying a battery mod unless i'ts on sale and I buy it for when I travel and use my phone heavily due to a lot of time to kill. Or I may just stick with the battery bank I already have.

Ugly to me ok fine I'll give you that, but as to the why? Really? Do I have to go through the list again? Did you even read my post? Expensive, lack of updates, too small a battery, no headphone jack etc.. These are not preferences, there is no excuse for a phone of this price to not be updated or to have a small battery. You expect that from cheapo phones, but $700+ phone should be updated. OP3 doesn't have the build quality? Nexus 6P doesn't have the build quality? Axon 7 doesn't have the build quality? Why so are they priced so much lower? What justifies the $300 or so more in money? The days of $700 phones is coming to an end and the sooner Lenovo realizes the better. Most mid range phones have an 820 chip, a good camera, a good battery. Something must differentiate them from the rest of the pack. In Moto and LG you find mods, others are choosing to go on price. 
I'm not hating on the Z, I think the HTC 10 and LG are in the same boat as these Z phones, overpriced. So is Apple and so is Samsung, but for whatever reason perceived cache or superior build i.e waterproof. Those guys are able to get people to pay $700. Sony, HTC, LG, Lenovo are all trying to get a foothold in the $700+ high margin market. Why choose any of those guys? What is compelling about their phones to justify those prices? Build quality??? Nobody wants to get in a race to the bottom, but eventually something has to give. There just aren't enough people on this planet who can keep paying those every 2 years. This one probably the worst offense, they couldn't figure out a way to make that bump flush? So you need a style cover to fix a poor engineering job? It's a plate that does nothing except to make the camera flush. Why not just make a bigger battery and no bump and no style cover? I'm not a fan of these camera bumps on any phone but Lenovo has taken it to a new level. They seem proud of that bump when they should be ashamed. They took leftovers from all those unsold watches and plugged them into the back of the phone.

title: A case tip for those of us who aren't that bright

thread.text:
So, my wife bought me a case and car charger while I was at work. Here's the casehttps://www.tech21.com/en_us/impact-...-z-force-droid 
Quick tip: After wondering why such an expensive case wouldn't fit, I realized you have to take the Moto Skin off before it will work, 
That is all.

I would have done the exact same thing. Fortunately, I did see the note on the style mod packing that you should remove the style mod before using a case. I bought an Otterbox Commuter to use for those occasions where I may be out and a "little" impaired. Otherwise, the style mod is my case.

The Z Force does not record video while plugged in, even though the camera UI says it's recording.
This with the stock camera, which randomly stopped, and adoptable storage. The battery was charged over 12% during the first video.
I figured the camera was stopping due too battery and plugged it in again, which caused another video to not be saved.
All videos recorded while not plugged in were saved.

replies.text: Plugged into a computer or just charger? If you are plugged into the computer, this could make complete sense, if you are not plugged in as a media device and only mass storage it may be the reason, If just charger, then that is a mystery
Just plugged into the included turbo charger.Sometimes you gotta do what you gotta do.

thread.text:
I don't think I've ever tried to record video while its plugged in and charging.
Posted via the Android Central App

replies.text: Just plugged into the included turbo charger.Sometimes you gotta do what you gotta do.

thread.text:
Here's another weird one!
The phone will not charge from a Samsung charger with a Type-c Cable!
I thought it was just their fast charger but it doesn't work with their regular charger either.
*My wife is a Samsung fan and after some years of new hones and replacements the chargers are everywhere. Plus the quick charger was pretty good.

replies.text: This isn't correct, I'm using the fast charger that came with with note 5 along with a USB type C cable from Amazon and it works fine. It even detects it as a turbo charger

Which cable did you order? This is the one I bought: https://www.amazon.com/gp/aw/d/B0198...cUvbUpU5299946
It must come down to the cable.

I got this one. It's a 2 pack. 
Kenex® 2 Pack (Silver) 3/6ft USB 3.1 Nylon Braided Type-C Male to Standard USB 3.0 Type A Male Cable USB Charging Cable Cord for Apple New MacBook, Chromebook Pixel, Nokia N1 and Other Type-C Devices https://www.amazon.com/dp/B01BAG9TBS...cUvbUpU5300109

Just tried our Samsung fast charger with this exact cable and it charges the phone. (The Sammy charger also charges the wireless battery pack using the Samsung wireless charger, although with a micro USB cable used, obviously.)

Since I redid the phrase it's not had one false positive. Originally it took 3 tries to find an echo free room.I don't know then. I've tried two fast chargers and a regular Samsung charger and none work. Every other charger works with the cable.
It doesn't fast charge it, just charges it. To avoid any confusion.
With the ones I linked above, it fast charges using the Samsung charger.

thread.text:
I changed the title because I'm finding lots of oddness and don't want to keep making threads.
Today's oddness: I kept getting false hits on my launch phrase so I changed it. I could not get Moto Voice to except the "OK Moto Z" launch phrase.
Using it it would launch google search and enter the entire phrase in the search bar ex: "OK Moto Z set timer for 30 minutes".
Changing to "OK Google Now" works mostly. Sometimes just "OK Google" works, Sometimes neither works.

replies.text: I think more syllables is the key. I'm currently using "OK Alexander".

This used to happen with the last few Moto phones when you create the launch phrase in a room where there's some white noise in the background. 
You have to be somewhere completely silent, or likely more silent than the room you were in.

Since I redid the phrase it's not had one false positive. Originally it took 3 tries to find an echo free room.I don't know then. I've tried two fast chargers and a regular Samsung charger and none work. Every other charger works with the cable.
It doesn't fast charge it, just charges it. To avoid any confusion.
With the ones I linked above, it fast charges using the Samsung charger.

thread.text:
So, I fell for the modular design and close to stock android features and decided to upgrade. I picked up a Z Force on the release day, then left for a long weekend/ vacation to see what would happen. I'm not a power user, I may have 20 apps or so but I work out of two offices and on the road so I need something that is capable of doing everything, including a hot spot when needed. So, Its been almost a week and here is what I've learned. 
1. Its big. Yep, I moved from a Thunderbolt, to a G2 to a G3, then to the Moto. It's big, but not unruly, won't fit in a back pocket .
2. Its more stock than I'm used to. I got used to having a lot of features that this phone doesn't have. At first, it was strange, then I realized I never used most of the stuff anyway. Simple seems better to me. 
3. Display. I can read this anywhere. Indoor, outdoor, its fine.
4. Camera. Simple, not the best but far from the worst. I like the fact that it just uses Google Photo and no BS.
5. Antennae. I can connect to any wifi and the phone works fine. Data seems to be able to connect with no issue also. 
6. Battery. Quite simply, its great. I can get all day and more. My first day was a fairly light day and I forgot to plug it in before bed. It had 40% in the morning. Not too shabby. When I get a mod battery, it will probably last two solid days under light use. 
7. I bought an case for it and it sucks. The USB C charger is big and it charges fast, but all the cases seem to be designed for micro USB.
8. Fingerprint sensor. Just as weird as getting used to the back buttons on the LG's I owned. After about a week, I've adapted.
Overall, I'm happy so far. I'll keep updating if problems arise.

replies.text: You will easily go 2 or more days without charging with the battery mod.
Depending on usage, but for most that's probably true.
Fair point, but I find the Force to have fantastic battery life even without the mod.

thread.text: BTW, download the Google Now launcher, which should come stock but doesn't.

replies.text:
Isn't the stock launcher pretty similar to Google Now? What are the primary differences for you? And do Moto Gestures and Display still work with a different launcher?
Posted via the Android Central App

It's funny because AOSP's stock launcher is Launcher3 but the Nexus devices use Google Now Launcher, which is just a Google-fied version of Launcher3.
The Moto Z uses Launcher3.

thread.text: It is very similar. The app tray is white instead of black on the Google Now Launcher. With the Google Now launcher, you get the left swipe feature that puts you right into Google Now.

replies.text: Gotcha. Thanks. I don't use Google Now so guess I'll just stick with stock for now. I'm enjoying it as is, though I do wish it allowed for five icons, instead of only four.

thread.text:
I use the Google launcher as well simply for the Google now screen to the far left. All of the moto features still work when using Google launcher
OP I was thinking of buying a case as well but decided that a style mod and screen protector will essentially be my "case." 
Posted via the Android Central App

You probably know this, but Nova Prime is a great 3rd party Launcher. I'm still using my Turbo 2 with it. Six icons across the bottom, with an actual Home screen, with a screen to the right and left as well. It's not quite as convenient to get to the Now cards, but a very nice replacement launcher.

I also added Nova Launcher to mine. Only having 4 icons/folders across the screen was driving me crazy. I have never used an outside launcher but I'm getting used to the extra stuff and enjoying it. 
Other wise enjoying the phone. I like the fact that the finger print scanner also turns off the screen instead of a home button. Coming from LG it more takes the place of knock on and off. I guess if you come from Samsung it would probably drive you crazy for a little while.

I think that Launcher3 is default so they can auto-rotate the launcher due to Moto Mods.
Posted via the Android Central App on the Moto X Pure Edition

title: Moto Z Droid Force or Galaxy Note 7?

thread.text:
Read about the Note 7 today. Watched some hands-on videos. All I can say is WOW!
I was set to hunt down a Moto Z - living in the Boondocks so they aren't nearby (only a non-Force in a contract retailer) - but now I need to check out a Note 7 in person before deciding.
The Note 7 has the same SoC and battery as the Force, with a slightly larger screen. Personally I really like the tightened curved edge screen design. Plus it has 64GB internal storage, micro SD card extra storage, and USB-C charging PLUS a headphone jack, & built-in wireless charging. Some nice extra features, too, like Gorilla Glass 5, over the Force. The overall form factor seems to be about the same on both.
I think the Moto Mods concept is awesome, especially the wireless chargeable battery pack, that can be used to 'protect' the life span of the internal battery. I also got to listen to the add-on speaker Mod, and was really impressed.
Samsung pulled a shocker here!!

replies.text: Note 7 will probably get more updates, has a better camera, and of course the s pen and its features. That being said, both seem like solid devices.

thread.text:
I came from the S7 Edge which is very similar to the Note 7. 
I am digging the Force because of the great battery life (same battery as the S7 Edge without the battery mod), stock software, adaptable storage, and of course the mods.
Posted via the Android Central App

Until today I'd have said Z Force. Now I'm not so sure. I'm locked into the Z at this point, but I'm not sure it's the obvious choice. The N7 does a lot in a smaller package (check the specs, it's shorter and narrower, but not as thin). The camera is likely superior but that remains to be seen. It's waterproof. Are Moto enhancements, mods, and near-stock worth the trade?
Bear in mind that the N7 is going to cost $860, though.

All valid points for sure. I personally was originally planning to get the Z and test it out knowing I was going to get the Note 7. Well after seeing the reveal today I am going to pass. But for me I had the S7 edge twice so it's not that different. I really truer truly enjoy the Z more. 
Now my wife on the other hand who has had a iPhone the past couple years wants the Note 7 since her last Android device was the Note 4. So I'll probably do that around the holidays for her. But as for me I have zero plans unless something crazy happens.

Z Force for me! I have a Note 5 right now. I never get the iteration of the phone that I already have. I must admit that I was waiting to hear about the Note 7 today, but after the event was over I was over it and kept my focus on getting the Z Force.
Posted via the Android Central App

This is what's so awesome about Android. 
We have a choice.
Posted via the Android Central App on the Moto X Pure Edition

I played with the Note last week before I picked up my Moto Z Force. Nothing really jumped out to me as "WOW" like the Moto Z did. The Note is nice. Its a very "solid" phone. Its very hefty and feels like very good build quality. I'm not a fan of the curved screen though. The edge of the screen goes right up to the edge and without a case I would be afraid that I would be constantly hitting the edge of the screen even just moving it between hands. The pen is nice, but I never used it on previous notes. Everything was very fluid in the interface, but it still has the touchwiz interface, which is way better than it used to be, but i prefer stock android. 
The mods are just really exciting. I also feel like Moto built such a quality phone and actually innovated, so I want to reward them. That's just me though. 
All in all, the Note is probably the best phone on every carrier except Verizon. I still feel like the Z Force is a better .... or at least more exciting phone ... than the Note. With that said, I'm keeping my Z Force, but my fiance is picking up the Note because she likes the Pen and shes on ATT.

I was going to go Z Force, but the new Note 7 is tempting. It has a larger screen by .2" with a smaller form factor as there are zero side bezels and a much smaller bottom bezel plus capacitive buttons instead of on screen buttons so you get to actually use the entire screen. I wonder how the 3500mah battery will fare in comparison to the Z Force since the Note has the larger screen. It also has wireless charging and there is the motomod like battery case. I hate the fingerprint prone glass rear though! It's tempting. I'm going to have to go check it out in person.

Where is the motomod battery case? I just pre ordered a note 7, coming from a note 4. I was going to get the z force but wanted to stick with the note series.
Posted via the Android Central App

replies.text: I saw it in the Marquis Brown youtube vid. Not sure when/where its for sale.

thread.text: Since the internal specs are pretty much identical, this will probably come down to form factor for most. I expect the Z Force will have better battery life - since there's no Touchwiz to gum up the works, the screen is a bit smaller, and the fact the Z Force already has better battery life than the S7 Edge, which has the same battery as the Note 7 - but I really don't think you can go wrong with either one.

I'm not sure how much use I'd get out of the S-pen. But since the phones just keep getting larger the smaller form factor is attractive. Perhaps I can get some form of skin to put on the back to stop the finger prints. Like previous iPhones, I don't know why they can't just have an aluminum back. No one likes fingerprints. No Moto display. I'll have to look into how their always on display is. The Note doesn't have motion sensors right? So that should save a little battery life, although trade that for the always on screen and I'm not sure which wins.

replies.text: One thing to keep in mind .. Always on display only works with Samsung apps as far as I'm aware. I didn't find a way to use 3rd party apps when i had the s7 Edge. So i use textra for my texting app and it wouldn't show up on the Always on display like it does for the Moto.
Well that's kinda sucky. So you're forced to use the Samsung texting app then? And does it matter if you change the launcher?
If you want Always On Display notifications you have to use the Samsung app. I have no idea on the launcher because i didn't do that when i had it.

Yeah, the way Sammy utilizes AOD renders it relatively useless. I keep thinking they're going to make significant improvements to it, but so far it's not in the same ballpark as Moto's version.
Posted via the Android Central App

thread.text:
Had the s7 edge and the note doesn't seem like much of a upgrade. Love everything about my force.
Posted via the Android Central App

replies.text:
Its technically not an upgrade of the edge. I can't think of any reason to get the note 7 over the force or any high end phone unless you're a fan of the note series. Many of the Note fans are disappointed that it doesn't have a removable battery.
Posted via the Android Central App

thread.text: I wouldn't use most of the functions that the Note would offer.

I really like the larger screen size in a smaller form factor with zero bezels on the Note, but the lack of notification on the AOD just seems pointless. So, to know if you have an email or text from a 3rd party app you have to actually turn the screen on? There is no other way to know unless you check manually? No LED or anything else? That just seems dumb and after using the Moto display on my last 3-4 phones could be a deal breaker. Everything else about the Note seems awesome though.

replies.text: I do believe it has a notification LED at least.

thread.text: I returned my Z Force and will be getting the Note 7. I had been using a Note 3 so no matter what I get will be a big upgrade. I didn't realize how often I use multiwindow until I didn't have it. Lack of FoxFi support on Moto devices was another deal breaker. If it wasn't for either of those two things though I'd give the Z Force two thumbs up. Awesome battery life, speed, camera and feel.
This vid says that 3rd party apps will show up on the AOD.

replies.text: Interesting ... They must have updated it from the s7 edge
They said third party would eventually show up on AOD for the S7 and S7 Edge too - and that hasn't happened.
I'll be dubious til I see it work in person

title: MOD Question about the battery pack

thread.text:
Is there a difference between the Incipio and the Tumi battery pack? 
How thick will the Force be with one of these?

I'd love to hear the dimensions on the battery pack as well. Also, how does it work? Does it charge the phone's battery or does it connect to the phone such that the phone reads the phone battery plus the battery pack as one giant battery?

I'm heard somewhere in the forum that it charges the battery, which is not as good as adding to the existing capacity. That's a little more complicated and would require some kind of balancer. Not sure if it was just speculation on how it will work.
Posted via the Android Central App
I wish I could remember the article or video they described it. I would certainly hope there is some intelligence to maximize its effectiveness.
The recent reviews say that the battery will actually be a charger battery like Mophie for iPhones

replies.text: Which reviews said this? I haven't seen any reviews released yet.

thread.text:
I guess its better than nothing.
Posted via the Android Central App

I wonder how much battery life it'll add. 
Battery cases usually are about 60% efficient.
Posted via the Android Central App
Hopefully there will be some intelligent management that will improve that.
I wonder does the battery pack have a seperate charging port? or does it have to be on the phone to be charged.
It appears that this crop must be charged piggybacked to the phone, but I don't see why other iterations couldn't have that feature.

replies.text: The wireless charging mod DOES NOT have to be attached to the phone to charge. Just set it on your wireless charger and it charges.

thread.text: At least one of them was described as not having its own charging port, but has to be charged on the phone (or as someone on this forum confirmed, charged by itself on a wireless charger).

I bought the $90 battery with wireless charging. The box is at home though with the dimensions. Wife bought the phone and brought it to my work so I could set it up.
Posted via the Android Central App
Question about the battery mod - is there any way to set it to turn on at 50% rather than 80%? Seems like it would be good for the user to be able to set the percentage at which it turns on.

replies.text:
I would assume they chose that % due to efficiency or battery health reasons, but I'm always up for more control (with recommendations & rationale) over less.
(Sorry, I don't have the battery mod & can't actually answer your question.)
Supposedly a charging battery is more efficient between 60 and 80 percent. Outside that range with takes more voltage to effect the same level of charge. Or so I read this morning.

thread.text: The battery packs approximately double the thickness. They charge the onboard battery to 100%, or 80% in efficiency mode. The attached battery pack will not charge unless using a quick charge charger on the phone.The wireless charging pack will charge on the wireless charger and pass through to the onboard battery.
Could I just leave the power pack on the phone at all times?
Yes you can no problem. Once the battery pack is depleted it will just use phone battery. It won't hurt anything leaving the battery mod on.

replies.text: This is exactly what I'm doing. It's incredible. There's nothing I could do to kill the battery in a single day.

Nothing you *could* do? I bet it wouldn't make it through a full day of obsessive Pokemon Go. lol It'll be interesting in time to see what the top screen-on time someone posts will be.
*edit* Also, the fact that someone could just buy a couple extra battery mods & keep playing without interruption or having to be tethered to anything is cool to think about.
Great point.

thread.text:
The battery pack will keep the phone charged to 100% or with efficiency mode 80%. So everytime the phone goes below those numbers the charger kicks in to recharge until the pack is depleted. Then the internal battery is on its own. 
Just wondering if this constant charging won't affect overall battery life? Not that many people keep their phones long enough anymore for that to matter.
Posted via the Android Central App

replies.text: It's good for the internal battery because you are not using cycles when using the battery mod. If anything heat might hurt it but it doesn't really get warm.

thread.text: As Veteater explained in the Z forum, it doesn't work like that. There's no way the battery mod can be charging the internal battery and keeping it at 80% while you're using the phone. So he says the battery mod depletes itself first. I don't have the phone so I can't test it but it makes sense to me. If so, that would be very good for efficiency and for the life of the internal battery.
I'm on 54 hours with my tumi battery mod. I posted screen shots in different thread. Very happy with the results.

It would really be ideal if that's the way it was. But in my opinion the battery pack is just a charger. It's not an additional battery which can be accessed by the phone for power.
Why do you think it couldn't charge the phone while the phone's in use? And if you're saying it wouldn't be able to actually keep it at 80% while it's being used, I agree, but it would be charging all the while until it's finally back at that percentage. 
Again, and this is just my opinion, the battery pack exists for one reason only. To charge the internal battery. When it's depleted then you would see the internal battery start to decrease from 80% or 100% depending on the settings.
So as I said earlier, the phone would be in a constant state of charging, which I think would degrade the internal battery as time goes on.
Posted via the Android Central App

replies.text: I understand your logic and while I'm not disagreeing answer me this. If just like the original turbo that I came from if in the beginning I only charge every 2.5 days with the battery mod and 1.5 days without it how will it degrade the battery faster with the battery mod. My turbo used to go 3 days and at the end maybe 6-8 hours. But that was 3 year timeframe.

thread.text: I don't know, the 16pin connector provides some pretty deep integration. I wouldn't be surprised if it is able to draw directly from the battery pack.

The phone battery doesn't go below 80% unless the battery mod is depleted. I love that.
Posted via the Android Central App

Just so I'm clear, you are not leaving your battery mod on all the time? If that's the case than no, it wouldn't degrade the battery at all. But if you are, then I'm not quite sure I understand your question. Again, I want to be clear that if I purchased this phone I would really want to leave it on all the time as it's very convenient and you can never have enough battery, right! But I also tend to think of what's best for battery longevity, not that I ever seem to keep a phone long enough to make that concern a reality .

replies.text:
I bought the phone and battery mod with the intention of leaving the mod on at all times. But now I've decided to only use the battery mod on days I won't be near a charger. 
Why? First, while not too big, the mod adds a good amount of weight to the phone. Second, the battery life on the Z Force is pretty incredible without the mod. I'm getting 7-8 hours of SOT without the mod.

thread.text:
Well up to today I have left it on all the time. Posted are the results of that. I kind of want to leave it on and not have to worry about it. But you bring up good points. I'm hoping someone with much more knowledge than me can advise the best way to use it. I love the fact I could go this long with only having to charge it once.

thread.text: Well I had my Force since since Monday night so far here the things that I like and I don't like about it I love the fact that I can operate it with one hand. I came from an LG V10 which was very tough to operate with one hand especially with an OtterBox on it the fingerprint scanner on the Z Force is a heck of a lot better then the one on the V10 battery life is excellent so far I love the lack of bloatware on this thing it takes a little getting used to the UI compared to what I have been using on previous Samsung and LG phones. I got the speaker Mod for free at Best Buy but haven't used it yet so I really can't comment on its use slash quality I also ordered the power pack mod with wireless charging and ordered the Verizon Wireless Charger stand. The biggest con for me right now is that it's slippery in my hand and that's due to the included back cover and design of phone other than that I am really enjoying this phone overall and once I get everything set up to where I wanted to be I think it's going to be a great phone

Like:- Overall size. My previous phone was a Nexus 6, and it was too big to use comfortably, even with my fairly big hands. I only remember dropping it once (no damage, had a case on it), but I was always having to be careful with it. I don't have to with the Z Force.- Speed. Very fast & responsive, usually the only time it lags is if there's a network connection issue that slows it down.- Battery. I don't have the battery mod, and so far I'm not having trouble getting through normal, or even semi-high use days. I also like knowing that if I do find myself needing more battery, between fast charging and the available battery mod, it shouldn't be an issue.- Fingerprint scanner. This is on a lot of phones now, but it's the first I've had, and I love it.- Fast camera. My Nexus 6's camera was/is really slow to load, so I appreciate that the Zf camera comes up very quickly.- Moto features. 2 phones back I had a Droid Maxx, and I missed some of these features with my Nexus. The Nexus is supposed to do "always listening", but it never worked well, where the Motos have. The chop for flashlight & twist for camera is wonderful too.- Durability. I like the thought that I can't shatter my screen. I've never cracked a screen, but it's still nice to know. I did put a glass screen protector on, mostly for scratch prevention & feel.- Mods. I got the speaker mod with the BestBuy deal, and will probably use it on occasion. I might eventually want the battery w/wireless charging mod, for long trips & such. I'm looking forward to seeing what else they come up with.Dislikes:- Updates. I hate knowing that Lenovo will probably suck at updating the phone quickly or for very long.- No built in Qi charging. I'm holding out on a thin wireless charging mod.- Not likely to be "Daydream certified" like the upcoming Nexus phones likely will be.
Overall, it's excellent.
Anyone tried Wi-Fi Tethering yet? Verizon still got that locked down so they can extort more money?
IIRC it only costs extra on the unlimited data plan as an add-on. For any other plan it is included.

Yeah, I'm on their "large" plan, and can use tethering/hotspot at will without any tricks. They only limit the unlimited data, which is part of why I had to give it up eventually. Thethering is too useful to me.

I was almost ready to upgrade to this from my 7 month old Turbo2, but I've become so used to how handy wireless charging is it would be hard to give it up. I figured it would just be standard on all phones going forward. I love just setting it on the stand next to my bed and grabbing it as necessary while I'm in bed as well as mounting it on the wireless charger in my car for using with Waze. I suppose it would have made the phone a little thicker, but they could have used it to fill in some of that space of the camera that sticks out.

thread.text: I think the combo will feel quite heavy, but not ridiculously chunky.

I just want to point out to you wireless charging fans that there is no such thing as wireless charging. Its a myth, a cheap magicians trick with smoke and mirrors. Only Telsa was able to transmit electricity without wires.
Posted via the Android Central App

replies.text: Well, Nikola must be crouched down next to my bed every night because I set my phone on the charger with no wires connected to the phone and when I wake it up its all charged. Now, there is a mirror next to the nightstand so maybe that's part of how it charges. Never smelled any smoke though...

A part of me is injecting humor but reality is that it is not true wireless charging. You are still connected to wires and not transmitting electricity across an air gap. True wireless charging if someone ever figures out how to do it safely and efficiently would mean you phone would receive electricity over the air just like a cell signal. Wireless charging would impress me if my phone could sit in my pocket and be charged from across the room.
Posted via the Android Central App

Yes, I've heard that is theoretically coming some day. But, alas... there still likely has to be wires to power the source spreading the energy into the air right? Still not technically wireless. Now maybe if I could get a charge from a rock or some other object...

To transmit wireless you have a transmitter and receiver across a gap of air as opposed to the way its done now holding two objects together. The wires at the transmitter would not count.
Posted via the Android Central App

Are you inferring that it's conductive rather than inductive?
Posted via the Android Central App

I'm not inferring anything.... Just stating the obvious
Posted via the Android Central App

While current wireless charging is short-ranged, it has nothing to do with "holding two objects together", and is unique from conductive charging. While longer range wireless charging could be sweet, the hope for it doesn't make inductive wireless charging irrelevant to everyone, and it doesn't mean it's a "myth" or "smoke and mirrors". How it works isn't a secret, and it does work without wires between the transmitter and receiver.

I understand perfectly how it works but you are still holding to objects together in its present form. You can call it wireless if you want but until you can separate the receiver and transmitter by a decent gap of air its not truly wireless.
Posted via the Android Central App
Considering the lack of a wire connection, it is by definition wireless.

Picking some mighty fine nits there....
I think what you're trying to convey is practicality, or maybe more specifically, applicability.
Its pretty trivial to increase the power handling capability of the transmitter and receiver. The practicality of it, or applications for it, are pretty non-existent beyond radio or radar, which are specialized examples of wireless power transfer.
Just because this application is on a small scale to address convenience and connector wear and tear, doesn't change the nature of what is happening.
Posted via the Android Central App

title: What accessories should I get for the Moto Z Force?

thread.text: I am looking to buy the Moto Z Force plus the Moto Mod power pack next month and so I want to go ahead and change out all my chargers and cables but I do not know what to get. I have been looking at quick charge 3.0 but not sure if the Moto Z supports it. Also what USB-C cables should I buy as well. Looking at 1 charger for home, car charger, work charger, and a charger for trips. Also should I get a screen protector? Any other advise would be appreciated.

It does not appear to support QC3 (the phone will charge, but not "turbo" charge). At least one person has reported it supporting his Apple USB-C charger for turbo charging. I suspect it supports a true USB-C standard, where many of the past devices with type-c connectors were actually USB 2 with the type C plug. I don't know that anyone has confirmed that yet, though.
I'd be sure to get the power pack with wireless charging, unless you just hate wireless charging. $10 more & doesn't seem to make the mod any bigger.
It may be a bit soon to assume it's the same with the Z Force, but many have reported that on the Turbo2 with shattershield screen, it was easy to scratch the top lens. It's replaceable, but still disappointing to have it scratch up. I went ahead with a Zagg glass protector on my Z Force, and am pretty happy with it. There's a thread for screen protectors, someone may be able to recommend a less expensive one from Amazon. I'd get a specific recommendation, though - sounds like the cheap Amazon protectors for the Z Force are hit & miss.

I bought some Aukey USB 3 to Type C cables from Amazon, and they're working fine, though I don't have a charger to test turbo charging through them with. I may eventually pick up a Type C charger & C to C cable, but I'll probably wait for more specific information & reviews on what to look for in a charger & cable to be sure it works for turbocharging.

title: Upgraded from Note 3. Any FoxFi alternatives?

thread.text:
My Note 3 still works well and carrying around extra batteries has been what's kept me going with it. I had recently compared pictures from my phone to friends newer phones and realized it was time to see what else is out there and this Z Force caught my attention. First impression was that it felt heavier than my Note 3 which I was surprised at. I didn't pay attention to weight specs and just assumed it'd be lighter. No problem with me there. Screen brightness is excellent. Running apps is nice and snappy. Pics look great. I'm sure it's safe to say that ANY phone purchased today would be a night and day difference to the Note 3.
The only thing that'll probably have me returning the phone is the fact that FoxFi doesn't work.  I'm still have an unlimited plan and it works well on road trips sharing my data with my kids device. Didn't even cross my mind to check the FoxFi site and see that Moto devices aren't supported. Anyone have any working alternatives? There's various apps out there I've tried and none seem to work.

I wouldn't count on a workaround.
Praying for a miracle but expecting it to go back. Enjoying the phone otherwise!

title: Have a Question about the phone.

thread.text: Has anyone tried to buy this phone outright and put it on straight talk or another carrier to see if it will work? I'm thinking of getting one but don't want to if it wont work on straight talk.

It won't work on Straight Talk ever. The Z Force is going to be a permanent Verizon exclusive, while the regular Z will eventually be released in an unlocked model that will work on Straight Talk. 
If you're using Straight Talk's Verizon service, it will work. But if you're using their AT&T or T-Mobile service, the Force will never work.

replies.text:
Just because it's sold for Verizon doesn't mean it can't work on Straight Talk. The Droid Maxx was a Verizon exclusive, but works on Straight Talk. 
The phone is unlocked, it's mainly a question of whether it has the right radios in it.
I assumed he meant Straight Talk's AT&T service, which was my mistake. And while the Droid Maxx had certain bands that would work on AT&T, it is missing Band 17, which is AT&T's main LTE band.

thread.text: Yes I'm using Verizon's Straight talk sim that's why i was unsure if it would work or not because I'm interested in the phone. I just don't want to get a overpriced contract with Verizon is all.

replies.text:
In that case it should work just fine, since it'd be running on Verizon's network anyway. 
Out of curiosity, why not go for Verizon's pre-paid plans? As I understand it, Verizon throttles Straight Talk users to 3G speeds, whereas Verizon's pre-paid customers get 4G speeds. Prices between Straight Talk's plans and Verizon's pre-paid plans are pretty comparable as well.

Quick question regarding Moto's touchless commands on the Moto Z Force Droid (MZFD). Coming from the Turbo, and before that the DM, I'm used to using my catch phrase to read my notifications. On my MZFD when I use my launch phrase I get to the pin unlock screen which negates the whole purpose of touchless. I keep going through the settings, but I don't see a command to eliminate that pin setting screen. It seems Moto keeps dumbing down its touchless implementation on its phones. It's the touchless controls which have kept me in the Moto universe. Thanks in advance...
edison

The trouble is that the always listening voice phrase is very unsecure, and prone to false positives. It's super handy, but if you need any sort of security on your phone, then it negates it. So, if you have any security set up (PIN, fingerprint, etc), then they can't really let the voice phrase bypass that security without it making it moot.
So, there are 2 solutions:
- Don't use any security. Turn off any & all PIN, fingerprint, etc. This is done under Security in the settings menu. Then it should work with the phrase seamlessly.
- Set up trusted places/devices so that you generally don't have to put in security information if you're in a secure place or connected to a trusted device, and the phrase should work most of the time without having to put in security information.

title: Thoughts after playing with Moto Z Force DROID Edition

thread.text:
I went to the Verizon store and played with The Z and Z Force and compared them to my Turbo 2
The screen size is supposed to be 0.1" larger on the Z, but I'm not sure how that is since the length seems the same and the screen is thinner than the T2. Screen image quality seemed similar. As has been said in reviews, with that mongo bottom bezel why didn't they put the buttons down there??? I'll just assume there was no room to fit extra electronics. 
With the regular wood back on the Force the phone felt fine and very comfortable in the hand, although when I put the battery mod on it it became unnecessarily heavy for something you'd carry around all day. I don't know how that compares to people with other phones that use Mophie cases, but I can't see carrying the phone around with the battery mod all day, nor can I see putting it on just to use it for wireless charging. It was comfortable to hold as far as size and shape, but just too heavy.
The phone seemed fast, but all brand new phones seem that way. My T2 has significant lag with a lot of things which really annoys me. I clear the cache every so often which helps some, but it's still laggy.
The camera seemed good, although it's hard to get a good sense just testing it there in the store and then not being able to send myself full res versions of the pics to compare. It should take better pics than my T2 though.
The fingerprint scanner wasn't set up, but I could tell that it reacts very fast just based on it prompting me to set it up when I touched my finger to it. 
I didn't find the visible sensors on the white model to be annoying at all, certainly not any more than on my white T2, which is to say that I really don't even notice them. 
With the back off and the phone sitting flat there is definitely wobble because of the camera protruding. Don't plan on doing any typing like that. I can't really see using these phones without a back on them. 
I can't imagine using either the video or speaker mods myself. The store rep said he would use the projector mod for presentations or for showing movies on the side of his house outside at night. Really? Ok. I don't know when I'd use the speaker as opposed to a regular bluetooth speaker option with better sound.
So in the end... I'm not sure if it's worth the cost of the upgrade or not for me. I could probably manage without the 3.5mm jack, but I really like the wireless charging on my T2 for sitting on my nightstand at night and just grabbing it off to check things and then placing it back to charge. I also use an AirDock in my car that provides some wireless charging. I think if they came out with just a thin back that just adds wireless charging I could probably be talked into the phone. I'd be curious to know how the 3500mah battery would last in a normal day for me compared to the 3750 on my T2. I'm not sure how the faster/more efficient processor fits into that equation.

Having used a Mophie (among other battery cases) in the past, this Moto Mod power pack is more convenient in my eyes. Opinions will differ I'm sure, but this is much less bulky and cumbersome than a battery case. Especially having access to every single port and how quickly it can be applied/removed. And I can just drop it on my wireless charger and it charges as well. Very pleased with the power pack.

replies.text: I don't doubt that it's better than a Mophie pack. I'm just used to carrying the phone naked so it is significantly heavier than I'm used to. That's more what I was meaning.
I understand. I do as well, but if I know I'm going to be out and about for a long time, I would bring a battery case. Same will go with the power mod. 99 percent of the time it won't be attached.
This is why the mod is so awesome. You can take it on and off without turning off the phone and it's incredibly fast and easy to do so.
I think it's definitely done well for what it is. I could see maybe using it on vacation or somewhere where I'd be away from a plug for some extended period of time.
This is absolutely true. The battery mod is heavy, but it's far smaller than a Mophie case.

thread.text: I get it. I normally use my devices naked as well. Never owned a Mophie case. I did buy the wireless charging mod though. It does make the device heavier than I'm used to. But since it is easier to pop on and off I have no issues. I can charge both overnight on my stand. Then if I need I'll take the mod off and pop it back on when I need more juice. Very convenient for me right now.

Well built device, but I do not like the waste of space on the front. Plenty of room for stereo speakers like the MXPE, but that would mean virtually no JBL mod sales, so I see why missing. Based on the tear down video, there would be plenty of room for front speakers and the 3.5MM jack.
I reluctantly get why no speakers (JBL sales), but zero get for lack of 3.5MM jack, unless a planned mod is a DAC with battery and 3.5MM jack. That would be a thick mod to carry though on the Force. Should have been on the device.

replies.text: I suspect the lack of 3.5mm was just to use mostly the same hardware as the regular Z. And is there plenty of space for a speaker at the lower end of the regular Z, because I suspect that's the same rationale as well. I bet they figured out what they could cram in the super-skinny Z, then just made the case a bit bigger for the bigger battery & extra screen layers on the Force, without any thought for other features they could've made fit.

thread.text: I wasn't wowed by them but I do prefer the Force, especially if one puts a glass screen protector on it. The store I was at didn't have a style shell in the display but had the other Moto mods. It certainly didn't feel like a big jump like going from the HTC Rezound to the Droid Maxx or from the Maxx to the 2015 MXPE.Those were two year jumps also. But that's the nature of cell phone advancements, unless the mods are important to you.

See for me I was looking forward to the Mods myself. I loved the overall design. The build, colors and look to me is important and they nailed it IMO. 
The way I see the Mods is a great way to enhance a already great device better. I have zero issues with any of the features built into the device. I cannot wait to see what other mods become available as well. 
Is the device for everyone , no. But so far I am very impressed. Hopefully this holds strong.
I may end up picking one up just to get a more fluid experience compared to my laggy Turbo2. I wonder how the battery life will be in comparison with the smaller battery.

replies.text: For me, battery life is about the same as the Turbo 2 (without using a mod).

title: Dropping the Moto Z Force DROID

thread.text:
lol "that's like hurting my soul"
Moto still deserves props for pursuing a screen that won't break.
Someone made the comment that the screen on the force was only slightly dimmer than the regular Z. That would be an improvement as the DT2 has a rather dim screen.

Come on, Motorola/Lenovo, let's get real with keyboards. Saw on the demo video that keyboard does not have a row for numbers. Is it that difficult to understand that numbers are used almost as often as letters? When keyboards have numbers and letters I don't need to go looking for 3rd party keyboards.

As far as I know Moto devices come with Google keyboard as default, so not their fault exactly. There are different options on the Play Store to get keyboards with different layouts and some of them, like Swiftkey, are even free. I'm not sure how the lack of some specific feature could be a problem.
That's because Moto is pretty much stock Android, so it doesn't have its own keyboard like Samsung or other OEMs. You won't get anything beside Google Keyboard pre-installed on a Nexus device either.
It's not like finding a 3rd party keyboard is difficult. You can find one in no time.

I am well aware I can find third party keyboards to suit my needs. I have owned two Nexus phones and stay away from them because I find the skins of other manufacturers provide more of what I want without customizing. Keyboards without numbers made sense when the first 3.5 inch phones came out. They continue out of laziness, nothing more.

replies.text:
Not sure where the laziness is though.
Motorola markets their devices and experience as "a bloatware-free version of Android with no unnecessary software to slow you down or uninstall". 
Posted via the Android Central App on the Moto X Pure Edition

thread.text:
That's nothing to do with laziness. Different keyboards, different options and layouts, as simple as that. My wife's got a Moto device and loves the number row, so she uses Swiftkey. And I have to say that she's very happy with it. I've got a different Moto device and I use Google keyboard. I don't like the number row, well, actually I hate watching all those numbers sitting there all the time. When I have to type an occasional number I just swipe after holding on the ’?1emoji’ key. And for a long string I just quickly switch to the number's pad (not the row) that I find more helpful.
Anyway, maybe you should join the specific Google forum and ask them to add the number row in the next update. Not a big deal.
Maybe different priorities is better than laziness. But numbers on a keyboard keep you from accessing another screen of the keyboard and should speed entry for more people.

replies.text:
These Keyboard software makers likely have data on how often numbers are used with letters. A recent Google Keyword update enabled an additional row of numbers when typing into most password fields.
Posted via the Android Central App on the Moto X Pure Edition

thread.text: Keyboards? You're talking about keyboards? Keyboards? Keyboards? Keyboards? See if anyone gets the reference.
#3. Allen Iverson was my boy. Practice?!

You're saying the manufacturers are lazy, but with this and the Nexus phones that come without added stuff, you can set them up however you want with different launchers and keyboards. It seems like perhaps it's you that doesn't want to go to the effort of finding the apps & settings that make it just how you like it. I personally prefer the manufacturer NOT make those decisions for me, as it leads to a lot of bloatware that takes up space, computing power, and delays & complicates updates. To each their own. 
Also, the Google Keyboard is getting better about providing a number row at times when it might be useful. It would be nice if they'd give the option to have it always there, though. I love the Google keyboard overall, and there's no reason I'm aware of not to provide that as an option.

thread.text: From Moto software, probably not but there are apps out there that low RAW format for newer phone models.

I'm also curious about the use of a DAC. Most DAC's for Android require a connection with a USB OTG adapter and certain apps in order to get the highest quality sound when listening to FLAC format. Would a DAC and a USB OTG adapter work with the USB C adapter?

It would. I have the Nexus 6p and you just need a USB-C to Micro USB cable and a DAC that connects via Micro USB and it works. I have been looking at doing that for a while but I haven't pulled the trigger on it.
